questions.text: According to the basis of the mode of the secretion, sweat glands present in the external genitalia are an example of the which of the following type?
questions.solution:
Classification of the gland (based on the mode of secretion)

  • Merocrine gland:
    • Secretory cells release their contents by exocytosis (no loss of cytoplasm).
    • e.g. most of the compound glands.
  • Apocrine gland:
    • Apical part of the cytoplasm of the secretory cells is lost in the process of secretion (partial loss of cytoplasm).
    • e.g. lactating mammary gland, sweat gland in the axilla and external genitalia.
  • Holocrine gland:
    • Secretory cells burst out pouring their contents, resulting in the death of the cells (complete loss of cytoplasm).
    • e.g. sebaceous gland and tarsal gland.
  • Cytocrine gland:
    • Whole cells are released as secretion.
    • e.g. ovary (ovum) and testis (spermatozoa).

Reference:

Textbook of Histology by J P Gunasegaran, 4th Edition, Page No 28, 29;

Singh's Textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page No 30, 31

choices.text: Meibomian gland dysfunction, warm compresses and lid massage

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with chronic burning, foreign body sensation, and redness in both eyes. On slit-lamp examination, there are greasy scales along the eyelashes and posterior lid margin inflammation with thickened meibomian gland secretions. What is the most likely diagnosis and the best initial management?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms and examination findings point to posterior blepharitis (Meibomian gland dysfunction), characterized by inflammation of the meibomian glands.
  • Initial treatment includes warm compresses and lid massage to express the glands.

Incorrect options:

  • A. Anterior blepharitis is characterized by flaky debris on the lashes but does not typically involve the meibomian glands.
  • B. Oral doxycycline may be used in severe or resistant cases of posterior blepharitis, but it's not the first-line treatment.
  • D. Chalazion would present as a localized eyelid mass rather than diffuse inflammation.

#blepharitis

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 8th ed, Elsevier; 2015. p. 163-167.

choices.text: Cutaneous anthrax; Gram stain and culture of skin lesion
Tetanus; Blood culture for Clostridium tetani
Leptospirosis; Urine PCR for Leptospira spp.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents with symptoms including fever, chills, and a rapidly enlarging ulcer with a black necrotic center on his forearm. He mentions handling animal hides and has no history of recent travel. Based on this presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous anthrax is Caused by Bacillus anthracis, a spore-forming bacterium.

  • A Painless papule appears at the site of spore entry, which progresses to a vesicle.
  • The vesicle ruptures, leaving a characteristic black eschar (necrotic ulcer with a black center).
  • Surrounding area may show extensive edema.
  • Usually non-painful unless secondary infection occurs.

Gram staining - Gram positive bacillus arranged in long chains with bulging spores.

On Gelatin Stab culture - Inverted fir tree appearance (slow liquefaction to gelatin)

Penicillin containing culture medium - String of Pearl appearance

Nutrient agar - Frosted glass appearance/medusa head colonies/comet tail appearance.

Capsule - Polypeptide capsule, demonstrated by Mc Fadyean reaction. Polychrome Methylene blue stain used (Capsule appears pink)

Explanation:

  1. Cutaneous anthrax; Gram stain and culture of skin lesion - Correct. The symptoms described-a black necrotic ulcer with fever and chills-are characteristic of cutaneous anthrax, a form of anthrax infection that occurs when Bacillus anthracis spores enter the skin. The diagnosis is confirmed through Gram staining and culture of the skin lesion, which reveals the characteristic large, gram-positive rods of Bacillus anthracis.
  2. Tetanus; Blood culture for Clostridium tetani - Incorrect. Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani, which typically does not cause a necrotic ulcer. It usually presents with muscle spasms and rigidity rather than a localized ulcer. Additionally, Clostridium tetani is not commonly cultured from blood but rather diagnosed based on clinical symptoms and history.
  3. Plague; Serology for Yersinia pestis - Incorrect. Plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, typically presents with buboes (swollen lymph nodes) rather than a black necrotic ulcer. The diagnostic test for plague is serology or culture for Yersinia pestis, but this is not consistent with the described skin lesion.
  4. Leptospirosis; Urine PCR for Leptospira spp. - Incorrect. Leptospirosis generally causes symptoms like fever, headache, and muscle pain rather than a localized necrotic ulcer. The diagnostic test for leptospirosis is typically urine PCR or serology for Leptospira spp., not applicable to a black necrotic ulcer.

Key Takeaway: Cutaneous anthrax should be suspected in patients presenting with a black necrotic ulcer and associated symptoms, particularly if there is a history of handling animal products. Diagnosis is confirmed by Gram staining and culture of the skin lesion.

Tag Line: Hard

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Anthrax: Clinical Information. CDC Anthrax Clinical Information

questions.text:
A Medical Officer investigating an epidemic in rural area. What is the correct sequence of steps he must follow?

a. Confirm epidemic existence
b. Verify the diagnosis
c. Formulation of hypothesis
d. Define the population at risk
e. Rapid search of cases
questions.solution:
Clinical Steps for the investigation of an epidemic are:

  • Verification of diagnosis
  • Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic
  • Defining the population at risk -
  • Obtaining a map of the area
  • Counting the population
  • Rapid search for all the cases -
  • Medical survey
  • Epidemiological case sheets
  • Searching for more cases
  • Data analysis on the basis of time, place and person
  • Formulation of hypothesis
  • Testing of hypothesis
  • Evaluation of ecological factors
  • Further investigation of the population at risk
  • Writing the report

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Formulation of the hypothesis is done in Descriptive studies.

Reference: Park's Textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Chapter 3, Page No 147-149.

choices.text: Plasmids are large, linear DNA molecules that replicate only bi-directionally.
The number of plasmids in a bacterial cell can vary widely, and replication may occur via mechanisms such as rolling circle replication.
Plasmids cannot carry genes for antibiotic resistance and are not involved in horizontal gene transfer.
Plasmids are solely responsible for the bacterial chromosome's replication and stability.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes plasmids in bacteria?
questions.solution:
Plasmids are small, circular, double-stranded DNA molecules found in bacteria and some eukaryotes, separate from chromosomal DNA.

They replicate independently of the host's chromosomal DNA.

Rolling Circle Replication:

  • Mechanism: It is a DNA replication process where a circular DNA molecule serves as the template for unidirectional synthesis.
  • Initiation: Starts with a single-strand break in one strand of the circular DNA by a specific enzyme (restriction enzyme).
  • Strand Displacement: The 3' end of the nicked strand acts as a primer, and DNA polymerase extends it while displacing the old strand.
  • Replication Products: Generates long single-stranded DNA, which can later form new circles or be converted to double-stranded DNA.
  • Examples: Common in plasmids, bacteriophages (e.g., PhiX174), and some viruses.

Explanation:

  • Option A: Incorrect. Plasmids are circular DNA molecules and can replicate bidirectionally or via rolling circle replication. They are not linear.
  • Option B: Correct. Plasmids are circular DNA and can replicate via different mechanisms, including rolling circle replication. Their copy number can vary from 1 to thousands per cell.
  • Option C: Incorrect. Plasmids can indeed carry antibiotic resistance genes and are involved in horizontal gene transfer.
  • Option D: Incorrect. Plasmids are independent of the bacterial chromosome and do not play a role in its replication or stability.

Key Takeaway:

  • Plasmids are independent, circular DNA molecules that replicate through various mechanisms and can carry genes for antibiotic resistance. Their number and replication style vary.
  • Rolling circle replication is fast and can produce multiple copies of DNA in a short time.

Tag Line: Moderate

Reference: Smith, J. (2024). Classification of microorganisms. In R. Brown & L. Green (Eds.), MIMS' Medical Microbiology and Immunology (6th ed., 2- CHAPTER, The bacteria, pp. 15).

questions.text: All of the following type of molecular class of breast cancer have high Ki-67 level except____
questions.solution:
Luminal A(ER+, PR+, Her2 -) type breast cancer has low Ki index(low risk of proliferation).

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery, 28th edition, chapter 58, page 931.

questions.text: A 54 year old man complained to his physician of an abnormal increase in the size of his breasts. The man had been suffering from systolic heart failure for 3 years. Two months earlier, the cardiologist had added a drug to the patient's therapeutic regimen. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's symptom?
questions.solution:
• The patient was suffering from gynecomastia, a well described adverse effect of spironolactone that is related to dose and duration of treatment.
  • Owing to its affinity for other steroid receptors, spironolactone can induce gynecomastia most likely by displacing androgens from androgen receptors. Generally, discontinuation of treatment results in resolution of gynecomastia.

Aldosterone antagonists

  • Spironolactone and eplerenone themselves lower BP slightly.
  • Used in conjunction with a thiazide diuretic they prevent K+ loss and augment the antihypertensive action.
  • Spironolactone has hormonal side effects (gynaecomastia, impotence, menstrual irregularities).

Adverse effects of Spironolactone

  • Drowsiness,
  • Ataxia,
  • Mental confusion,
  • Epigastric
  • Distress and loose motions.

Hormonal side effects

  • Gynaecomastia,
  • Erectile dysfunction or loss of libido in men
  • Breast tenderness or menstrual irregularities in women.

Most serious problem with spironolactone is risk of hyperkalaemia, especially if renal function is inadequate.

Uses:

Spironolactone & Eplerenone are a weak diuretic in its own right and is used mostly in combination with other more efficacious diuretics.

  1. To counteract K+ loss due to thiazide and loop diuretics.
  2. Edema:
    • Spironolactone & Eplerenone are more useful in cirrhotic and nephritic edema in which aldosterone levels are generally high.
    • It potentiates thiazides and loop diuretics and is frequently added to them in the treatment of ascitis due to cirrhosis of liver.
    • It breaks resistance to the thiazide/loop diuretic that develops due to secondary hyperaldosteronism and re-establishes the response.
    • Thus, spironolactone & Eplerenone are particularly employed in refractory edema.
  3. Hypertension:
    • Spironolactone & Eplerenone are used to augment a thiazide in the treatment of resistant hypertension
    • It also serves to prevent thiazide-induced hypokalaemia. Further, it has the potential to attenuate hypertension related renal fibrosis and ventricular/vascular hypertrophy.
  4. Heart failure:
    • As additional drug to conventional therapy in moderate to severe CHF; it serves to retard disease progression and lower mortality
  5. Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome).

Option A, C & D: The risk of gynecomastia with these drugs is negligible.

Key takeaway:

  • Because of its affinity for other steroid receptors, spironolactone can induce gynecomastia most likely by displacing androgens from androgen receptors

Tags:

[Must Know]

[Spironolactone]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 635

choices.text: Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides): Characterized by its large, cylindrical shape and smooth surface.
Hookworm (Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus): Identified by its hook-like anterior end and the presence of cutting plates or teeth.
Strongyloides (Strongyloides stercoralis): Known for its small size and the presence of rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity.
Whipworm (Trichuris trichiura): Recognizable by its thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end.

questions.text: The image below displays a microscopic view of a parasitic worm. Based on the visible features, which of the following correctly identifies the parasite shown?
questions.solution:
A) Incorrect: Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm) is large, cylindrical, and smooth, which does not match the hook-like appearance shown in the image.

B) Correct: Ancylostoma duodenale (Hookworm) features a hook-like anterior end and may have cutting plates or teeth. It has segmented eggs with blastomeres.

C) Incorrect: Strongyloides stercoralis (Strongyloides) is smaller and characterized by rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity, unlike the hook-like structure.

D) Incorrect: Trichuris trichiura (Whipworm) has a thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end and barrel shaped eggs with mucus plugs.

Key Takeaway: Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus (Hookworms) can be identified by their segmented appearance with blastomeres. This distinguishes them from other parasitic worms based on morphological features.

Tag Line: Hard

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Hookworm. CDC Hookworm

questions.text: Treatment of choice in recurrent epistaxis due to hereditary hemorrhagic telengiectasia is?
questions.solution:
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) is a rare genetic disorder that can cause frequent nosebleeds:

Symptoms

The most common symptom is frequent nosebleeds, which can start in childhood and sometimes occur daily. Other symptoms include:

  • Small red spots or lacy red vessels on the lips, face, fingertips, tongue, and inside of the mouth
  • Iron deficiency anemia
  • Shortness of breath
  • Headaches
  • Seizures

Causes

HHT occurs when blood vessels don't develop normally, resulting in abnormal blood vessels called telangiectases. These fragile vessels can bleed easily, especially when they form in the lining of the nose or gut.

Treatment

There's no cure for HHT, but treatments can help control bleeding and prevent complications. Treatments include:

  • Electrocautery to stop nasal tissues from bleeding
  • Iron supplementation to reverse anemia
  • Embolization
  • Surgery in form of septodermoplasty
  • Stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Prevalence

HHT affects males and females equally, and is estimated to occur in about 1 in 5,000 people. However, it's often underdiagnosed because some people with HHT have few obvious symptoms.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th ed, pg 209.

questions.text: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is associated with use of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is associated with use of gadolinium contrast in patients with advanced kidney disease.
  • It is mostly associated with use of group I gadolinium-based contrast media.
  • Should know facts about contrast induced Nephropathy:
  • The most common clinical course of contrast nephropathy is characterized by a rise in SCr beginning 24-48 h following exposure, peaking within 3-5 days, and resolving within 1 week.
  • Patients with multiple myeloma and/or renal disease are particularly susceptible. Low fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) and relatively benign urinary sediment without features of tubular necrosis (see below) are common finding.
  • The most Common cause of contrast Induced nephropathy is cytotoxic damage to tubules directly or via the generation of oxygen radicals, transient tubular obstruction and hypoxia of renal outer medulla
  • Vancomycin causes renal toxicity by Tubular injury and intratubular obstruction.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook, 21st Medicine, page no 2300

questions.text: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• TTP is characterized by the pentad of MAHA, thrombocytopenia, neuro-logic symptoms, fever, and renal failure.
  • TTP can be acquired or congenital Acquired TTP accounts for >90% cases. The pathophysiology of TTP involves the accumulation of ultra-large multimers of von Willebrand factor as a result of the absence or markedly decreased activity of the plasma protease ADAMTS13, a disintegrin and metalloproteinase with a thrombospondin type 1 motif, member 13.
  • TTP can be congenital from ADAMTS13 mutation (cTTP) or acquired from autoantibody against ADAMTS13 protein (iTTP).

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook, 21st Medicine, page no 2365

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 22 weeks of gestation with a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy presents for a routine ultrasound. The scan reveals that one twin has a bladder that is not visualized, polyhydramnios in the other twin, and abnormal Doppler findings. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The presentation suggests twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS). Laser photocoagulation is the definitive treatment for severe TTTS to ablate the placental anastomoses causing the condition.

This clinical scenario is consistent with twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), a complication of monochorionic twin pregnancies characterized by abnormal inter-twin vascular anastomoses leading to an imbalance in blood flow between the twins.

  • Key ultrasound findings suggestive of TTTS:
    • Bladder not visualized in one twin (the donor twin).
    • Polyhydramnios in the other twin (the recipient twin).
    • Abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent/reversed flow in the donor twin's umbilical artery or recipient twin's ductus venosus.
  • Management:
    • Laser photocoagulation of placental anastomoses is the treatment of choice for TTTS stages II-IV. It aims to interrupt the abnormal vascular connections and restore balanced blood flow.
    • Conservative monitoring (option A) is insufficient for stages beyond I as it does not address the underlying pathophysiology.
    • Amnioreduction (option D) may temporarily relieve symptoms of polyhydramnios but does not treat the underlying cause and is no longer the primary therapy for advanced TTTS.
    • Immediate delivery (option C) is not appropriate at 22 weeks, as it would lead to poor neonatal outcomes due to extreme prematurity.

Staging of TTTS (Quintero Classification):

  • Stage I: Polyhydramnios in the recipient twin and oligohydramnios in the donor twin, with a visible bladder in the donor twin.
  • Stage II: Bladder not visible in the donor twin.
  • Stage III: Abnormal Doppler findings in either twin.
  • Stage IV: Hydrops fetalis in one or both twins.
  • Stage V: Fetal demise of one or both twins.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Twin-to-Twin Transfusion syndrome

Reference: Aria's practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery, Chapter 12, Multiple Pregnancy, Page no. 175

choices.text: Serial ultrasounds for fetal growth and structural abnormalities
Routine follow-up with no further monitoring required

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G3P2, presents at 24 weeks of gestation for routine follow-up. An ultrasound reveals the presence of a single umbilical artery (SUA). The rest of the ultrasound is normal with no signs of fetal abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The presence of a single umbilical artery (SUA) is associated with an increased risk of fetal anomalies, particularly cardiovascular, renal, and chromosomal defects.

However, if the ultrasound reveals no other structural abnormalities and there is no indication of other complications, the appropriate management involves serial ultrasounds to monitor fetal growth and check for any potential structural issues or signs of fetal distress.

This is important because SUA can sometimes be associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), so monitoring the growth of the fetus is key.

Other Options:

  • a) Amniocentesis for karyotyping:
    • Amniocentesis is not routinely recommended solely based on the presence of SUA unless there are additional risk factors or signs of fetal abnormalities (such as abnormal screening results, structural anomalies, or family history of genetic disorders). Since this pregnancy has no signs of abnormal findings, amniocentesis is not immediately indicated.
  • c) Routine follow-up with no further monitoring required:
    • Although SUA can sometimes be an isolated finding with no adverse outcomes, this condition warrants some level of monitoring because it can be associated with fetal growth issues or anomalies that may not be initially apparent. Therefore, no further monitoring is not recommended.
  • d) Elective cesarean section at 38 weeks:
    • There is no indication for an elective cesarean section based on the presence of SUA alone, particularly when the rest of the pregnancy appears normal. Most women with SUA can have a vaginal delivery unless there are other complicating factors such as growth restriction or fetal distress.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Single Umbilical Artery

Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Obstetrics, Chapter 17, Multiple Pregnancy, Amniotic Fluid Disorders, Abnormalities of Placenta & Cord, Page no. 254

questions.text: A 25 year old male patient presented with complaint of trismus. Picture is given below. Trismus is not seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Trismus, or jaw locking, can have many causes, including:

Trauma: Facial trauma, jaw injury, or a blow to the face can cause trismus.

Infection: like Ludwig's angina, Quincy, and parapharyngeal abscess.

Surgery: Surgery to remove the jaw or jaw muscles, or to treat head and neck cancer, can cause trismus.

Radiation: Radiation therapy to treat head and neck cancer can cause trismus.

Tumors: Tumors that grow into the jaw muscles or jaw joint can cause trismus.

Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) issues: Issues with the TMJ, such as displacement of the joint cap or wear on the joint surfaces, can cause trismus.

Rheumatic diseases: Inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, and scleroderma can cause trismus.

Anesthesia: An intramuscular injection of anesthesia can cause trismus if it accidentally penetrates the masticatory muscles.

Tetanus: Tetanus is a disease caused by a toxin that produces trismus (lockjaw).

Other conditions: Trismus can also be caused by conditions like peritonsillar abscess, tetanus, seizure, stroke, traumatic brain injury, and stiff person syndrome.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th ed, pg 314.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complained to her physician of cold intolerance and menstrual irregularities over the past 3 weeks. The woman, recently diagnosed with Grave's disease, had started a treatment with methimazole 2 months earlier. The physician told the patient that her symptoms were most likely due to an excessive dose of methimazole. Which of the following effects could also occur as a result of an excessive dose of that drug?
questions.solution:
• Thioamide antithyroid drugs such as methimazole are currently used to treat hyperthyroidism, but excessive doses of these drugs can shift a hyperthyroid patient to a hypothyroid one, as in this case.
  • Constipation is a common symptom of hypothyroidism.
  • Thioamides include drugs like methimazole, carbimazole and propylthiouracil.
  • Agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia is serious side effect of all of these drugs but it is seen rarely. Lung fibrosis is not at all associated with use of the same drugs.
  • Propylthiouracil is associated with hepatotoxicity.
  • All the 3 drugs are teratogenic. Least teratogenic is propylthiouracil.

Adverse effects of Thioamides

Hypothyroidism and goiter

  • [Enlargement of thyroid is an indication of hypothyroidism and is due to excess feedback TSH production]
  • Gastrointestinal Intolerance
  • Skin rashes
  • Joint pain
  • Liver damage can occur [especially with propylthiouracil]
  • Loss or graying of hair
  • Loss of taste and fever [infrequent]

Option A, B & C: All of these are symptoms of hyperthyroidism and therefore unlikely after an excessive dose of methimazole.

Key takeaway

  • Thioamide antithyroid drugs such as methimazole are currently used to treat hyperthyroidism, but excessive doses of these drugs can shift a hyperthyroid patient to a hypothyroid one, as in this case.
  • Constipation is a common symptom of hypothyroidism.

Tags:

[Good to Know]

[Methimazole]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 274

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient having oral cavity tumor involving inferior alveolar nerve. What is the stage of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Involvement of inferior alveolar nerve makes it stage T4a

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery, 28th edition, chapter 53, page 816.

questions.text: Osteoporosis is defined as?
questions.solution:
• Osteoporosis is defined as decreased bone strength.
  • For quantification Dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) is used. In DEXA scan T-scores (a T-score of 1 equals 1 SD) compares individual results to those in a young adult population that is matched for race and sex. The mean value is given a score of zero and the range +2.5 to -2.5 (i.e., 2.5 SDs above or below the mean). Z-scores (also SDs) compare individual results to those of an age and gender-matched reference population. Thus, a 60-year-old woman with a Z-score of -1 (1 SD below mean for age) has a T-score of -2.5 (2.5 SD below mean for a young control group)
  • A T-score <-2.5 in the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or total hip has been defined as osteoporosis.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook, 21st Medicine, page no 3196

choices.text: Referral to an ENT specialist for a throat biopsy
Administration of oral corticosteroids for inflammation

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of sore throat, fever, and a grayish membrane observed on the back of the throat. The child has also been experiencing difficulty swallowing and breathing. The parents report that the child's immunizations are not up-to-date. Based on the clinical presentation and CDC guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Diphtheria is a potentially life-threatening bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, affecting the respiratory tract and sometimes the skin.

Pharyngeal or Tonsillar Diphtheria (Most Common Form):

Pseudomembrane:

  • Grayish-white or dirty-gray membrane forms on the tonsils, pharynx, or nasal passages.
  • Firmly adherent, and attempts to remove it may cause bleeding.
  • It can extend to the larynx, trachea, or bronchi, leading to airway obstruction.
  • Bull neck appearance: Severe cases may show lymphadenopathy and swelling of the neck due to regional inflammation.
  • Hoarseness and stridor: May develop as the disease progresses, indicating laryngeal involvement.
  • Dysphagia: Difficulty swallowing due to throat and neck swelling.

Cutaneous Diphtheria:

  • Chronic non-healing ulcers:
    • Infected wounds or skin lesions develop ulcers covered with a grayish membrane.
    • Most commonly seen in tropical regions or in people with poor hygiene.
  • Typically, less severe than respiratory diphtheria but still contagious.

Systemic Complications (Due to Toxin Spread):

Cardiac Complications:

  • Myocarditis: Can occur in the second or third week of illness.
    • Symptoms include arrhythmias, heart block, and heart failure.
    • Can lead to sudden death in severe cases.

Neurological Complications:

  • Cranial nerve palsies: Usually affects the soft palate, causing dysphonia (difficulty speaking) or dysphagia (difficulty swallowing).
  • Peripheral neuropathy: Occurs several weeks after the onset of diphtheria.
    • Involves motor weakness or paralysis starting in the lower extremities, progressing in a pattern similar to Guillain-Barre syndrome.

Treatment:

The antitoxin is administered intravenously or intramuscularly as soon as the disease is suspected, without waiting for laboratory confirmation.

  • Perform a skin test before administration to rule out hypersensitivity to the antitoxin.

Dose: Depends on the severity and duration of the disease, ranging from 20,000 to 100,000 units.

First-line antibiotics:

  • Erythromycin: 40-50 mg/kg/day (maximum 2 g/day) for 14 days, orally or intravenously.
  • Penicillin G: 250,000 to 500,000 units intramuscularly every 6 hours for 14 days (alternatively, penicillin V can be used orally).

Explanation:

A. Immediate initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics - Incorrect. While antibiotics such as penicillin or erythromycin are important for treating diphtheria, the immediate and critical step in the management of diphtheria, especially with the presentation of a grayish membrane, is the administration of diphtheria antitoxin to neutralize the toxin. Antibiotics are then used to eradicate the bacteria.

B. Immediate administration of diphtheria antitoxin - Correct. The administration of diphtheria antitoxin is essential to neutralize the diphtheria toxin and prevent severe complications. This should be done as soon as diphtheria is suspected, according to CDC guidelines. Antibiotic therapy should also be started concurrently.

C. Referral to an ENT specialist for a throat biopsy - Incorrect. While a throat biopsy might be necessary in some cases to confirm the diagnosis, the immediate management of suspected diphtheria should focus on the administration of diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics. Delays in treatment can lead to serious complications.

D. Administration of oral corticosteroids for inflammation - Incorrect. Corticosteroids are not indicated for the treatment of diphtheria. The primary treatment includes diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics to address the bacterial infection and neutralize the toxin.

Key Takeaway: The immediate administration of diphtheria antitoxin is crucial in the management of diphtheria to neutralize the diphtheria toxin. Antibiotic therapy should follow to treat the bacterial infection.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Diphtheria Treatment Guidelines. CDC Diphtheria Treatment

questions.text: Inhaling the cloth soaked in drug is:
questions.solution:
• Huffing refers to the act of inhaling volatile substances or drugs by saturating a cloth or other material and then inhaling the fumes.
  • Huffing is a form of inhalant abuse, and it can have harmful effects on the body, including intoxication and potential damage to the respiratory system.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Bagging: Bagging refers to a method of inhaling substances by placing them inside a bag and then inhaling or breathing in the vapors. The bag is typically held over the nose and mouth, allowing the person to inhale the substance contained within the bag.
  • Option B - Spraying: Spraying typically involves the dispersal of liquid substances in a fine mist or spray form.
  • Option D - Sniffing: Sniffing refers to the act of inhaling substances directly through the nose.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Huffing refers to the act of inhaling volatile substances or drugs by saturating a cloth or other material and then inhaling the fumes

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 608

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for malignancy screening in patients of longstanding inflammatory bowel disease?
questions.solution:
The IOC for malignancy screening in patients of IBD is colonoscopy.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook, 21st Medicine, page no 2422

choices.text: Referral to a specialist for biopsy

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presents with a single, painless ulcer on his genitalia that appeared about three weeks ago. The ulcer has a clean base and raised edges. He also reports swollen lymph nodes in the groin. The patient has no significant medical history and denies any recent sexual activity, although he admits to occasional unprotected sex. Based on the clinical presentation and the CDC guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Primary syphilis typically presents with:

  • A single, painless ulcer on genitalia
  • Clean base, raised edges
  • Swollen shotty lymph nodes
  • Spontaneously heals in 3-6 weeks.
  • Diagnosis-Dark-field microscopy, serological tests (RPR, VDRL, FTA-ABS)

A. Immediate initiation of oral azithromycin - Incorrect. While azithromycin is used in the treatment of syphilis, it is not the first-line treatment recommended by the CDC. Additionally, initiating treatment before confirming the diagnosis can lead to mismanagement and potentially complicate the diagnosis.

B. Serological testing for syphilis - Correct. The patient's presentation of a painless ulcer (chancre) and regional lymphadenopathy is suggestive of primary syphilis. According to CDC guidelines, the appropriate next step is to perform serological testing for syphilis to confirm the diagnosis. Testing includes non-treponemal tests (e.g., RPR or VDRL) followed by treponemal tests (e.g., FTA-ABS) for confirmation.

C. Immediate initiation of intravenous penicillin - Incorrect. Although intravenous penicillin is an effective treatment for syphilis, it is reserved for more advanced stages or neurosyphilis. Initial management should include confirmation of the diagnosis through appropriate serological tests.

D. Referral to a specialist for biopsy - Incorrect. A biopsy is not typically the first step in diagnosing syphilis. Diagnosis is usually made based on clinical presentation and serological tests rather than biopsy.

Key Takeaway: A hard chancre is a hallmark of primary syphilis, and early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent the disease's progression.

Serological testing for syphilis is essential to confirm the diagnosis before initiating treatment. The CDC guidelines recommend starting with diagnostic tests to confirm syphilis rather than starting treatment immediately.

Tag Line: Hard

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Syphilis Treatment Guidelines. CDC Syphilis Guidelines

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins. The father who believed that they did not belong to him requested DNA testing. After testing, it was found that one child did not belong to him. This case would be best described as?
questions.solution:
• Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, in the same cycle, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father.
  • This indicates that two separate acts of sexual intercourse with different partners occurred, leading to the fertilization of two different ova by two different spermatozoa. As a result, the twins have different genetic fathers, confirming the occurrence of superfecundation.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Superfetation: Superfetation refers to the occurrence of a second pregnancy during an ongoing pregnancy, where a woman conceives another fetus while already pregnant. This is not applicable in the given scenario as there is no indication of a second pregnancy occurring during an ongoing pregnancy.
  • Option C - Suppositious child: A suppositious child refers to a child who is falsely or fraudulently claimed or substituted as one's own. In the given scenario, there is no indication of false claims or substitution of the child, as the DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father. Therefore, suppositious child is not the appropriate term for this case.
  • Option D - Atavism: Atavism refers to the reappearance of a characteristic or trait in an organism that is not present in its immediate ancestors but was present in previous generations. It is not applicable in the given scenario, as the issue at hand is related to the genetic paternity of the twins, rather than the reappearance of ancestral traits.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, in the same cycle, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 396

choices.text: Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate

questions.text: Which amongst is the most accurate reasons which justifies that why is atropine mixed with diphenoxylate in combination medications?
questions.solution:
Diphenoxylate (2.5 mg) + atropine (0.025 mg)

  • Diphenoxylate is a synthetic opioid, chemically related to pethidine and used exclusively as constipating agent.
  • The anti-diarrhoeal action is most prominent, but because it is absorbed systemically and crosses blood-brain barrier-CNS effects do occur.
  • Atropine is added in subpharmacological dose to discourage abuse by taking several tablets.
  • Abuse liability is rated low, and overdose will produce disturbing atropinic side effects.
  • It has caused respiratory depression, paralytic ileus and toxic megacolon in children, because of which it is contraindicated below 6 years of age.
  • Loperamide has largely superseded it.

Key takeaway:

  • Diphenoxylate is a synthetic opioid, chemically related to pethidine and used exclusively as constipating agent. Atropine is added in sub pharmacological dose to discourage abuse by taking several tablets.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with AIDS presented to the clinic because of fever malaise, myalgias, nausea, and diarrhoea. Three weeks earlier, the patient had started a highly active antiretroviral therapy. He stated that the symptoms were most prominent several hours after each dose and that they seemed to be getting progressively worse with each dose. Physical examination disclosed maculopapular rash over his face, trunk, and arms. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• The patient was most likely suffering from a hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir.
  • This is a multiorgan systemic illness that occurs in up to 8% of HIV-infected patients who initiate therapy with abacavir.
  • Abacavir hypersensitivity reaction can cause life-threatening complications if abacavir is continued despite progressive symptoms.
  • In addition, among persons who have experienced the abacavir hypersensitivity reaction, subsequent rechallenge with abacavir following discontinuation can cause an immediate and potentially fatal reaction.
  • Abacavir increases the risk of myocardial infarction.
  • It may cause severe hypersensitivity reaction particularly in patients having HLA B*5701 allele. Testing of this allele should be done before starting abacavir.

Option A: These drugs very rarely cause hypersensitivity reactions.

Option B & C: These drugs are not active against HIV.

  • Key takeaway
  • Abacavir cause severe hypersensitivity reaction particularly in patients having HLA B*5701 allele. Testing of this allele should be done before starting abacavir.

[Good to Know]

[Abacavir]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 862-863

questions.text: A 66 year old woman suffering from osteoporosis and hypertension has been treated for the past year with raloxifene and calcium carbonate for osteoporosis and with hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. Despite the therapy, a recent bone mineral density test showed a significant decrease in bone mass. Which of the following would be an appropriate change in the treatment plan of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Bisphosphonates are first-line therapy for osteoporosis, and adding alendronate to the current regimen is a rational choice, as the ongoing therapy failed to prevent the decrease in bone mass.
    • Bisphosphonates should be atleast given for at least 5 years and it continue to afford protection for at least 5 years of continuous use.

Osteoporosis

  • The second and third generation BPNs (e.g. alendronate, ibandronate, risedronate) are effective in
  • Preventing and treating postmenopausal osteoporosis in women
  • Age related, idiopathic and steroid induced osteoporosis in both men and women.
  • Alendronate is equally or more effective than HRT or raloxifene in conserving bone mineral density
  • Bisphosphonates are more effective than calcitonin and continue to afford protection for at least 5 years of continuous use.
  • Thus, they are the first choice drugs now for osteoporosis.
  • Since the t½ of alendronate in bone is ~ 10 years, treatment beyond 5 years is considered unnecessary.

Option A: Selective estrogen receptor modulators are today preferred over estrogens for the therapy of osteoporosis because they do not increase the risk of breast and endometrial cancer.

Option B: Calcitonin is much less effective than bisphosphonates in the therapy of osteoporosis.

Option C: The dose of calcium taken by the patient is the standard for calcium supplementation in postmenopausal women. It is unlikely that a larger dose would add benefit.

Key takeaway:

  • Bisphosphonates are first-line therapy for osteoporosis, and adding alendronate to the current regimen is a rational choice, as the ongoing therapy failed to prevent the decrease in bone mass.
  • Bisphosphonates should be atleast given for at least 5 years and it continue to afford protection for at least 5 years of continuous use.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 370

questions.text: What is the primary function of Neutrophil Extracellular Traps (NETs)?
questions.solution:
Neutrophil Extracellular Traps (NETs) are web-like structures composed of DNA, histones, and antimicrobial proteins released by neutrophils during a process called NETosis. They are part of the immune system's defense mechanism against infections.

Key Points:

  1. Function: NETs trap and neutralize pathogens like bacteria, fungi, and viruses, preventing their spread.
  2. Components: Made of neutrophil DNA, histones, and granular proteins (e.g., elastase, myeloperoxidase) that have antimicrobial properties.
  3. Formation: NETosis occurs when neutrophils release their DNA in response to infections or inflammatory stimuli.
  4. Role in Disease: While beneficial in controlling infections, excessive NET formation can contribute to inflammation and tissue damage in conditions like autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus) and thrombosis.

Incorrect Options-

B. They play a crucial role in antimicrobial defense, particularly against bacteria, fungi, and parasites.

A. Phagocytosis is a process by which neutrophils internalize pathogens, but it's not the primary function of NETs.

C. Inflammation resolution is not directly related to NETs.

D. Cytokine production is a function of various immune cells, including neutrophils, but not the primary function of NETs.

Key takeaways: NETs play a dual role in immunity, defending against pathogens but also potentially causing harm in inflammatory diseases.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 83-84.

questions.text: Which of the following is an aseptate fungus?
questions.solution:
• Irregular, broad, nonseptate hyphae branching at wide angles.
  • Causes mucormycosis, mostly in patients with DKA and/or neutropenia (e.g. leukemia).
  • Inhalation of spores of fungi proliferate in blood vessel walls, penetrate cribriform plate, and enter brain. Rhinocerebral, frontal lobe abscess; cavernous sinus thrombosis. Headache, facial pain, black necrotic eschar on face; may have cranial nerve involvement.
  • Treatment: surgical debridement, amphotericin B or isavuconazole.

A) Aspergillus - Incorrect. Aspergillus is a septate fungus with narrow, septate hyphae.

B) Candida - Incorrect. Candida can form pseudohyphae and true hyphae but they are typically septate.

C) Nocardia - Incorrect. Nocardia is a bacterium, not a fungus, and does not have hyphae.

D) Rhizopus - Correct. Rhizopus is a fungus with broad, aseptate hyphae and belongs to the order Mucorales.

Key Takeaway: Rhizopus is distinguished by its broad, aseptate hyphae, making it the only aseptate fungus among the options provided.

Reference: Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander (Author). Chapter 26, Page 554.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl was treated topically with eye drops during a routine ophthalmoscopic examination. After 15 minutes, the ophthalmologist measured an increase in pupillary diameter with negligible changes in lens curvature and intraocular pressure. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered to the patient?
questions.solution:
• Phenylephrine is a selective α1 agonist frequently used to facilitate the examination of the retina.
  • The drug causes mydriasis by contracting the radial muscle of the iris, which receives only sympathetic innervation.
  • Because M3, α 2, andβ2 receptors are not activated, lens curvature and intraocular pressure are not affected.
  • Phenylephrine (5-10%) dilates the pupil, and is used to facilitate fundus examination, since cycloplegia is not required for this purpose.
  • Lower concentrations (0.1-0.2%) are utilized to decongest conjunctiva in allergic conjunctivitis.

Option B, C & D: Each of these drugs, given locally, would affect the intraocular pressure.

Key takeaway

  • Phenylephrine dilates the pupil, and is used to facilitate fundus examination, since cycloplegia is not required for this purpose.

[Good to Know]

[Phenylephrine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 151

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is primarily associated with Coxsackie virus infections?
questions.solution:
HFMD is most commonly caused by Coxsackievirus A16 and sometimes by Enterovirus 71 (EV71).

Mumps - Incorrect. Mumps is caused by the mumps virus, not Coxsackie virus.

TIPS AND TRICK - POMP

P-Parotitis

O-Orchitis

M-aseptic Meningitis

P-Pancreatitis

B) Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease - Correct. Coxsackie viruses, particularly Coxsackievirus A16, are known to cause Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD), which is characterized by sores in the mouth, and a rash on the hands and feet.

C) Scarlet Fever - Incorrect. Scarlet fever is caused by group A Streptococcus bacterium, not Coxsackie virus.

D) Measles - Incorrect. Measles is caused by the measles virus, not Coxsackie virus.

Key Takeaway: Coxsackie viruses are commonly associated with Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease. HFMD is generally mild and self-resolving, but its high contagiousness in young children emphasizes the need for good hygiene practices to control outbreaks.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease. CDC Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation presents with sudden, painless vision loss in his right eye. He reports that his vision was normal the day before, and there was no preceding trauma or symptoms. Fundus examination reveals a pale retina with a cherry red spot at the macula. Fluorescein angiography confirms delayed arterial filling. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
• Correct answer: A. Retinal artery embolism
    • CRAO is caused by the occlusion of the central retinal artery, most commonly due to an embolism from the carotid artery or heart, especially in patients with atrial fibrillation. The hallmark finding is a pale retina with a cherry red spot at the macula.
    • CRAO is an ophthalmic emergency due to sudden occlusion of the central retinal artery, often caused by an embolus or thrombus, leading to retinal ischemia.

Key points:

  1. Etiology:
    • Emboli from carotid artery plaques (most common).
    • Cardiac emboli (e.g., atrial fibrillation).
    • Giant cell arteritis (in older patients).
  2. Risk Factors:
    • Cardiovascular diseases (carotid artery stenosis, atrial fibrillation).
    • Hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia.
    • Smoking.
  3. Clinical Presentation:
    • Sudden, painless, monocular vision loss.
    • Often described as a "curtain coming down over the eye".
    • Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is often present.
  4. Fundoscopic Findings:
    • Pale retina due to retinal ischemia.
    • Cherry-red spot at the macula (due to preservation of the choroidal circulation).
  5. Initial Management (Time-sensitive):
    • Ocular massage to dislodge the embolus.
    • Anterior chamber paracentesis to lower intraocular pressure (IOP).
    • Hyperbaric oxygen or carbogen therapy to increase oxygenation (if available).
  6. Prognosis:
    • Poor visual prognosis if not treated within 90-100 minutes.
    • Irreversible retinal damage occurs due to prolonged ischemia.
  7. Long-term Management: Investigate and manage underlying cardiovascular risks (e.g., carotid artery disease, cardiac arrhythmias)

Incorrect options:

  • B. Hypertensive retinopathy: Leads to retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, but not a cherry red spot.
  • C. Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO): Presents with widespread hemorrhages ("blood and thunder" appearance).
  • D. Age-related macular degeneration: Results in gradual vision loss, not sudden.
  • E. Diabetic retinopathy: Causes microvascular changes, not arterial occlusion.

#CRAO #ocular emergency conditions #causes of CRAO #Cherry red spot

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Elsevier; 2015. p. 556-558.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with blurred vision, pain, and photophobia in his left eye two months after a traumatic injury to his right eye, which required surgical repair. The right eye was damaged by a penetrating object while working in a factory. Examination of the left eye shows granulomatous anterior uveitis, vitritis, and choroidal thickening. What is the best initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis that occurs after trauma or surgery to one eye, causing an autoimmune response in the fellow eye. The hallmark is bilateral uveitis with features like vitritis and choroidal thickening. The first-line treatment is systemic corticosteroids to suppress the immune-mediated inflammation.

Sympathetic ophthalmia (SO)

Etiology:

  • Precipitating event: Ocular trauma (penetrating injury) or intraocular surgery.
  • The inflammation typically appears weeks to months after the initial insult but can manifest as early as a few days or as late as several years.

Pathophysiology:

  • Autoimmune response: Traumatic or surgical injury exposes normally hidden ocular antigens, particularly from the uveal tract. These antigens are recognized as foreign by the immune system, leading to a bilateral autoimmune reaction.

Clinical Features:

  1. Bilateral panuveitis:
  2. Granulomatous anterior uveitis with mutton-fat keratic precipitates.
  3. Posterior segment involvement: Vitritis and Dalen-Fuchs nodules (small, yellow-white lesions at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium).

Diagnosis:

  1. Fundus findings: Serous retinal detachment, Dalen-Fuchs nodules.
  2. Imaging: Optical coherence tomography (OCT) or ultrasound can demonstrate choroidal thickening and detachment.

Treatment:

  1. Systemic corticosteroids:
    • First-line treatment to reduce inflammation. High doses are typically required initially (e.g., oral prednisone).
  2. Immunosuppressive agents:
    • Steroid-sparing agents like methotrexate, cyclosporine, or azathioprine are used for long-term control in chronic or refractory cases.
  3. Cycloplegics
    • Used to reduce pain and prevent posterior synechiae in cases with anterior uveitis.
  4. Enucleation:
    • If performed within 10-14 days of the trauma to the exciting eye, enucleation can prevent sympathetic ophthalmia. However, it is not effective once the disease has developed.

Incorrect options:

  • A. Topical corticosteroids: These are used for anterior uveitis but are insufficient for a panuveitis like sympathetic ophthalmia.
  • B. Intravitreal antibiotics: Indicated for endophthalmitis, not for an autoimmune uveitis.
  • D. Cycloplegics: Useful for pain relief in uveitis but do not treat the underlying inflammation.

#systemic ophthalmia #complication of ocular trauma

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Elsevier; 2015. p. 250-253.

questions.text: Which type of motility is characterized by Listeria monocytogenes?
questions.solution:
• Gram Positive, facultative intracellular rod; acquired by ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products and cold deli meats, transplacental transmission, and by vaginal transmission during birth.
  • Grows well at refrigeration temperatures ('cold enrichment'). Forms 'rocket tails' via actin polymerization that allow intracellular movement and cell to-cell spread across cell membranes, thereby avoiding antibody. Listeriolysin generates pores in phagosomes, allowing its escape into cytoplasm.
  • Shows Differential motility - Characteristic tumbling motility at 25° but no tumbling motility at 37°

A) Brownian motion Incorrect. Brownian motion refers to the random movement of particles suspended in a fluid, caused by collisions with molecules in the surrounding medium. It is not a type of active bacterial motility.

B) Corkscrew motility Incorrect. Corkscrew motility, or helical motility, is characteristic of spirochetes like Treponema pallidum(SPIROCHETS) and is not associated with tumbling motility.

C) Tumbling motility correct. Tumbling motility is a distinctive type of bacterial movement often seen in Listeria monocytogenes. This motility is characterized by a tumbling or spinning motion, where the bacteria appear to tumble or spin in place, particularly evident under the microscope.

D) Swarming motility Incorrect. Swarming motility involves the coordinated movement of bacterial cells across surfaces, often in a wave-like pattern, and is characteristic of bacteria like Proteus mirabilis, not Listeria monocytogenes.

Key Takeaway: Tumbling motility, which is observed in Listeria monocytogenes, is characterized by a distinctive tumbling or spinning motion of the bacteria. This type of motility is important for identifying and differentiating certain bacterial species.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Listeria monocytogenes

questions.text: Country is showing slow increase in population due to low birth and death rate but still birth rate is more than death rate. Demographic cycle is:

questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient presents with a diffusely thickened stomach wall and a "leather bottle" appearance on imaging.

Biopsy shows:
1. Diffuse infiltration of the stomach wall by signet ring cells
2. Marked desmoplasia and fibrosis
3. Poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Linitis plastica is a rare and aggressive form of stomach cancer (gastric adenocarcinoma) that involves the thickening and stiffening of the stomach wall, giving it a leather-like appearance. This condition leads to poor stomach motility and is often difficult to detect early due to its subtle symptoms

Linitis plastica is a type of diffuse-type adenocarcinoma characterized by a diffusely thickened stomach wall and signet ring cell infiltration.

Incorrect Options -

B. Intestinal-type adenocarcinoma typically shows glandular differentiation and is not diffusely infiltrative.

C. Diffuse-type adenocarcinoma is a broader category that includes linitis plastica, but does not specifically describe the "leather bottle" appearance

D. Mucinous adenocarcinoma is characterized by excessive mucin production, which is not a feature of linitis plastica.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Linitis plastica is a type of diffuse-type adenocarcinoma characterized by a diffusely thickened stomach wall and signet ring cell infiltration.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 775.

choices.text: Acute liver failure due to drug toxicity

questions.text:
A patient with hepatitis presents with:

1. High fever
2. Severe abdominal pain
3. Elevated bilirubin and INR
4. Liver biopsy shows massive hepatic necrosis

What is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Fulminant hepatitis B is characterized by high fever, severe abdominal pain, and massive hepatic necrosis.

It is a severe form of acute hepatitis B characterized by rapid liver failure and hepatic encephalopathy within 8 weeks of symptom onset in a previously healthy individual.

  • Caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV), which triggers a massive immune-mediated destruction of hepatocytes.
  • Clinical Presentation: Early: Nausea, vomiting, jaundice, and abdominal pain.
  • Rapid progression to hepatic encephalopathy, coagulopathy, and multi-organ failure.
  • Pathophysiology: Massive necrosis of hepatocytes due to the host immune response against infected liver cells. Cytokine storm and activation of innate and adaptive immune systems.
  • Diagnostic Features:
    • Elevated serum aminotransferases (AST/ALT).
    • Prolonged prothrombin time (PT) or INR >1.5.
    • Encephalopathy.
  • Serological tests: HBsAg, anti-HBc IgM, HBV DNA (often very high).

Incorrect Options-

A. Fulminant hepatitis A is rare and typically affects children.

C. Acute liver failure due to drug toxicity may show different histological features.

D. Septic shock with liver dysfunction typically shows different clinical and laboratory features.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Fulminant hepatitis B is characterized by high fever, severe abdominal pain, and massive hepatic necrosis.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 833.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive vision loss over the past few months. He reports a history of alcohol abuse and has recently been consuming large amounts of methanol. On examination, he has a central scotoma and a relative afferent pupillary defect in the right eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Correct answer: The patient's history of methanol ingestion and symptoms of progressive vision loss with a central scotoma point toward toxic optic neuropathy. Methanol is known to be toxic to the optic nerve, leading to characteristic vision changes.

Toxic optic neuropathy refers to optic nerve damage caused by toxic substances, leading to vision loss. Common toxins include:

  1. Chemical Agents:
    • Methanol:
    • Carbon Monoxide:
    • Heavy Metals:
    • Pharmaceuticals:
  2. Ethambutol
    • Chloroquine and Hydroxychloroquine:
    • Chemotherapeutic Agents:
    • Amiodarone:

Key Features:

  • Symptoms: Gradual vision loss, central scotomas, color vision changes, and sometimes relative afferent pupillary defects.
  • Diagnosis: Based on clinical history, examination findings, and exclusion of other causes of optic nerve dysfunction.
  • Management: Involves removal of the toxin, supportive care, and potential use of corticosteroids, although prognosis may vary depending on the extent of damage.
  • Incorrect options:
    • A. Nutritional optic neuropathy: Typically associated with vitamin deficiencies (e.g., B12) rather than toxic substances.
    • C. Papilledema: Usually presents with headaches and vision changes due to increased intracranial pressure, not specific toxic exposure.
    • D. Ischemic optic neuropathy: Generally results in sudden vision loss and is more common in older patients with vascular risk factors.

#Toxic optic neuropathy #optic disc pallor #neuroophthalmology

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Elsevier; 2015. p. 257-259.

questions.text: A young man presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation with sparing of touch and vibration in upper limb. Examination reveals loss of reflexes in upper limbs bilaterally while reflex in lower limb are normal. There is no involvement of bladder and bowel. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pointers for diagnosis:
    • Dissociated sensory loss with involvement of only upper limbs. Areflexia of upper limb with weakness indicates cervical cord involvement
    • In syringomyelia there is a developmental cavity in the cervical cord that when enlarges leads to compression of various tracts. Since fibers for pain and temperature run close to the central canal so they are compressed first resulting in loss of pain and temperature early.
    • C. Vitamin B12 deficiency: presents with subacute paresthesias in the hands and feet, loss of vibration and position sensation, and a progressive spastic and ataxic weakness.
    • A. In motor neuron disease there is no sensory loss. So it is ruled out.
    • D. Hypocupric Myelopathy presents similar to vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a painless lumps over scrotum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Epidermal Cysts

  • Cysts lined with stratified squamous epithelium
  • derived from hair follicles.
  • Clinical Features: Fixed to the skin with a central punctum.
  • Treatment:
    • Incision and drainage if infected
    • excision once inflammation subsides.
  • Meibomian cysts are epidermal cysts found on the free edge of the eyelid.
  • Trichilemmal (pilar/pilosebaceous) cysts are derived from the epidermis of the external root sheath of the hair follicle; 90% are found in the scalp and 70% are multiple. They are usually distinguished from epidermal cysts by pathologists, rather than clinically.

Option A) Lipoma is a soft, movable lump, usually without a central punctum.

Option B) Correct. Epidermal cysts are fixed to the skin and usually have a central punctum.

Option C) Meibomian cysts are epidermal cysts found on the free edge of the eyelid.

Option D) Abscess presents with fluctuation and signs of infection.

Key Points:

  • Epidermal cysts also called sebaceous cysts.Should be excised completely to prevent recurrence.

TAGS:

  • Difficulty Level: Must Know
  • Topic: Epidermal Cysts

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 45, Pages- 645

questions.text: A 4 year old child having pale blue iris, pale hair, blurring of vision identified with Deficiency of Tyrosine Metabolism. What is the probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Clinical History is suggestive of Albinism. Tyrosine metabolism, the first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme Tyrosinase. Tyrosinase again acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin.

Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Oculocutaneous Albinism is characterized by a reduction or complete lack of Melanin pigment in the skin hair and eyes. This leads to decreased visual activity, photophobia.

Option B) Tyrosinemia II is caused due to deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical Findings include keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia.

Option C) Alkaptonuria is caused by defect in Homogentisate oxidase. Presented with dark color urine with bluish black pigmentation in connective tissue.

Option D) Phenylketonuria is caused by deficiency of Phenylalanine hydroxylase required for conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Infants have low IQ and hypopigmentation.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Review SAE Chapter 25 page 408, 405-406

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male is concerned about his risk of developing coronary heart disease. What cholesterol/HDL ratio would you aim to achieve in this patient?
questions.solution:
A cholesterol/HDL ratio <3.5 is recommended for the prevention of coronary heart disease (CHD).

  • When we look at the various types of lipoproteins, it is the level of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol that is most directly associated with CHD.
  • While very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) has also been shown to be associated with premature atherosclerosis, it is more strongly associated with peripheral vascular disease (e. g., intermittent claudication) than with CHD.
  • High-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol is protective against the development of CHD - the higher its mean level in a group of individuals, the lower the incidence of infarction in that group). HDL should be more than 40 mg/dl.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- CHD risk prediction based on serum lipid levels, a total 'cholesterol/HDL ratio' has been developed. A ratio of less than 3.5 has been recommended as a clinical goal for CHD prevention

REFERENCE:- Park's Textbook of preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Chapter 6, Page No-419-425.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man was referred to a psychiatrist because of irritability, worrying thoughts, palpitations, dry mouth, and insomnia of 1-month duration. The man had a past history of alcohol abuse, but he was able to quit 1 year ago after psychological counselling and drug therapy. Recently, he suffered from erectile dysfunction, treated with sildenafil. A provisional diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder was made, and cognitive behavioural therapy with a drug treatment was prescribed. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Buspirone is considered a second-line agent for generalized anxiety disorders because of inconsistent reports of long term efficacy.
  • However, it can be the appropriate drug in patients who fail other anxiolytic therapies or in patients with a history of substance abuse, as in this case.
  • 5-HT1A (presynaptic receptor) modulates the release of serotonin. Partial agonists of this receptor (buspirone, ipsapirone, gepirone) are useful as anti-anxiety drugs

Azapirones

  • Buspirone, gepirone and ipsapirone act as partial agonists of presynaptic 5-HT1A receptors and decrease the release of serotonin.
  • These drugs do not cause sedation or cognitive impairment and are devoid of abuse potential, muscle relaxant and anticonvulsant activity.
  • Therapeutic effect of these drugs takes up to 2 weeks and therefore these are ineffective in acute anxiety states like panic attacks.
  • These are indicated for mild to moderate generalized anxiety states.

Buspirone

  • It is the first azapirone, a class of selective antianxiety drugs, distinctly different from BZDs. Buspirone:
  • Does not produce significant sedation or cognitive/functional impairment.
  • Does not interact with BZD receptor or modify GABAergic transmission.
  • Does not produce tolerance or dependence; no rebound anxiety or withdrawal symptoms on stoppage.
  • Does not suppress BZD or barbiturate withdrawal syndrome.
  • Has no muscle relaxant or anticonvulsant activity.
  • Buspirone relieves generalized anxiety of mild-to-moderate intensity, but is ineffective in severe cases and in those showing panic reaction.
  • The mechanism of anxiolytic action is not clearly known, but may be dependent on its selective partial agonistic action on 5-HT1A receptors.
  • By stimulating presynaptic 5-HT1A auto receptors, it reduces the activity of dorsal raphe serotonergic neurones.
  • Antagonistic action at certain postsynaptic 5-HT1A receptors has also been demonstrated.

Option A & C: Benzodiazepines can cause dependence and therefore are contraindicated in a person with a past history of substance abuse.

Option B: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are drugs of choice for anxiety disorders but are relatively contraindicated in this patient because of the recent episode of sexual dysfunction.

Key takeaway:

  • 5-HT1A (presynaptic receptor) modulates the release of serotonin. Partial agonists of this receptor (buspirone, ipsapirone, gepirone) are useful as anti anxiety drugs

[Good to Know]

[Buspirone]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 495

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition seen in below image.
questions.solution:
Option A ) : Paraphimosis is a condition where the retracted foreskin cannot be returned to its normal position over the glans penis, leading to painful swelling and restricted blood flow. If untreated, it can cause tissue damage or necrosis. Immediate treatment involves manual reduction, but in severe cases, surgical intervention (dorsal slit or circumcision) may be necessary to relieve the constriction and restore blood flow.

Option B) : Phimosis is a condition where the foreskin cannot be retracted over the glans penis, either due to tightness or scarring. It is common in children but can persist into adulthood. While often asymptomatic, it can cause discomfort, difficulty with hygiene, or infection (balanitis). Treatment ranges from topical corticosteroids to gently loosen the foreskin, to circumcision or preputioplasty in more severe cases.

Option C ) : Peyronie's disease is a condition where fibrous scar tissue develops inside the penis, causing curved, painful erections. It can result in erectile dysfunction and difficulty with intercourse. The exact cause is unclear, but it may be related to trauma or injury during sex. Treatment options include oral medications, injections to break down the scar tissue, or surgery for severe cases. Some men may experience improvement without treatment, while others may require medical intervention to restore function and reduce discomfort.

Option D ) : Penile fracture is a rare but serious injury caused by the rupture of the tunica albuginea, the fibrous covering of the penile erectile tissue, often due to trauma during vigorous intercourse or bending of the erect penis. It typically presents with a cracking sound, immediate pain, rapid swelling, and bruising. This is a urological emergency, and prompt surgical repair is the preferred treatment to prevent complications like erectile dysfunction or penile curvature.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 85 ; page 1549, 1550,1547

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from a rural area presents with redness, tearing, and irritation in both eyes. On examination, there is follicular conjunctivitis, limbal scarring (Herbert's pits), and tarsal conjunctival inflammation with pannus formation. The cornea shows signs of superficial neovascularization. What is the most appropriate long-term treatment strategy for preventing blindness in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Correct answer: C. Azithromycin and improved sanitation
    • The patient presents with features of trachoma, an infectious eye disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
    • The SAFE strategy (Surgery for trichiasis, Antibiotics, Facial cleanliness, Environmental improvement) is the cornerstone for long-term control of trachoma.
    • Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice for mass drug administration, and environmental improvements (such as better hygiene and sanitation) are critical for preventing reinfection and long-term complications.
  • Incorrect options:
    • A. Topical corticosteroids and cycloplegics: Steroids may be used in severe inflammation but are not the primary or long-term solution for trachoma.
    • B. Tetracycline ointment for 6 weeks: Effective but azithromycin is preferred due to better compliance with single-dose treatment.
    • D. Surgical correction of entropion: Indicated for late-stage trichiasis, but prevention with antibiotics and hygiene is key to avoiding this complication.

#trachoma #SAFE stratergy

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Elsevier; 2015. p. 136-139.

questions.text: Budding is seen with which fungus?
questions.solution:
CRYPTOCOCCUS-

  • 5-10 μm with narrow budding, PAS positive.
  • Found in soil, pigeon droppings.
  • Acquired through inhalation with hematogenous dissemination to meninges.
  • Highlighted with India ink and mucicarmine (red inner capsule).
  • Latex agglutination test detects polysaccharide capsular antigen and is more sensitive and specific.
  • Causes cryptococcosis, which can manifest with meningitis, pneumonia, and/or encephalitis ('soap bubble' lesions in brain), primarily in immunocompromised.
  • Treatment: amphotericin B + flucytosine followed by fluconazole for cryptococcal meningitis.

Soap bubble appearance in CNS Cryptococcosis

CANDIDA-

  • Dimorphic; forms pseudohyphae and budding yeasts at 20°C , germ tubes at 37°C .
  • Systemic or superficial fungal infection. Causes oral and esophageal thrush in immunocompromised (neonates, steroids, diabetes, AIDS), vulvovaginitis (diabetes, use of antibiotics), diaper rash, infective endocarditis (people who inject drugs), disseminated candidiasis (especially in neutropenic patients as host defense relies on phagocytes), chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.
  • Treatment: oral fluconazole/topical azoles for vaginal; nystatin, azoles, or, rarely, echinocandins for oral; fluconazole, echinocandins, or amphotericin B for esophageal or systemic disease.

A) Cryptococcus & Candida - Correct. Both Cryptococcus and Candida are fungi that reproduce by budding. Cryptococcus, a yeast, reproduces through budding (blastoconidia), while Candida, which is yeast-like, reproduces via budding and binary fission.

B) Candida & Rhizopus - Incorrect. While Candida reproduces by budding, Rhizopus is a Mold that reproduces primarily through the formation of sporangia and not budding.

C) Rhizopus & Mucor - Incorrect. Rhizopus and Mucor are both molds that reproduce by forming sporangia and are not characterized by budding.

D) Candida & Aspergillus - Incorrect. Candida reproduces by budding, but Aspergillus, a mold, reproduces through the formation of conidia and not budding.

Key Takeaway: Budding is a reproductive feature seen in Cryptococcus and Candida. Rhizopus, Mucor, and Aspergillus utilize different reproductive mechanisms.

Reference: Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander (Author). Chapter 20.

questions.text: Disease caused by virus of family of RNA paramyxovirus, with incubation period of 14-21 days with high secondary attack rate with most common complication of aseptic meningitis. Live attenuated vaccine is available for disease with strain Jeryl Lynn strain, the disease is?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is b. Mumps.

  • Mumps is caused by a virus from the RNA paramyxovirus family.
  • It has an incubation period of 14-21 days.
  • It has a high secondary attack rate, meaning it spreads easily from person to person.
  • The most common complication of mumps is aseptic meningitis.
  • A live attenuated vaccine is available for mumps, and the Jeryl Lynn strain is commonly used in mumps vaccines.

Measles, Rubella, and Chickenpox are caused by other viruses, and the specific details in the question (such as aseptic meningitis and Jeryl Lynn strain) point directly to mumps.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Mumps is a contagious viral infection caused by the mumps virus, characterized by swelling of the salivary glands, particularly the parotid glands, leading to puffy cheeks and jaw pain. It is usually self-limiting but can cause complications like orchitis, meningitis, or hearing loss, and is preventable through the MMR vaccine.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter- 05,Page no.: 172-178.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female presents with fever, weight loss, and decreased pulse in the left arm. Imaging studies reveal stenosis of the left subclavian artery. A biopsy of the affected artery shows:

1. Granulomatous inflammation with giant cells
2. Marked intimal thickening and fibrosis
3. Disruption of the elastic lamina

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with giant cells, intimal thickening, and fibrosis, leading to stenosis of large arteries.

A. Giant cell arteritis typically affects older adults and involves smaller arteries. Most commonly - Superficial temporal artery, presents with temporal headache, increased ESR and polymyalgia rheumatica.

C. Polyarteritis nodosa is characterized by necrotizing inflammation without giant cells.

D. Kawasaki disease is a childhood disease with distinct clinical features.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Takayasu arteritis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with giant cells, intimal thickening, and fibrosis, leading to stenosis of large arteries

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 512.
