questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents with a complaint of gradual loss of vision, specifically noting that he cannot see the right half of his visual field in both eyes. He reports that this change has been occurring over the past month and is accompanied by occasional headaches and difficulty navigating through crowded areas. There is no history of trauma, but he has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

Based on this clinical presentation, locate the neurological lesion responsible for the visual field defect.
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation is consistent with right homonymous hemianopia, which indicates that he has lost the right half of the visual field in both eyes. This specific pattern of vision loss occurs due to a lesion affecting the left optic tract.

Key Points:

  • Visual Pathway: The optic tracts carry visual information from the retina to the occipital lobe. Each optic tract contains fibers from the nasal retina of one eye and the temporal retina of the other eye.
  • Homonymous Hemianopia: This type of vision loss is characterized by a loss of the same visual field quadrant in both eyes, which occurs when the optic tract is damaged.
  • Other Options:
    • A. Right optic nerve: Lesion here would cause loss of vision in the right eye only (monocular vision loss).
    • C. Left occipital lobe: Damage to this area would result in contralateral visual field loss, but it typically causes a different pattern, such as a left homonymous hemianopia.
    • D. Optic chiasma: Lesions here would typically cause bitemporal hemianopia due to the crossing fibers.

#neurological fields #visual field loss #hemianopia #neuroophthalmology

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th ed. Elsevier; 2015. p. 101-105.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge, along with dysuria and dyspareunia. She also complains of vaginal pruritus. On examination, there is a frothy, yellow-green discharge with a characteristic odor. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for the 40-year-old woman presenting with frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge, dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal pruritus, along with a characteristic odor on examination, is Trichomoniasis.

  • Trichomoniasis (A) is caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. It presents with frothy, yellow-green discharge that is often malodorous and is typically associated with vaginal irritation, pruritus, dyspareunia, and dysuria. The discharge is usually described as frothy and may have a distinct fishy odor. These clinical signs are typical of trichomoniasis.

Why other options are less likely:

  • Candidiasis (B): Candidiasis usually presents with thick, white, curd-like discharge and is associated with itching and erythema of the vaginal mucosa. There is no significant froth or strong odor in candidiasis, and dysuria or dyspareunia are not common.
  • Chlamydia infection (C): Chlamydia often presents with mucopurulent or thin, watery discharge that may be odorless. It is commonly asymptomatic, but if symptoms occur, they typically involve dysuria and abnormal discharge. The frothy, yellow-green discharge with a distinct odor seen here is more characteristic of trichomoniasis.
  • Herpes simplex virus infection (D): Herpes simplex virus infection typically presents with painful ulcers or vesicles in the genital region, often accompanied by pain or burning. There is no characteristic frothy, yellow-green discharge or fishy odor associated with herpes.

Thus, the clinical presentation of frothy, yellow-green discharge, pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia with a distinct odor strongly points to Trichomoniasis.

Type: Must know

Topic: Vaginal discharge

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Chapter 3 Gynaecologic Infection, Page no. 61

questions.text: A young female presents with sudden onset partial vision loss of left eye. Additionally she also reports claudication in right upper limb. Examination shows right radial and brachial artery pulse to be absent. A carotid bruit is also audible. Rest of the cardiovascular examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis

  • Takayasu arteritis is an inflammatory and stenotic disease of medium- and large-sized arteries characterized by a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its branches.
  • It is most prevalent in adolescent girls and young women. Although it is more common in Asia, it is neither racially nor geographically restricted.
  • The disease involves medium- and large-sized arteries, with a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its branches; the pulmonary artery may also be involved. The involvement of the major branches of the aorta is much more marked at their origin than distally. Narrowing of the lumen occurs with or without thrombosis. demonstrated, but their pathogenic significance is unclear.
  •  CLINICAL AND LABORATORY MANIFESTATIONS Takayasu arteritis is a systemic disease with generalized as well as vascular symptoms. The generalized symptoms include malaise, fever, night sweats, arthralgias, anorexia, and weight loss, which may occur months before vessel involvement is apparent. These symptoms may merge into those related to vascular compromise and organ ischemia. Pulses are commonly absent in the involved vessels, particularly the subclavian artery. Hypertension occurs in 32-93% of patients and contributes to renal, cardiac, and cerebral injury.
  • Vision loss is most common ocular manifestation in Takayasu arteritis and sudden onset vision loss can be due to embolization in retinal artery.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2770

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding Fixed Dose Combination of drugs?
questions.solution:
• Fixed dose combination (FDC) refers to a combination of two or more therapeutically active entities in a fixed ratio of doses.
  • The term is used generically to mean a particular combination of drugs irrespective of the formulation or brand.

Criteria for choosing FDCs

  • The FDCs must be based on convincing therapeutic rationalization and be carefully justified and clinically relevant.
  • FDCs must be shown to be safe and effective for the claimed indications and it cannot be assumed that benefits of the FDC outweigh its risks.
  • As for any new medicine, the risks and benefits must be defined and compared. Specifically, attention should be drawn to the doses of each active substance in the FDC.

Advantages of using FDC

  • Increased compliance
  • Reduced incidence of adverse effects as side effects of one may be counteracted by the other; example loop diuretic with a potassium sparing diuretic
  • Increased efficacy as some drugs act synergisticallyg. levodopa + carbidopa/ benserazide
  • May help to lower the cost of therapy as well
  • Reduced development of resistance in case of antibiotics. This is particularly relevant for the treatment of TB, HIV

Disadvantages of using FDC

  • Either the doses of the components, and/or the ratio of doses may differ from patient to patient (inter-patient variability)
  • The patients may be taking different doses at different stages of treatment (as in initial treatment compared with long-term treatment; intra-patient variability)
  • Difficult of establishing causality of a newly reported adverse drug reaction.
  • Presence of allergic reaction to any component of the FDC precludes its use as a whole.
  • There is a higher incidence or greater severity of adverse reactions to the combination than with any of the ingredients given alone,
  • There are unfavorable pharmacokinetic interactions between the ingredients, for example when one drug alters the absorption, distribution, metabolism or excretion of another.
  • Dose adjustment is required necessarily in special populations, such as in people with renal or hepatic impairment, or the elderly.

Key takeaway

  • The FDCs must be based on convincing therapeutic rationalization and be carefully justified and clinically relevant.
  • FDCs must be shown to be safe and effective for the claimed indications and it cannot be assumed that benefits of the FDC outweigh its risks.

[Good to Know]

[Fixed Dose Combination]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 72

questions.text: A 2 month Old baby girl presented with cataract, not being able to track object. Her urine is positive for Benedict's test but dipstick test is negative. Rest all examination is normal. Which enzyme is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
As per given case scenario, baby girl is suffering from Galactokinase deficiency. The child is having cataract due to accumulation of Galactitol.

The baby presents with isolated cataracts and a positive Benedict's test, indicating the presence of a reducing sugar (galactose) in the urine. However, the absence of systemic symptoms such as developmental delay or hepatomegaly suggests a milder disorder compared to classic galactosemia.

Galactokinase deficiency leads to the accumulation of galactose in the blood and tissues.

Some of the excess galactose is converted to galactitol, which accumulates in the lens and causes cataracts.This condition does not lead to the toxic accumulation of galactose 1-phosphate, as seen in GALT deficiency, and thus systemic symptoms (e.g., liver dysfunction, developmental delay) are absent.

Option A) Galactose 1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT):Deficiency causes classic galactosemia, a severe disorder with cataracts, developmental delay, hepatomegaly, and vomiting after milk intake. The absence of systemic findings makes this less likely.

Option C) Fructokinase: Deficiency causes essential fructosuria, which involves the accumulation of fructose and does not cause cataracts or involve galactose metabolism.

Option D) Aldolase B: Deficiency causes hereditary fructose intolerance, presenting after fructose ingestion with symptoms such as hypoglycemia, vomiting, and liver dysfunction. It is unrelated to galactose metabolism or cataracts.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Review SAE Chapter 17 page 243- 244

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en-masse to remove organs from tongue to prostate is:
questions.solution:
• Letulle technique is named after Maurice Letulle, which involves the removal of organs together in one mass from tongue to prostate.
    • This method of autopsy is thus also called "en masse."
    • The anatomy of the organs and organ systems can be preserved in the greatest possible way due to this.
    • Forensic pathologists can get a better overall picture due to the preservation of anatomical linkages.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Virchow technique: This approach is named after Rudolf Virchow. Instead of removing all organs at once, this method involves the sequential removal and examination of individual organs. The Virchow technique does not fit the description in the question because it does not involve the "en masse" removal of organs.
  • Option B - Rokitansky technique: In situ dissection (inside the body itself) is done in the Rokitansky technique.
  • Option C - Ghon's technique: Anatomical relationships are maintained by using the Ghon's approach, often known as "en bloc." Instead of one enormous block, the thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed using this procedure in three separate blocks. The dissection is made much more manageable by dividing the huge block into these three portions while still keeping the anatomy between the organs.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Letulle technique is named after Maurice Letulle, which involves the removal of organs together in one mass from tongue to prostate.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 121

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and ascites. Doppler ultrasound shows absent flow in the hepatic veins. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Budd-Chiari Syndrome

  • Impaired hepatic venous outflow from hepatic veins to IVC.
  • Key Features: Triad of abdominal pain, ascites, hepatomegaly.
  • Common in young women with hypercoagulable conditions.
  • Complications:
    • Liver congestion
    • portal hypertension
    • ascites, varices
    • cirrhosis
    • liver failure.
  • Diagnosis: Doppler ultrasonography, CT scan, and hematological studies.
    • CT scan demonstrates a large, congested liver or cirrhosis with gross enlargement of the caudate lobe resulting from preservation and hypertrophy of the segment due to direct venous drainage to the IVC.
  • Treatment:
    • Liver transplantation for fulminant failure or cirrhosis;
    • TIPSS, portocaval shunt, or IVC stenting if liver function is normal.
    • Lifelong anticoagulation is often required.

Explanation:

Option A. Portal vein thrombosis: Incorrect. Portal vein thrombosis can cause portal hypertension and ascites, but it does not involve the hepatic veins, which are occluded in Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Option B. Budd-Chiari syndrome: Correct. Budd-Chiari syndrome is caused by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow, leading to hepatomegaly, ascites, and abdominal pain. Doppler ultrasound typically shows absent or reduced flow in the hepatic veins.

Option C. Cirrhosis: Incorrect. Cirrhosis presents with similar symptoms but usually shows diffuse liver fibrosis rather than specific venous obstruction.

Option D. Hepatic artery aneurysm: Incorrect. A hepatic artery aneurysm typically presents with a different clinical picture, such as upper abdominal pain or rupture, and does not cause hepatic venous obstruction.

Key Points:

  • Triad of abdominal pain, ascites, hepatomegaly with gross enlargement of the caudate lobe- Budd Chiari syndrome

Tags:

Topic: Budd-Chiari Syndrome

Difficulty Level: Must Know

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 69, page no- 1208.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with numerous small, red, scaly papules scattered across the trunk and extremities. The patient reports a recent episode of streptococcal pharyngitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Guttate psoriasis is characterized by:

  • Small, red, scaly papules that appear suddenly and are often distributed across the trunk and extremities.
  • It is frequently triggered by a recent upper respiratory infection, particularly streptococcal pharyngitis.

Option B: Pityriasis rosea typically begins with a single "herald" patch followed by a generalized rash with a Christmas tree pattern, rather than scattered small papules.

Option C: Tinea corporis (ringworm) presents with annular lesions with a central clearing and a raised, scaly border, not with diffuse small papules.

Option D :Erythema multiforme usually presents with target lesions and is often associated with infections or drug reactions, not typically with the scattered papular rash seen in guttate psoriasis.

Key takeaway:

Guttate psoriasis

  • Small, red, scaly papules that appear suddenly and are often distributed across the trunk and extremities.
  • It is frequently triggered by a recent upper respiratory infection, particularly streptococcal pharyngitis.

Tag:

Guttate psoriasis

Must know

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, pg no 35.16

questions.text: Which of the following is a common mode of HIV transmission?
questions.solution:
The most common mode of HIV Transmission - Sexual contact

Most Efficient mode of HIV Transmission - Blood transfusion

A) Casual contact - Incorrect. HIV is not transmitted through casual contact.

B) Respiratory droplets - Incorrect. HIV is not spread through respiratory droplets.

C) Unprotected sexual contact - Correct. HIV is commonly transmitted through unprotected sexual contact with an infected person.

D) Sharing food and utensils - Incorrect. HIV is not transmitted through sharing food or utensils.

Key Takeaway: Unprotected sexual contact is a primary route of HIV transmission.

Tag Line: Easy

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). HIV Transmission. CDC HIV Transmission

questions.text: Saturnine gout is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Saturnine gout refers to gout-like symptoms caused by chronic lead poisoning.
  • Lead exposure can interfere with the kidneys' ability to excrete uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia (elevated levels of uric acid in the blood).
  • This can result in the deposition of urate crystals in the joints, causing gout-like symptoms.
  • This condition was historically seen in people exposed to lead, such as those who drank wine sweetened with lead or worked in industries with high lead exposure.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Cadmium poisoning: Cadmium poisoning primarily affects the kidneys and can cause kidney damage, but it is not specifically associated with Saturnine gout.
  • Option C - Beryllium poisoning: Beryllium poisoning is associated with lung disease (berylliosis) and is not directly linked to Saturnine gout.
  • Option D - Mercury poisoning: Mercury poisoning primarily affects the nervous system and can lead to symptoms such as tremors, cognitive impairments, and sensory disturbances. It is not specifically associated with Saturnine gout.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Lead exposure can interfere with the kidneys' ability to excrete uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia (elevated levels of uric acid in the blood).

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no546

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with Hypercalcemia, Elevated calcitonin levels, Thyroid nodule on ultrasound.

Histopathological examination of the thyroid nodule reveals:
1. Increased number of parafollicular cells (C-cells)
2. Formation of nodular aggregates
3. Amyloid deposition

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
C. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a malignant tumor originating from parafollicular cells (C-cells).

Elevated calcitonin levels and amyloid deposition are characteristic features.

A. Hashimoto thyroiditis typically shows lymphocytic infiltration and no nodular aggregates of C-cells.

B. Follicular thyroid adenoma typically shows follicular architecture and no amyloid deposition.

C. Papillary thyroid carcinoma typically shows papillary architecture and nuclear features.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a malignant tumor originating from parafollicular cells (C-cells).

Elevated calcitonin levels and amyloid deposition are characteristic features.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1091.

questions.text: A 45 year old woman was undergoing surgery to remove an extensive lipoma in her right arm. Her medical history was significant for long-term, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to heavy smoking. Local anesthesia with a peripheral nerve block was planned. Which of the following local anesthetics would be contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Most local anesthetics can block Na+ channels in cardiac muscle, thereby depressing automaticity and conduction.
  • At very high doses they can also depress contractility, most likely by blocking Ca2+ channels.
  • Bupivacaine is more cardiotoxic than most other local anesthetics, apparently because the drug dissociates much more slowly than other local anesthetics during diastole, so a significant fraction of Na+ channels at physiological heart rates remains blocked with bupivacaine at the end of the diastole.
  • Bupivacaine-induced cardiac toxicity is very difficult to treat and is enhanced by coexisting acidosis and hypoxemia, which are most likely in this case because of COPD.

Bupivacaine is most cardiotoxic local anaesthetic.

  • At toxic doses, local anaesthetics can result in CNS (convulsions) or CVS (hypotension, bradycardia, arrhythmias) symptoms.
  • Diazepam is used to treat convulsions.
  • Arrhythmias should be promptly treated using bretylium, amiodarone, disopyramide, magnesium sulphate, esmolol or sotalol.
  • Lignocaine should be avoided as anti-arrhythmic because it can exacerbate the CNS toxicity.
  • In refractory arrhythmias, intravenous lipid emulsion (like intralipid) has been found to be extremly useful.

Key takeaway

  • Bupivacaine-induced cardiac toxicity is very difficult to treat and is enhanced by coexisting acidosis and hypoxemia

[Must Know]

[Bupivacaine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 390

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, altered sensorium. The poisoning is?
questions.solution:
• Datura is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties. It can cause symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity, which include dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and altered sensorium. This is consistent with the clinical presentation described.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Morphine:
    Morphine is an opioid and typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), not mydriasis. It can lead to respiratory depression and altered sensorium, but the dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic of morphine poisoning.
  • Option B - Cannabis:
    Cannabis can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech but is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Cannabis effects are typically less severe and do not match the full clinical picture described.
  • Option D - Alcohol:
    Alcohol can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech, but it is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Alcohol typically causes miosis and does not have the anticholinergic effects seen with Datura.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic symptoms, including dry skin, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and altered sensorium.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 598

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath. Physical examination reveals pallor, jaundice, and glossitis.

Laboratory tests show:
1. Hemoglobin (Hb): 7 g/dL
2. Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 120 fL
3. Red blood cell count (RBC): 2 million/μL
4. White blood cell count (WBC): 3,000/μL
5. Platelet count: 50,000/μL
6. Serum vitamin B12: 50 pg/mL (normal: 200-900 pg/mL)

Peripheral smear findings: Macro ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophil.

What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
MCV > 100 fL, Low serum vitamin B12 suggests Megaloblastic anemia.

Peripheral smear shows megaloblastic changes confirms the diagnosis of Megaloblastic anemia.

On PBS:

  1. RBC- Macro-ovalocyte
  • Howell Jolly bodies -Made of DNA remnants
  • Cabot ring-mitotic spindles
  1. WBC changes-Hyper segmented neutrophils

Incorrect Options-

A. Iron deficiency anemia has low mcv.

C. No evidence of myeloproliferative disorder, it shows increase in a particular lineage of cells

D. Sickle cell anemia shows sickle shaped RBCs.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Peripheral smear findings: Macro ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils with increased MCV points towards megaloblastic anemia.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 651.

choices.text: Ryanodine receptor channel in cardiac muscle

questions.text: Which among the following is an example of ligand gated channel?
questions.solution:
• Option b: The ryanodine receptor (RyR2 in cardiac muscle) is a calcium-activated calcium release channel in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. While it is activated by calcium, it is an example of ligand gated ( Ca++ as ligand) channel.
  • Option a: This is a voltage-gated calcium channel found in the T-tubules of muscle cells. It responds to changes in membrane potential and is involved in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal and cardiac muscles, not ligand binding.
  • Option c: This is a voltage-gated sodium channel that opens in response to depolarization of the membrane. It is crucial for initiating and propagating action potentials but does not involve ligand binding.
  • Option d: The sodium channels in Pacinian corpuscles are mechanosensitive channels, which respond to mechanical deformation caused by pressure or vibration. These are not ligand-gated channels as they are not activated by chemical messengers.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.219

questions.text: Which of the following trematodes is commonly associated with liver disease and is transmitted through the consumption of undercooked fish?
questions.solution:
Clonorchis sinensis is known to cause biliary tree infection and transmitted through the consumption of undercooked fish.

  • Clonorchis sinensis also known as Chinese liver fluke.
  • Definitive host - Man
  • 1st intermediate host -Snail
  • 2nd Intermediate host - Clonor fish
  • Infective form -Metacercaria larva
  • Treatment -Praziquantel

A) Schistosoma mansoni - Incorrect. This trematode causes schistosomiasis and is primarily transmitted through contact with contaminated freshwater, not through undercooked fish.

B) Fasciola hepatica - Incorrect. This trematode is known as the liver fluke and is associated with liver disease, but it is transmitted through contaminated water plants, not fish.

C) Clonorchis sinensis - Correct. Commonly known as the Chinese liver fluke, it is transmitted through the consumption of undercooked or raw freshwater fish and is associated with liver disease.

D) Paragonimus westermani - Incorrect. This trematode causes lung fluke infection and is transmitted through the consumption of undercooked crustaceans, not fish.

Key Takeaway: Clonorchis sinensis is a trematode transmitted through undercooked fish and is associated with liver disease.

Tag Line: Moderate

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Clonorchiasis. CDC Clonorchiasis

questions.text: A 26 years old female presents with recurrent episodes of severe unilateral headache that increases with movement and is associated with nausea and occasional vomiting. each episode lasts for 12-24 hours and requires use of NSAID. what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pointers for diagnosis:

  • Young female with unilateral headache that increases with movement and improves with NSAID. Diagnostic criteria for
  • AT LEAST 2 OF THE FOLLOWING FEATURES:
  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity
  • The Diagnostic criteria for Migraine
  • PLUS AT LEAST 1 OF THE FOLLOWING FEATURES:
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

Remember that cluster headache is more common in males and episodes are severe with each episode lasting for 15-180 Mins. In our case the headache is lasting for 12-24 hours. Therefore, Migraine is most likely diagnosis.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 3361

questions.text: A 48 year old male patient with history of uncontrolled hypertension was brought to emergency department with complaints of acute chest pain. ECG of the patient confirms it to be non ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). Which of the following drug useful in this patient which acts by inhibiting platelet aggregation?
questions.solution:
• Clopidogrel
    • This is a more potent congener of ticlopidine acts by irreversibly blocking the P2Y12 type of purinergic receptor on the surface of platelets.
    • This Gi-coupled GPCR mediates ADP-induced platelet aggregation by inhibiting adenylyl cyclase and decreasing cAMP.
    • Clopidogrel is also a prodrug.
    • It is a slow acting drug; antiplatelet action takes about 4 hours to start and develops over days.
    • Since CYP2C19, exhibits genetic polymorphism, the activation of clopidogrel and consequentlyits antiplatelet action shows high interindividual variability.
    • Combination of clopidogrel and aspirin is synergistic in preventing ischaemic episodes.
    • This 'dual antiplatelet therapy' (DAPT) is also utilized for checking restenosis of stented coronaries.
    • Neutropenia is rare with clopidogrel.
    • The most important adverse effect is bleeding.
    • Other side effects are diarrhoea, epigastric pain and rashes.

Option B: Fibrinolytics are the drugs which activate plasminogen to form plasmin and thus help in lysis of thrombus

Option C: Low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin, dalteparin, tinzaparin, ardeparin, nadroparin and raviparin) mainly inhibit factor Xa

Option D: Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant and acts by inhibiting the activation of vitamin K dependent clotting factors.

  • Key takeaway
  • Clopidogrel is a more potent congener of ticlopidine acts by irreversibly blocking the P2Y12 type of purinergic receptor on the surface of platelets.

[Good to Know]

[Clopidogrel]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 678

questions.text: What is the characteristic pattern observed in given portion B (RED ARROW) of electrophoresis image?
questions.solution:
Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death that occurs in a controlled and regulated manner to remove damaged, unnecessary, or harmful cells without causing inflammation.

Key Features:

  1. Cell Shrinkage: Cells shrink and condense.
  2. DNA Fragmentation: The cell's DNA is broken down.
  3. Formation of Apoptotic Bodies: The cell breaks into small, membrane-bound fragments.
  4. Phagocytosis: Apoptotic bodies are engulfed and removed by neighboring cells or immune cells.

Explanation: Shown picture is of DNA FRAGMENTATION on agar gel electrophoresis.

Portion A: Normal cells

Portion B: Step ladder pattern

Portion C: Smear pattern

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Apoptosis is characterized by a ladder-like pattern of DNA fragmentation due to cleavage by caspases and endonucleases.

Smear-like pattern can occur in both necrosis and apoptosis, but is less specific.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 37.

questions.text: A diagnosed case of multiple myeloma is started on Dexamethasone. 5 days after starting therapy he develops decreased urine output. Evaluation shows hyperkalemia, Hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia and hyperuricemia and raised serum urea and creatinine. The ratio of urinary uric acid to urinary creatinine is >1. Serum Creatine phosphokinase is 150 U/L (normal <130 U/L). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute renal failure post chemotherapy with hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia and hyperuricemia indicates tumor lysis. The ratio of urinary uric acid to urinary creatinine is >1 in patients with acute hyperuricemic nephropathy and <1 in patients with renal failure due to other causes.

Serum creatine kinase and uric acid levels are often elevated in rhabdomyolysis, while tumor lysis syndrome can be associated with normal or marginally elevated creatine kinase and markedly elevated serum uric acid.

Must Know facts about TSS:

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is characterized by hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia and is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. Acute renal failure occurs frequently.
  • TLS is most often associated with the treatment of Burkitt's lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.
  • TLS usually occurs during or shortly (1-5 days) after chemotherapy. The finding of uric acid crystals in the urine is strong evidence for uric acid nephropathy. The ratio of urinary uric acid to urinary creatinine is >1 in patients with acute hyperuricemic nephropathy and <1 in patients with renal failure due to other causes. Other events may lead to renal failure in TLS.
  • Calcium phosphate also precipitates in the interstitium and renal microvasculature, leading to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Hyperkalemia in patients with renal failure may rapidly become life threatening by causing ventricular arrhythmias and sudden death.
  • The likelihood that TLS will occur in patients with Burkitt's lymphoma is related to the tumor burden and renal function. Hyperuricemia and high serum levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH >1500 U/L), both of which correlate with total tumor burden, also correlate with the risk of TLS.
  • The standard preventive approach consists of allopurinol and aggressive hydration. Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate is no longer recommended. Febuxostat, a potent nonpurine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is indicated for treatment of hyperuricemia.
  • Rasburicase (recombinant urate oxidase) can be effective in these instances, particularly when renal failure is present. Rasburicase should also be administered to high-risk patients for TLS prophylaxis.

Despite aggressive prophylaxis, TLS and/or oliguric or anuric renal failure may occur. Renal replacement therapy is often necessary and should be considered early in the course. Hemodialysis is preferred. Hemofiltration offers a gradual, continuous method of removing cellular by-products and fluid.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 573

questions.text:
A newborn presents with a keyhole-shaped defect in the inferior portion of the iris in both eyes. The mother's prenatal history is unremarkable, and there were no reported complications during delivery. This congenital defect is attributed to improper closure of the choroid fissure during development.

Which of the following structures is least likely to be affected by the same developmental process?
questions.solution:
• Option D). Cornea: Correct. The cornea develops from surface ectoderm and neural crest cells, independent of the choroid fissure. Therefore, it is not affected by incomplete closure of the fissure.
  • Option A). Retina: Incorrect. The retina develops from the optic cup, which forms from the neural ectoderm. Incomplete closure of the choroid fissure can result in a retinal coloboma, affecting its inferior portion.
  • Option B). Optic nerve: Incorrect. The optic nerve forms from the optic stalk, which is continuous with the developing retina. A defect in the choroid fissure can affect the optic nerve, leading to optic nerve coloboma.
  • Option C). Choroid: Incorrect. The choroid develops from neural crest cells that surround the developing optic cup. Anomalies in choroid fissure closure can lead to a choroidal coloboma.

Embryological derivatives of eye

Choroid Fissure Closure and Coloboma:

  • The choroid fissure forms along the ventral aspect of the optic stalk during early eye development. It allows entry of the hyaloid artery to nourish the developing eye. Normally, the choroid fissure closes by the 7th week of gestation.
  • Incomplete closure of the choroid fissure results in a coloboma, a congenital defect that can involve the iris, retina, optic nerve, and choroid, often presenting as a keyhole-shaped defect in the affected structures.
  • The cornea is not involved in this process since it develops separately from the surface ectoderm and neural crest cells.

KEY TAKE AWAYS:

Incomplete closure of the choroid fissure results in a coloboma, a congenital defect that can involve the iris, retina, optic nerve, and choroid, often presenting as a keyhole-shaped defect in the affected structures.

#choroidal fissure closure #coloboma #fundal Coloboma #must know

Reference:

Kanski, Jack J., and Bowling, Brad. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier, 2016, Chapter 1, pp. 1-8

questions.text: Sagar was being tried in a court for the murder of Mohan in the park. Shikhar appeared in court and said he saw Sagar carrying a knife in his hand while in the park. What is this evidence known as?
questions.solution:
Indirect evidence is also known as circumstantial evidence. It is not the direct testimony of an eyewitness. It has an effect on other facts and subsidiary facts which are depended upon as consistent.

Other options:

  • Option A - Direct evidence is the evidence of a fact that is actually in issue. E.g.: The witness saw A shooting B, prescription, consent form.
  • Option C - Hostile evidence is given by someone who is supposed to have some interest or motive for hiding part of the truth. He might give completely false evidence too.
  • Option D - Hearsay evidence is given by someone about something that he did not personally witness. Sometimes it might be obtained from a third party. It is presented in the court to claim that the facts contained in the statement are true.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Indirect evidence is also known as circumstantial evidence. It is not the direct testimony of an eyewitness. It has an effect on other facts and subsidiary facts which are depended upon as consistent.

REFERENCE: - The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 13

questions.text: Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is due to?
questions.solution:
Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing.

When the distance between the firing and the victim is between 30-50 cm (in the case of pistols and revolvers), it is a near-shot wound. The victim is within the range of powder deposition, so there is some amount of tattooing present. But it is outside the range of flame, so there will not be any burning or singeing. There will not be any blackening, as it is outside the range of smoke as well.

The injuries related to firearms are:

  • Burn injuries: Occur due to flame released during the firing. It is seen in contact shot wounds or distances up to 5-8 cm. Singeing of hair is caused due to burns.
  • Blackening: Occurs due to the deposit of smoke. It can be removed with a wet cloth. This can be seen up to around 15 cm of firing.
  • Tattooing: Occurs due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing.
  • Greasing and collaring: Occur due to the deposition of the lubricant of the bullet in the tissues, during its penetration. It can be found in contact, near-shot, or distant shot wounds.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing.

REFERENCE: - The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no 210

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is NOT considered as an oncogenic virus?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus is not considered as an oncogenic virus, as it is primarily associated with gastrointestinal infections and not with cancer development.

  • HPV, EBV, and HBV are all considered oncogenic viruses, as they can contribute to the development of various cancers, such as cervical cancer (HPV), Burkitt's lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma (EBV), and hepatocellular carcinoma (HBV).

Southern analysis to display mutant alleles

questions.text: Which of the following techniques will be required for newborn screening of cystic fibrosis or other diseases using DNA-based technology?
questions.solution:
The prime justification for newborn screening is that early diagnosis results in benefits through prevention or treatment. Although early identification of carriers through diagnosis of their affected newborns is a benefit of newborn screening

Option A) Florescent in situ hybridization may employ control and test labeled DNA probe to highlight their specific locus on a chromosome, showing two signals for individuals with paired autosome. An absence of test signal on one chromosome when the control signal is present shows there is a submicroscopic deletion as in the DiGeorge or Williams syndromes.

Option B) Subtelomere FISH analysis extends this to many DNA probes, highlighting all 44 autosome and the 2 X chromosome ends-subtle rearrangements will shift the position of the FISH signal, and deletions or duplications involving a target region will yield a missing or extra signal

Option C) DNA arrays or chips where thousands of DNA probes can be affixed to arrays on microbeads or glass slides, hybridized in replicate to individual DNAs, and passed through machines for reading of deficiencies. These techniques are undergoing explosive development, but cannot yet screen for thousands of potential mutant alleles in an individual

Option D) Southern analysis is intensive, time consuming and has limited use in this era of automated allele detection and DNA sequencing.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition chapter 35 Page 364,449-450

choices.text: Increase in Substrate concentration cannot reverse the reaction

questions.text: The Lineweaver Burk plot shown in above image of Effect of Malonate on Succinate Dehydrogenase is suggestive of
questions.solution:
Reaction catalyzed by Succinate Dehydrogenase is formation of Fumarate from Succinate. Malonate acts as competitive Inhibitor of the said enzyme. Thus the graph suggestive of Competitive Inhibition having no change in Vmax but km Increased.

In competitive inhibition, inhibitor binds with the substrate binding active site thus blocking the binding of substrate with enzyme. the structures of most classic competitive inhibitors therefore tend to resemble the structure of a substrate, and thus are termed substrate analogs.

Inhibition of the enzyme succinate dehydrogenase by malonate illustrates competitive inhibition by a substrate analog.

In effect, a competitive inhibitor acts by decreasing the number of free enzyme molecules available to bind substrate, that is, to form ES (enzyme substrate complex), and thus eventually to form product.

Increasing [S] decreases the concentration of the EI complex and raises the reaction velocity. The extent to which [S] must be increased to completely overcome the inhibition depends on the concentration of the inhibitor present, its affinity for the enzyme (K1), and the affinity, Km , of the enzyme for its substrate.

In non competitive Inhibition, Km remain same , Vmax decreases.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition chapter 8 Page 80-81

choices.text: Mutation in Vitamin D Receptor Gene

questions.text: A 3.5-year-old Male child presented with Delayed Walking, Weakness of muscle of leg, Bowed Leg. His blood level of 25 OH cholecalciferol is within normal range and Elevated Calcitriol levels are seen. S. Calcium and S. Phosphate levels are low. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As per given clinical case scenario with significant history suggestive of Rickets but normal level of 25 OH cholecalciferol (Storage form of Vitamin D) & elevated Calcitriol is most likely due to mutation in Vitamin D receptor Gene, this will leads to vitamin D resistant Ricket.

Normal 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D): This suggests that the child has an adequate amount of vitamin D storage, ruling out vitamin D deficiency as the cause.

Elevated Calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D): This is an unusual finding. In the context of normal 25(OH)D levels, an elevated calcitriol level suggests that the body is attempting to increase calcium and phosphate absorption, but the tissues are not responding properly to the active form of vitamin D.

Low serum calcium and phosphate: These are consistent with rickets, which often results from defective mineralization due to low calcium and phosphate levels.

Option A) Hypophosphatemic Rickets -: Typically caused by mutations in genes regulating phosphate metabolism (e.g., PHEX in X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets).

  • Pathophysiology: Leads to phosphate wasting in the kidneys and impaired bone mineralization.
  • Key Lab Findings: Low serum phosphate, normal to slightly low calcium, normal or low 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D.
  • Clinical Features: Bowing of legs, dental abnormalities, and growth retardation.

Option B) Renal Osteodystrophy -: Secondary to chronic kidney disease (CKD), causing imbalances in calcium, phosphate, and vitamin D metabolism.

  • Pathophysiology: CKD reduces Calcitriol production, leading to secondary hyperparathyroidism and bone remodeling issues.
  • Key Lab Findings: Elevated phosphate, low or normal calcium, elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH).
  • Clinical Features: Bone pain, skeletal deformities, and growth impairment in children.

Option C) Vitamin D Deficient Rickets ;Caused by insufficient vitamin D intake, limited sun exposure, or malabsorption.

  • Pathophysiology: Impaired calcium and phosphate absorption leads to poor bone mineralization.
  • Key Lab Findings: Low calcium, low phosphate, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and low 25-hydroxyvitamin D.
  • Clinical Features: Bowing of legs, delayed growth, and craniotabes (soft skull bones).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition Chapter 44

choices.text: 25 g/dL, indicative of microcytic hypochromic anemia
30 g/dL, within the normal range
35 g/dL, indicative of hereditary spherocytosis
20 g/dL, indicative of severe anemia

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female presents with fatigue and pallor. Blood investigations reveal the following:

1. Hemoglobin (Hb): 9 g/dL (normal: 12-15 g/dL)
2. Hematocrit (Hct): 30% (normal: 36-46%)
3. Red Blood Cell (RBC) count: 4.0 million/μL (normal: 4.2-5.4 million/μL)

Calculate MCHC in this patient and identify its clinical significance.
questions.solution:
To calculate the MCHC:

MCHC

= 100 × Hemoglobin (Hb) /Hematocrit (Hct)

= 100 x 9/30

= 30 g/dl (normal range 28 to 36 g/dl)

  • Option b: The calculated MCHC is within the normal range. It suggests there is no hypochromia.
  • Option a: An MCHC of 25 g/dL would suggest hypochromia, but the calculated value is 30 g/dL, which is within the normal range.
  • Option c: MCHC values of 35 g/dL or higher are associated with hereditary spherocytosis, but this patient does not meet that criteria.
  • Option d: An MCHC of 20 g/dL would indicate severe hypochromia. It does not match with the value in this patient.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 1261

questions.text: Interval between Primary case and secondary case is known as
questions.solution:
• The gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called the "serial interval".
  • The primary case is followed by 2 or 3 secondary cases within a short time. By collecting information about a whole series of such onsets, we get a distribution of secondary cases from which we can guess the incubation period of disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called the "serial interval".

REFERENCE: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K.park,27th Edition, Chapter -3, Page no.107-108

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis presents with hematemesis. He is diagnosed with esophageal varices. Which of the following is the preferred method for managing acute bleeding from esophageal varices?
questions.solution:
Variceal bleeding management

  1. Endoscopic Band Ligation (EBL):
    • First-line treatment for acute esophageal variceal bleeding.
    • Involves the placement of rubber bands around varices to induce thrombosis and fibrosis, effectively stopping the bleeding.
    • Fewer complications (e.g., strictures, ulcers) and lower rebleeding rates than sclerotherapy.
  2. Endoscopic Sclerotherapy:
    • Historically used to manage variceal bleeding, it involves injecting a sclerosing agent into the varices.
    • Associated with a higher risk of complications such as esophageal ulcers, strictures, and rebleeding.
  3. Adjunctive Therapies:
    • Octreotide: A somatostatin analog that helps reduce portal hypertension and is used alongside endoscopic treatment.
    • Balloon Tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube): Used in cases of massive or uncontrolled bleeding as a temporary measure.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Endoscopic sclerotherapy: Incorrect. While sclerotherapy has been used historically, it is associated with a higher risk of complications such as esophageal ulcers and strictures compared to band ligation.

Option B. Endoscopic band ligation: Correct. Endoscopic band ligation (EBL) is the preferred treatment for acute esophageal variceal bleeding. It has fewer complications and a lower rebleeding rate compared to sclerotherapy.

Option C. Balloon tamponade: Incorrect. Balloon tamponade (e.g., Sengstaken-Blakemore tube) is used as a temporary measure in massive bleeding when endoscopic techniques fail or are unavailable, but it is not the first-line treatment.

Option D. Intravenous octreotide: Incorrect. While octreotide is used to reduce portal pressure and control bleeding, it is usually administered in combination with definitive treatments such as EBL, not as a standalone therapy.

Key Points:

  • Endoscopic band ligation is the preferred first-line treatment for acute esophageal variceal bleeding, as it is more effective and has fewer complications compared to sclerotherapy.
  • Sclerotherapy is rarely used today due to the availability of safer and more effective alternatives like EBL.

Tags:

Topic: Endoscopic Band Ligation and Sclerotherapy

Difficulty Level: Must Know; Moderate

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-69, Page 1204

questions.text:
A 28-year-old primigravida with a history of moderate persistent asthma is undergoing an emergency cesarean section due to non-reassuring fetal heart rates. Post-delivery, she develops postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony. Her blood loss is estimated at 1200 mL. On examination, the uterus is soft and boggy despite administration of oxytocin.

Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient for the management of PPH?
questions.solution:
• OPTION A: Oxytocin: First-line treatment for uterine atony; safe in asthma.
  • OPTION B: Misoprostol: Effective as a second-line agent; no significant bronchospastic effects, making it safe in asthma.
  • OPTION C: Carboprost: A prostaglandin F2α analogue that induces bronchospasm. It is contraindicated in asthma due to the risk of severe respiratory complications.
  • OPTION D: Tranexamic acid: Antifibrinolytic agent; safe and effective in managing hemorrhage and has no contraindications in asthma.

Type: Must know

Topic: PPH Management

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Chapter 23 Postpartum Haemorrhage, Page no. 394

choices.text: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is an acute bacterial infection of ascitic fluid.
The diagnosis is confirmed by finding an increased neutrophil count of 250/mm³ in aspirated ascitic fluid.
Culture of ascites is positive in as many as 90% of patients with clinical manifestations of SBP.

questions.text: All of the following are true about spontaneous bacterial peritonitis except .........
questions.solution:
Culture of ascites is negative in as many as 60% of patients with clinical manifestations of SBP.

Option A) :

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP; sometimes called primary bacterial peritonitis) is an acute bacterial infection of ascitic fluid. There is often a history of cirrhosis and ascites. The clinical picture is highly variable as the patient may be asymptomatic. The course can be prolonged.

Option B ) :

The diagnosis is made by paracentesis and should be considered in cirrhotic patients and those with ascites even when there is a low index of suspicion. The diagnosis is confirmed by finding an increased neutrophil count of 250/mm³ in aspirated ascitic fluid.

Option C ) :

Culture of ascites is negative in as many as 60% of patients with clinical manifestations of SBP. When culture is positive the most common pathogens include Gram-negative bacteria, usually Escherichia coli, and Gram-positive cocci (mainly streptococci and enterococci).

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition ; chapter 65 ; page 1089.

questions.text: An 18 year old boy from Rajasthan weighing 50 kg is diagnosed with mixed P. vivax and P. falciparum malaria. What is the appropriate treatment regimen on day 2?
questions.solution:
Uncomplicated falciparum malaria

  • Oral artemisinins are indicated for the treatment of all cases of uncomplicated falciparum malaria (CQ-resistant as well as sensitive) as ACT.
  • Even when used alone, they are almost 100% effective, but because of short duration of action recrudescence rates are high.
  • In order to preserve their powerful antimalarial activity and to reduce recrudescence rates, they must be used in combination with a long acting schizonticide which acts by a different mechanism.

Primaquine in Falciparum malaria

  • A single 45 mg dose of primaquine is given with the curative dose of ACT or CQ to kill the gametes and cut down transmission to mosquito.
  • However, the recent WHO guideline has advised a lower 15 mg (0.25 mg/kg) single dose for this purpose.

Key takeaway

  • Oral artemisinins are indicated for the treatment of all cases of uncomplicated falciparum malaria (CQ-resistant as well as sensitive) as ACT.
  • Primaquine is given with the curative dose of ACT or CQ to kill the gametes and cut down transmission to mosquito.

[Must Know]

[Artesunate/Primaquine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 877-888

questions.text:
A renal allograft biopsy shows:

1. Fibrosis and sclerosis of the glomeruli
2. Duplication of the tubular basement membrane
3. Interstitial fibrosis and inflammation
4. Peritubular capillaritis

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of fibrosis and sclerosis in the glomeruli, tubular basement membrane duplication, peritubular capillaritis, and interstitial fibrosis and inflammation is characteristic of chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN).


  • CAN is a long-term complication of kidney transplantation, resulting from chronic immune-mediated damage and non-immune factors.

A. Acute cellular rejection is characterized by tubulitis, interstitial inflammation, and vascular rejection.

B. Acute antibody-mediated rejection is characterized by the presence of donor-specific antibodies and C4d deposition in the graft.

C. Recurrent glomerulonephritis would show characteristic histological features of the original disease, such as membranous nephropathy or IgA nephropathy.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The combination of fibrosis and sclerosis in the glomeruli, tubular basement membrane duplication, peritubular capillaritis, and interstitial fibrosis and inflammation is characteristic of chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN).

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 236

questions.text: Identify the enzyme deficiency seen in above cutaneous manifestation of disease related with Heme Metabolism.
questions.solution:
As shown in above image related to Heme Metabolism most likely skin eruption seen in patient suffering from Porphyria Cutanea Tarda. The disease associated with server deficiency of UROD - Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. It will lead to accumulation of Uroporphyrin in urine.

Patients are photosensitive. Porphyrin accumulation leads to cutaneous manifestation as well as urine sample is red to brown in sunlight and pink to red in fluorescent light. It is most common type of porphyria and expression depends on hepatic iron load, sunlight exposure, alcohol ingestion, estrogen therapy and presence of Hepatitis B or C. Mutation are only 20% - Autosomal dominant .

In heme synthesis pathway various enzymes are involved and deficiency of enzymes leads to clinical presentation like porphyria.

Ferrochelatase and ALA dehydratase are inhibited by lead. ALAD deficiency leads to Acute Hepatic Porphyria. Similarly, Hydroxymethylbilane synthase also known as Porphobilinogen deaminase leads to Acute Intermittent Porphyria. Patients are not photosensitive.

UDP Glucuronosyl Transferase is involved in Heme Breakdown and conjugation of Bilirubin in liver. Not related with porphyria.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd Edition Chapter 26 page 418-419

questions.text: A 34 years old male patient presented to emergency room after road traffic accident. On examination patient had blood at tip of meatus. Which investigation should be done to rule out posterior urethral injury ?
questions.solution:
Blood at tip of meatus indicates urethral trauma. Voiding cystourethrogram is the Investigation of choice for urethral trauma.

Urethral Trauma Approach: Flowchart

  1. Initial Assessment:
    • Patient History and Physical Exam
      → Suspected mechanism of injury: Blunt trauma, pelvic fracture, straddle injury, or penetrating injury
      → Symptoms: Hematuria, blood at meatus, inability to urinate, perineal swelling, penile deformity, high-riding prostate
    • Vital Signs Assessment
      → Assess for signs of hemodynamic instability
  2. Stabilize Patient:
    • Airway, Breathing, Circulation (ABCs) → If unstable: Follow Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines
  3. Assess Injury Type: Anterior vs. Posterior Urethral Injury
    • Anterior Urethral Injury (e.g., straddle injury, penile trauma):
      → Look for localized signs of injury (swelling, bleeding)
      → Typically involves bulbar or penile urethra
      • If stable, consider immediate imaging (retrograde urethrogram)
      • If severe or complicated by open wounds: Surgical consult
    • Posterior Urethral Injury (often associated with pelvic fractures):
      → Check for high-riding prostate, difficulty in catheter insertion
      • Likely requires retrograde urethrogram for confirmation
      • Surgical consultation for exploration and repair
  4. Diagnostic Evaluation:
    • Retrograde Urethrogram (RUG): → Indicated for all suspected urethral injuries
      → Evaluate extent and location of injury (disruption, contusion, or partial tear)
    • Pelvic Imaging (CT scan) if associated injuries are suspected (e.g., pelvic fractures)
  5. Management Based on Findings:
    • For Partial Urethral Tears:
      → Conservative management (catheterization, suprapubic catheter if needed)
      → Observation and follow-up with urology
    • For Complete Urethral Disruption:
      → Surgical repair (primary realignment or delayed repair depending on the case)
      → Suprapubic catheter placement may be required for urinary diversion
  6. Post-Operative/Management Follow-up:
    • Urethral Catheter: Typically remains in place for a few weeks for healing
    • Monitor for Complications: Stricture formation, incontinence, erectile dysfunction
  7. Long-Term Follow-up:
    • Urethral Stricture Risk: Consider urethroscopy or follow

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 85 ; page 1538.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P1, is scheduled for an elective cesarean section due to a history of a previous cesarean delivery. She has a known allergy to penicillin, which causes a severe rash. In light of her allergy, what is the most appropriate antibiotic to administer as prophylaxis for this surgery?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a penicillin allergy, which precludes the use of penicillin or cephalosporins for prophylaxis during cesarean delivery. Clindamycin is the recommended alternative, as it provides excellent coverage against Gram-positive cocci (including Streptococcus agalactiae, a common cause of infection in cesarean sections), which are the primary pathogens involved in post-cesarean infections.

Option-wise explanation:

  • A) Metronidazole: While metronidazole is effective against anaerobes, it does not cover the common Gram-positive organisms responsible for cesarean infections, such as Streptococcus and Staphylococcus.
  • B) Clindamycin: Correct answer. Clindamycin covers both Gram-positive bacteria and anaerobes, making it a suitable choice for women with penicillin allergies. It is effective against Streptococcus species, Staphylococcus aureus, and Group B Streptococcus, which are the primary pathogens involved in cesarean wound infections.
  • C) Ciprofloxacin: Although ciprofloxacin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, it is not typically used for prophylaxis in cesarean sections because it has limited activity against Gram-positive organisms. It is more commonly used for urinary tract infections or in cases of suspected resistant Gram-negative organisms.
  • D) Azithromycin: While azithromycin is an effective antibiotic against a range of organisms, it is not the preferred choice for surgical prophylaxis in cesarean sections, particularly because it does not cover Gram-positive cocci as effectively as clindamycin.

Type: Must know

Topic: Caesarean section

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 177: Antibiotic Prophylaxis for Cesarean Delivery

choices.text: The superior oblique muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III).
The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for adduction of the eye.
The inferior oblique muscle originates from the floor of the orbit and inserts on the lateral surface of the globe.
The primary function of the medial rectus muscle is adduction of the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the extraocular muscles is true?
questions.solution:
• The superior oblique muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III): False. The superior oblique is innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV).
  • The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for adduction of the eye: False. The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for abduction of the eye.
  • The inferior oblique muscle originates from the floor of the orbit and inserts on the lateral surface of the globe: False. The inferior oblique originates from the maxillary bone and inserts on the posterior aspect of the globe, primarily on the lateral surface.
  • The primary function of the medial rectus muscle is adduction of the eye: True. The medial rectus muscle pulls the eye medially, resulting in adduction.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

#extraocular muscle anatomy #functions of recti #must know

Reference:

Kanski, Jack J., and Bowling, Brad. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Elsevier, 2016, pp. 48-53.

questions.text:
10-year-old boy presents with a 2-week history of Swelling in the right jaw, Weight loss, Fever, Night sweats,

Physical examination reveals:
1. Palpable lymphadenopathy in the neck and axilla
2. Hepatosplenomegaly

Biopsy of the mass reveals: 'Starry sky' appearance.

Which of the following chromosomal translocation is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Clinical presentation and physical examination findings are consistent with Burkitt lymphoma.

  • Biopsy findings of starry sky appearance is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma.
  • t(8;14) translocation is a hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma.
  • The t(8;14)(q24;q32) translocation involves the MYC oncogene on chromosome 8 and the IGH gene on chromosome 14, leading to overexpression of MYC protein.
  • This translocation is seen in approximately 80% of Burkitt lymphoma cases.

The other options are not specific to Burkitt lymphoma:

B. t(11;14)(q13;q32) is associated with mantle cell lymphoma.

C. t(14;18)(q32;q21) is associated with follicular lymphoma.

D. t(4;11)(q21;q23) is associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- t(8;14) translocation is a hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 601.

questions.text: Which species of Leishmania is primarily responsible for causing mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, characterized by lesions affecting mucous membranes and skin?
questions.solution:
Leishmania braziliensis is the primary causative agent of mucocutaneous leishmaniasis. This form of leishmaniasis is characterized by lesions affecting mucous membranes of the mouth and nose, in addition to skin lesions.

A) Leishmania donovani

Incorrect. Leishmania donovani is primarily responsible for visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kala-azar, which affects internal organs rather than the mucous membranes or skin.

B) Leishmania major

Incorrect. Leishmania major is primarily associated with cutaneous leishmaniasis, causing skin ulcers, but it is not typically associated with mucocutaneous leishmaniasis.

C) Leishmania braziliensis

Correct. Leishmania braziliensis is the primary causative agent of mucocutaneous leishmaniasis. This form of leishmaniasis is characterized by lesions affecting mucous membranes of the mouth and nose, in addition to skin lesions.

D) Leishmania tropica

Incorrect. Leishmania tropica is associated with cutaneous leishmaniasis in some regions but does not typically cause mucocutaneous leishmaniasis.


Key Takeaway: Leishmania braziliensis is specifically linked to mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, which involves both skin and mucosal lesions. Differentiating between Leishmania species is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis

questions.text: Drug of choice for management of Prinzmetal's angina?
questions.solution:
Prinzmetal's Angina presents with acute chest pain of cardiac origin with rest pain and transient ST segment elevation.

Typically, patients are younger and has less risk factors except cigarette smoking.

Must Know facts about Prinzmetal's angina:

  • Occurs due to coronary spasm which can be demonstrated by coronary angiography
  • Nitrates and calcium channel blockers are the main therapeutic agents.
  • Aspirin may actually increase the severity of ischemic episodes, possibly as a result of the sensitivity of coronary tone to modest changes in the synthesis of prostacyclin. Statin therapy has been shown to reduce the risk of major adverse events
  • The response to beta blockers is variable. Coronary revascularization may be helpful in patients who also have discrete, flow-limiting, proximal fixed obstructive lesions.
  • Prognosis is good.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2052

questions.text: MEN 2A syndrome results from which of the following gene mutations?
questions.solution:
MEN 2A- results from RET gene mutation.

Various features of MEN2A include:

MTC (90%) Pheochromocytoma (>50%) Parathyroid adenoma (10-25%)

MEN2B- also results from RET gene mutation. Various clinical features of mutation include:

MTC (>90%) Pheochromocytoma (>50%)

Associated abnormalities (40-50%)

  • Mucosal neuromas
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
  • Megacolon

MEN-1 syndrome results from mutation in MEN-1 gene. The predominant manifestations include:

Parathyroid adenoma (90%)

Enteropancreatic tumor (30-70%)

  • Gastrinoma (>50%)
  • Insulinoma (10-30%)
  • Nonfunctioning and PPoma (20-55%)
  • Glucagonoma (<3%)
  • VIPoma (<1%)

Pituitary adenoma (15-50%)

  • Prolactinoma (60%)
  • Somatotrophinoma (25%)
  • Corticotrophinoma (<5%)
  • Nonfunctioning (<5%)

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no: 2984.

questions.text: What is the Declaration of Oslo related to?
questions.solution:

  • Option C - Declaration of Helsinki: Concerned with human experimentation.

questions.text: HIV primarily infects which of the following cells in the immune system?
questions.solution:
• HIV attacks and destroys the CD4 cells (CD4 T lymphocyte) of the immune system. CD4 cells play a major role in protecting the body from infection.
  • HIV uses the machinery of the CD4 cells to multiply and spread throughout the body. This process, which is carried out in seven steps or stages, is called the HIV life cycle.

A) Red blood cells- Incorrect. HIV does not primarily infect red blood cells; it targets immune cells.

B) B lymphocytes- Incorrect. While HIV can affect B cells indirectly, it primarily infects CD4+ T cells.

C) CD4+ T cells- Correct. HIV primarily infects CD4+ T cells, which are crucial for the immune response.

D) Neutrophils- Incorrect. Neutrophils are not the primary targets of HIV infection.

Key Takeaway: HIV specifically targets and destroys CD4+ T cells, leading to immune system compromise. The HIV life cycle is critical to understanding how the virus replicates and spreads within the body, and it forms the foundation for developing antiretroviral therapies (ART). Each stage of the life cycle is a target for specific drugs designed to inhibit viral replication and prevent the progression of HIV infection to AIDS.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). HIV Basics. CDC HIV Basics

questions.text: Lead time refers to the time between:
questions.solution:
• Lead time specifically refers to the time between the detection of a disease or condition and the point at which it would have been diagnosed without screening.
  • It's a concept often discussed in the context of early detection or screening programs.
  • Lead time in healthcare can be both beneficial and potentially misleading, as it can provide an opportunity for early intervention and treatment, but it can also create the appearance of prolonged survival without necessarily extending overall lifespan.
  • lead time refers to the interval between the first possible point of detection of a disease or condition through screening or other means, and the usual time of diagnosis if the disease or condition had presented with symptoms.
  • It's crucial in evaluating the effectiveness of screening programs and understanding the implications of early detection.

Top of Form

KEY TAKEAWAYS: lead time refers to the interval between the first possible point of detection of a disease or condition through screening or other means, and the usual time of diagnosis if the disease or condition had presented with symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient sustains a penetrating trauma to the abdomen. On exploratory laparotomy, a grade IV liver laceration involving the inferior vena cava (IVC) is discovered. According to the AAST liver injury scale, what grade corresponds to a liver injury involving the major hepatic veins or retro hepatic vena cava?
questions.solution:
Option A. Grade III: Incorrect. Grade III liver injuries involve lacerations greater than 3 cm but do not involve major vascular structures.

Option B. Grade IV: Incorrect. Grade IV involves major lacerations or parenchymal disruption, but without injury to the major hepatic veins or vena cava.

Option C. Grade V: Correct. Grade V injuries involve parenchymal disruption of more than 75% of the liver lobe or major injuries to the hepatic veins or retrohepatic vena cava.

Option D. Grade VI: Incorrect. Grade VI represents hepatic avulsion, which is a near-complete or complete separation of the liver from its vascular attachments.

Liver Injury Grading

Key Points:

  • Grade V liver injuries include those involving major vascular structures like the inferior vena cava or hepatic veins.
  • These injuries carry a high risk of hemorrhage and require immediate surgical intervention.

  • Difficulty Level: Good to Know

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoing hysteroscopic surgery with glycine experiences breathlessness after the procedure. The surgical team is concerned about the possible absorption of glycine. What is the best method for monitoring this patient postoperatively?
questions.solution:
• The most effective way to monitor for complications related to glycine absorption is to closely monitor serum sodium levels and fluid balance (OPTION B). This helps detect hyponatremia and fluid overload.
  • OPTION A: Abdominal x-rays are not necessary for monitoring glycine absorption.
  • OPTION C: Diuretics are not typically administered immediately unless fluid overload is severe.
  • OPTION D: A nasogastric tube is unnecessary in this case. A nasogastric tube would be indicated if there were concerns about gastric distention or a bowel obstruction, which is not the primary concern here. The primary issue is fluid absorption, so electrolyte monitoring is more critical.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Distension media in hysteroscopy

Reference: American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (ACOG) Practice Bulletin No. 130(2012)

choices.text: Inhibition of ovulation by suppression of gonadotropins
Decreasing the motility of fallopian tubes

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is prescribed combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) for contraception. Which of the following is the primary mechanism by which COCPs prevent pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (COCPs): COCPs contain estrogen and progestin, which act through multiple mechanisms to prevent pregnancy.

A. Thickening of cervical mucus:

  • Progestin in COCPs thickens cervical mucus, creating a barrier to sperm penetration.
  • While this contributes to contraceptive efficacy, it is not the primary mechanism.

B. Inhibition of ovulation by suppression of gonadotropins:

  • The estrogen-progestin combination suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.
  • This inhibits the release of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), thereby preventing ovulation.
  • Primary mechanism: Suppression of ovulation accounts for the main contraceptive effect of COCPs.

C. Alteration of the endometrial lining:

  • Progestin causes the endometrial lining to become less receptive to implantation.
  • This is a secondary mechanism, not the primary action.

D. Decreasing the motility of fallopian tubes:

  • Progestin may reduce tubal motility, but this effect is not well-established or primary in preventing pregnancy.

Type: Must know

Topic: Combined Oral Contraceptives

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Chapter 19 Temporary and Permanent Methods of Contraception, Page no: 263

Laboratory tests reveal:
1. Positive Coombs test
2. Presence of autoantibodies against red blood cells
3. Increased reticulocyte count

Which type of hypersensitivity is this?
questions.solution:
• The presence of autoantibodies against red blood cells and a positive Coombs test indicate an immune-mediated destruction of red blood cells, characteristic of Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA).
  • The increased reticulocyte count suggests a compensatory response to the hemolysis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Auto immune hemolytic anemia is an example of type II hypersensitivity, where antibodies bind to specific antigens on the surface of red blood cells, marking them for destruction.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 210.
