questions.text:
A 50-year-old female presents with Cushing's syndrome and a 3 cm mass in the lung.

Biopsy reveals:
1. Small, round cells with scant cytoplasm
2. Positive immunostaining for ACTH, chromogranin A, and synaptophysin
3. Ki-67 index of 1%

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms of Cushing's syndrome suggest an ACTH-producing tumor.
  • The biopsy findings of small, round cells with positive immunostaining for ACTH, chromogranin A, and synaptophysin support a neuroendocrine tumor.
  • The low Ki-67 index (1%) indicates a well-differentiated tumor, consistent with OPTION A NET G1 (bronchial carcinoid tumor).

Incorrect Options:

B: Small cell lung carcinoma:

  • Typically presents with aggressive symptoms, such as weight loss, cough, and chest pain
  • Biopsy shows small, round cells with scant cytoplasm, but:
    • Usually has a high Ki-67 index (>50%)
    • Typically doesn't produce ACTH, so wouldn't cause Cushing's syndrome
    • Often has a different immunostaining profile (e.g., positive for CD56, TTF-1)

C: Adenocarcinoma of the lung:

  • Most common type of lung cancer, often presents with cough, chest pain, or incidental finding.
  • Biopsy shows glandular or acinar architecture, but:
    • Typically doesn't produce ACTH, so wouldn't cause Cushing's syndrome
    • Often has a different immunostaining profile (e.g., positive for TTF-1, CK7)
    • Can have a variable Ki-67 index

D: Pulmonary metastasis of a gastrointestinal NET:

  • Would typically present with a history of a primary NET in the GI tract
  • Biopsy would show similar morphology and immunostaining to the primary tumor
  • Ki-67 index would depend on the primary tumor's grade
  • Less likely, as the tumor is primary in the lung

KEY TAKEAWAYS: small, round cells with positive immunostaining for ACTH, chromogranin A, and synaptophysin support a neuroendocrine tumor. The low Ki-67 index (1%) indicates a well-differentiated tumor, consistent with NET G1 (bronchial carcinoid tumor).

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 1116.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old male visited physician for fitness. Doctor examined patient clinically and advised patient to do osmotic fragility test. The result of fragility test is as follows,

1. Hemolysis begins at 0.5% saline
2. Hemolysis completes at 0.35% saline

What is the conclusion in this male?
questions.solution:
• Osmotic fragility test:
    • This test evaluates the ability of red blood cells (RBCs) to withstand osmotic stress in hypotonic saline solutions. The range for hemolysis in normal individuals is:
      • Hemolysis begins: 0.45-0.50% saline
      • Hemolysis completes: 0.30-0.35% saline
  • Option a: The patient's results fall within the normal range, with hemolysis starting at 0.5% saline and completing at 0.35% saline. This indicates normal RBC membrane stability and no pathology.
  • Option b: Increased osmotic fragility occurs when RBCs rupture at higher saline concentrations (e.g., hemolysis begins at 0.6% saline and completes at 0.5% saline).
    • This is typically seen in conditions like hereditary spherocytosis, where membrane defects make RBCs more fragile.
  • Option c: Decreased osmotic fragility occurs when RBCs can withstand lower saline concentrations before lysing (e.g., hemolysis begins at 0.4% saline and completes at 0.25% saline).
    • This is seen in conditions like thalassemia or iron deficiency anemia, where RBCs are more resistant to osmotic stress due to altered shape or composition.
  • Option d: This refers to RBCs rupturing under mechanical stress (e.g., shear forces) rather than osmotic stress. It is seen in sickle cell anemia.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page no: 1265.

questions.text: What is recommended dilution and route of administration of adrenaline in case of anaphylaxis?
questions.solution:
• The treatment of first choice for anaphylaxis is intramuscular administration of 0.3-0.5 mL of 1:1000 (1 mg/mL) epinephrine, with repeated doses at 5- to 20-min intervals as needed for a severe reaction. The failure to use epinephrine within the first 20 min of symptoms is a risk factor for poor clinical outcomes in various studies of anaphylaxis.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine, page no: 2728.

questions.text: A 4 year old child developed acute laryngobronchitis. His x-ray image is given below. What is the name of the sign shown in this image?
questions.solution:
The steeple sign is a radiographic appearance that can be seen on a frontal neck radiograph of a patient with croup or other conditions:

Appearance

The steeple sign is characterized by a narrowing of the subglottic lumen that makes the tracheal air column look like a church steeple or a steeply pitched roof.

Cause

The steeple sign is caused by edema in the trachea, which elevates the tracheal mucosa and makes the air column lose Its normal lateral convexities.

Conditions

The steeple sign is usually seen in children with croup, but it can also be caused by other conditions, such as angioneurotic edema, bacterial tracheitis, epiglottitis, and thermal injury.

Croup is a viral infection of the upper airway that can cause a characteristic cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, and dyspnoea. Other symptoms of acute laryngotracheobronchitis, also known as croup, include mild chest wall retraction and audible stridor.

Treatment for croup includes intranasal oxygen, oral dexamethasone, and epinephrine nebulization.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi, page no: 340.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with secondary amenorrhea 6 months after undergoing a D&C for a miscarriage. She reports normal menstrual cycles prior to the procedure. On ultrasound, the endometrial stripe is noted to be thin and irregular. A hysteroscopy is performed, and intrauterine adhesions are visualized.

What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient, based on the clinical presentation and diagnostic findings, is Asherman syndrome.

Optionwise analysis:

a) Endometrial carcinoma

  • Endometrial carcinoma typically presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in postmenopausal women, rather than secondary amenorrhea after a miscarriage. The ultrasound finding of a thin, irregular endometrial stripe is more suggestive of Asherman syndrome rather than endometrial carcinoma, which would show a thickened endometrium with possible mass or irregularities.

b) Asherman syndrome

  • Correct answer: Asherman syndrome is characterized by the formation of intrauterine adhesions (scar tissue) usually following trauma to the endometrial lining, such as a dilation and curettage (D&C) procedure.
  • Asherman syndrome is often associated with menstrual irregularities, infertility, and recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Hysteroscopy, which visualizes the uterine cavity, confirms the diagnosis.
  • The patient's history of D&C for a missed miscarriage, followed by secondary amenorrhea and a thin, irregular endometrial stripe on ultrasound, points to the presence of intrauterine adhesions.
  • Most likely diagnosis.

c) Uterine fibroids

  • Uterine fibroids present with symptoms like heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia), pelvic pain, or bulk symptoms, but they would not typically cause secondary amenorrhea unless they obstruct the endometrial cavity. On ultrasound, fibroids would appear as well-defined masses in the myometrium, not as a thin endometrial stripe.

d) Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)

  • PCOS commonly presents with menstrual irregularities, such as oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, often accompanied by other signs like hyperandrogenism and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. However, PCOS does not typically present with a thin, irregular endometrial stripe and intrauterine adhesions, as seen in this patient.
  • Not likely.

In summary, Asherman syndrome is the most likely diagnosis due to its association with uterine scarring after D&C, leading to the formation of adhesions that cause secondary amenorrhea and irregularities in the endometrial stripe seen on ultrasound.

Type: Must know

Topic: Asherman syndrome

Reference: Speroff's Gynaecology 9th edition, Chapter 10 Amenorrhoea, Page no: 865.

choices.text: This is characterised by occlusive disease of small and medium-sized limb arteries
Histologically, there are inflammatory changes in the walls of arteries and veins, leading to thrombosis
Treatment is total abstinence from smoking, which arrests and reverse, the disease

questions.text: A 35 years old male smoker patient presented to OPD with complains of Right side lower limb pain. Resident doctor is suspecting Buerger's disease. Which of the following statements are true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease)

Option A):

This is characterised by occlusive disease of small and medium-sized limb arteries, thrombophlebitis of superficial or deep veins and Raynaud's syndrome; it usually occurs in young male smokers.

Option B):

Histologically, there are inflammatory changes in the walls of arteries and veins, leading to thrombosis.

Option C):

Treatment is total abstinence from smoking, which arrests, but does not reverse, the disease. Established arterial occlusions are treated as for atheromatous disease, but amputations may eventually be required.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery; 28th edition; chapter 61, page no: 1024.

choices.text: 24 hour urinary free cortisol excretion
Low dose dexamethasone test (0.5 mg every 6 hourly for 2 days or 8 mg overnight)

questions.text: A middle aged male presents with central obesity and buffalo hump. Possibility of cushing syndrome is kept. There is no history of over the counter steroid intake. Which of the following tests will confirm the diagnosis of cushing syndrome?
questions.solution:
Screening test for suspected cushing include:

  • 24-h urinary free cortisol excretion increased above normal (≥2x)
  • Dexamethasone overnight test (Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8-9 am after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 pm).
  • Midnight salivary cortisol >5 nmol/L (≥2x)

Confirmatory tests include:

  • Low dose DEX test (Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L after 0.5 mg DEX q6h for 2 days or a single dose of 8 mg overnight)

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine, page no: 2962.

choices.text: Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong
Start ART after First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong

questions.text: A pregnant lady was found to be HIV positive in First trimester. Next line of management is:
questions.solution:
• Antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be initiated immediately in all HIV-positive pregnant women, regardless of the trimester. Early initiation of ART helps reduce maternal viral load, preventing mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV.
  • Triple Drug Therapy: The standard regimen typically involves a combination of three antiretroviral drugs from at least two classes. Common regimens include:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine/Emtricitabine + Efavirenz (or other integrase inhibitors like Dolutegravir).

  • Current guidelines recommend that ART should be continued lifelong in HIV-positive women to maintain viral suppression and prevent further transmission to the child and others.

Incorrect options:

  • a. Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery: ART should not be stopped after delivery; it must be lifelong.
  • c. Start ART after First trimester: ART is recommended to start immediately, even in the first trimester.
  • d. Start ART after First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong: ART should begin immediately, not after the first trimester.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: ART is started as soon as diagnosis is made and continued lifelong.

Reference: National Guideline for HIV Care & Treament, MOHFW,GOI, section no: 5a, Page No: 62-66 https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National_Guidelines_for_HIV_Care_and_Treatment_2021.pdf

choices.text: To allow damaged cells to repair DNA
To permit cells to enter quiescence
To regulate cell growth and division

questions.text: What is the primary function of the G1 checkpoint in the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
The G1 checkpoint ensures that a cell is ready to enter the S phase of the cell cycle by checking:

  1. Cell Size: Ensures the cell has grown enough to divide.
  2. DNA Integrity: Detects and repairs DNA damage or triggers apoptosis if the damage is irreparable.
  3. Nutrient Availability: Confirms sufficient nutrients and energy are present.
  4. Growth Signals: Responds to external growth factors needed for division.
  5. Quiescence Decision: Determines whether to proceed or enter a resting state (G0).

Key regulators include p53 (DNA damage response), Cyclins/CDKs, and Retinoblastoma (Rb). If conditions are favorable, the cell moves into the S phase for DNA replication.

Explanation:

D. The G1 checkpoint ensures that cells are ready to enter the S phase and undergo DNA replication by checking for proper cell growth and division.

A. G2 checkpoint allows damaged cells to repair DNA.

B. Chromosome segregation occurs during mitosis.

C. Quiescence is a state of dormancy that can occur outside of the cell cycle.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The G1 checkpoint ensures that cells are ready to enter the S phase and undergo DNA replication by checking for proper cell growth and division.

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 27.

questions.text: The given image shows a newborn suffering from Blue Sclera and Brittle bone disease mainly Type I Collagen vascular disorder. Identify the most likely mutation involving amino acid occurred in this child
questions.solution:
Above case study is of Osteogenesis Imperfecta - a collage disorder. It is also called as Brittle bone disease. Over 80% of cases of OI are caused by dominant mutation of Genes that encodes the alpha 1 or alpha 2 chains in type I collagen.

The most common mutation cause the replacement of Glycine (in -Gly-X-Y-) by amino acids with bulky side chains.

The disease is characterized by mild bone fragility, hearing loss, and blue sclera. also multiple fractures at birth , short stature and humped back appearance can be seen in severe form.

Glycine is present at every third residue within a collagen monomer because it is the only amino acid side chain that can fit in the triple helix when the three chains wind about each other. Substitution of glycine with any other amino acid can lead to a weakened collagen structure.

Conversion of proline to hydroxyproline is a normal event in collagen biosynthesis and allows for hydrogen bonding to occur, which will stabilize the collagen triple helix. Proline to glycine will not lead to cross-links in collagen, nor will glycine or serine to proline. The latter mutations may disrupt triple-helix formation and lead to a form of osteogenesis imperfecta, but they would not lead to the biochemical findings of cross-linking.

Option A) Proline: While proline is important for collagen structure, substitution of glycine with proline (as seen in OI) is a mutation, not a normal occurrence. This mutation disrupts the collagen structure, but proline itself is not the amino acid that is usually mutated in OI.

Option B) Hydroxyproline: is important in stabilizing collagen through hydrogen bonding, but mutations in hydroxyproline are not the primary cause of OI. Instead, it's the primary amino acid (glycine) in the collagen sequence that is mutated.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Review Biochemistry SAE Chapter 9, Page no: 127-128.

questions.text: What is the primary vector responsible for transmitting dengue virus to humans?
questions.solution:
A) Anopheles mosquito- Incorrect. The Anopheles mosquito is primarily responsible for transmitting malaria, not dengue. Sits at an angle to surface.

B) Aedes mosquito- Correct. The Aedes mosquito, specifically Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the dengue virus to humans.

C) Culex mosquito- Incorrect. Culex mosquitoes are vectors for other diseases such as West Nile virus and filariasis, but not dengue.

D) Tsetse fly- Incorrect. The tsetse fly is the vector for trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not dengue fever.

Key Takeaway: The Aedes mosquito is the primary vector for dengue fever transmission. Understanding these properties helps in devising control measures and public health interventions to mitigate the spread of diseases transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Dengue Transmission. CDC Dengue Transmission

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with non-classic CAH presents with hirsutism and irregular periods. She is found to have mildly elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. What is the first-line treatment for managing hirsutism in this patient?
questions.solution:
In women with non-classic CAH, oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly used to treat hirsutism and irregular periods. OCPs help to reduce ovarian androgen production and also suppress excessive adrenal androgen secretion, improving symptoms like hirsutism and acne.

In women with non-classic congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), the first-line treatment for managing symptoms like hirsutism and irregular periods is the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs). OCPs help to regulate menstrual cycles, suppress excessive ovarian androgen production, and reduce adrenal androgen secretion. This leads to improvement in hirsutism and other androgenic symptoms, such as acne. OCPs are particularly useful as they provide both contraceptive benefits and hormonal regulation.

  • Spironolactone is an anti-androgen that can be used in conjunction with OCPs if additional control of hirsutism is needed.
  • Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor used for hirsutism, but it is not typically the first-line treatment in this scenario.
  • GnRH agonists are not the first choice for non-classic CAH. They are usually used in conditions involving central precocious puberty or endometriosis.

Thus, OCPs remain the cornerstone of treatment for hirsutism in women with non-classic CAH.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia

Reference: Speroff’s Gynaecology 9th edition, Chapter 12 Hirsutism, Page no. 1087-1088

questions.text: 5 year old patient presented with itching and skin lesion over cubital fossa, popliteal fossa, and neck. History of similar recurrent lesions present since 6 years. Similar history was present in younger brother. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hanifin and rajka criteria for diagnosis of atopic dermatitis:


Option A: Scabies is caused by sarcoptes scabiei var hominis (mite). Short duration of generalized itching with predominant involvement of flexures, interdigital space, areola, genitals(circle of hebra). There is night aggravation of itching. Scabies is highly contagious.

Option B: Lichen planus is characterized by pruritic, purple, polygonal, plane topped (flat) papule with flexural surface involvement. On the surface of lesion, there are white criss cross streaks (Wickham’s striae).

Option D: Seborrheic dermatitis is characterized by greasy yellow scales involving scalp, retro auricular area, around nose.

choices.text: The linea aspera serves as an attachment site for multiple muscles.
The femoral head articulates with the acetabulum of the pelvis to form the hip joint.
The intertrochanteric line is located posteriorly, connecting the greater and lesser trochanters.
The undersurface of patella glides over the trochlea and inter-condylar notch during flexion and extension of knee joint.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the femur is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Linea Aspera

  • The medial and lateral surfaces of the femoral shaft are smooth, but the posterior surface features a roughened ridge called the Linea Aspera (Latin for "rough line").
  • It has distinct medial and lateral lips that serve as attachment sites for multiple muscles.

Intertrochanteric Line

  • Located anteriorly, the intertrochanteric line connects the greater and lesser trochanters on the anterior surface of the femur.
  • It marks the junction of the anterior surface of the neck with the shaft of the femur.
  • This prominent roughened ridge begins as a tubercle at the anterosuperior angle of the greater trochanter and continues below as the spiral line, in front of the lesser trochanter.
  • The spiral line winds around the shaft below the lesser trochanter, reaching the posterior surface of the femoral shaft.

Femoral Head

  • The femoral head forms more than half of a sphere and is directed medially, upwards, and slightly forwards.
  • It articulates with the acetabulum of the pelvic bone to form the hip joint, which is a ball-and-socket joint.

Lower Articular Surface

The lower articular surface of the femur is divided into two parts:

  1. Anterior - Patellar side:
    • The patellar articular surface covers the anterior region between the two condyles, called the trochlear surface.
    • The trochlear surface contacts the patella during knee extension.
  2. Distal - Tibial side:
    • During knee flexion, the patella sits between the two condyles in the intercondylar notch.

General orthopaedics and basic sciences

Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy -Volume 2, Edition 6th, page no. 15.

choices.text: Drain the hematoma and suture the bleeding vessel
Start intravenous antibiotics and provide analgesia

questions.text:
A 26-year-old primigravida complains of severe perineal pain and swelling 8 hours postpartum. On examination, a tender, firm, bluish swelling measuring 6 cm in diameter is noted at the episiotomy site. The patient is hemodynamically stable but reports increasing discomfort.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) Apply cold compresses and monitor

  • Explanation: Cold compresses may be used for small hematomas (<2-3 cm) to reduce swelling and pain, but they are insufficient for larger hematomas. Observation alone risks worsening the condition.

B) Drain the hematoma and suture the bleeding vessel

  • Explanation: Surgical drainage is indicated for hematomas >5 cm or those causing significant pain or discomfort. Identifying and suturing the bleeding vessel addresses the source of the problem, preventing further complications. This is the definitive management.

C) Start intravenous antibiotics and provide analgesia

  • Explanation: Antibiotics and pain relief are supportive treatments and do not resolve the hematoma. These are typically used adjunctively after the hematoma has been managed.

D) Perform a blood transfusion immediately

  • Explanation: Blood transfusion is unnecessary unless the patient shows signs of hemodynamic instability or significant blood loss. In this case, the patient is stable, so transfusion is not indicated.

Type: Must know

Topic: Complications of episiotomy

Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition, Chapter 37, Operative Obstetrics Page no. 651

questions.text: Vestibular evoked myogenic potential (VEMP) in sternocleidomastoid muscle detects lesion in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Vestibular evoked myogenic potential (VEMP) is a neurophysiological test that measures muscle activity in response to sound or vibration to assess the function of the inner ear’s otolithic organs through Inferior vestibular nerve.

A repetitive sound stimulus is applied to one ear, and the muscle activity in response is averaged.

VEMPs are measured from the neck using surface electrodes over sternocleidomastoid muscle (cervical VEMP, or cVEMP) or under the eyes (ocular VEMP, or oVEMP).

VEMPs can help diagnose conditions like vestibular neuritis, Meniere’s disease, and multiple sclerosis. They can also help identify which side of the body may be causing imbalance or dizziness.

During the test, you’ll recline at an angle and have sticker electrodes attached to your head and neck. You’ll hear a knocking sound as you lift your head slightly.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg 51.

choices.text: Prior otitis media is not an exclusion criteria

questions.text: A 5 year old child presented with congenital cholesteatoma. His otoendoscopy examination is shown in the image given below. Which of the following feature is not a part of Levenson s criteria for congenital cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
The Levenson criteria for diagnosing congenital cholesteatoma (CC) are:

  1. A pearly white mass is medial to an intact tympanic membrane
  2. The pars tensa and pars flaccida are normal
  3. There is no history of otorrhea, perforation, or previous otologic procedure.

Canal atresia, intramembranous cholesteatoma, and giant cholesteatoma are excluded

Levenson revised the criteria to include previous bouts of otitis media or effusion, which were not previously considered exclusion criteria.

Early diagnosis of CC is important to avoid extensive damage to the middle ear, achieve better hearing outcomes, and reduce the risk of recurrence.

Reference: Disease Of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg 80.

choices.text: Oral antiviral therapy for the mother at 36 weeks gestation
Postpartum antiviral therapy for the newborn
Routine administration of acyclovir to the newborn after delivery

questions.text: A pregnant woman with genital herpes is concerned about transmitting the infection to her baby. She is in her third trimester and has a history of recurrent genital herpes. What is the most important aspect of management to reduce neonatal transmission?
questions.solution:
The most important measure to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes transmission is to prevent maternal genital herpes outbreaks at the time of delivery. This can be achieved by starting oral antiviral therapy (such as acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir) at 36 weeks gestation. This treatment helps to suppress the virus and reduce the likelihood of active outbreaks at the time of delivery, thus lowering the risk of transmission to the baby during labor.

Other Options?

  • A) Immediate cesarean section: A cesarean section is recommended only if there are active genital herpes lesions or prodromal symptoms (like viral shedding) at the time of delivery. For a woman with recurrent herpes but no active lesions at the time of delivery, a vaginal delivery is safe.
  • C) Postpartum antiviral therapy for the newborn: While antiviral therapy may be given to the newborn if there are concerns of neonatal herpes, the most crucial intervention occurs before delivery. Preventing the transmission during labor through maternal antiviral treatment is far more effective.
  • D) Routine administration of acyclovir to the newborn after delivery: Newborns are not routinely given acyclovir unless there are symptoms or evidence of neonatal herpes infection. The key step is preventing neonatal herpes through the management of the mother's condition during pregnancy.

Summary:

  • Oral antiviral therapy for the mother starting at 36 weeks gestation reduces the risk of genital herpes outbreaks at delivery and helps prevent neonatal transmission.
  • Cesarean section is indicated only if active lesions are present during labor.
  • Postpartum antiviral therapy and routine administration of acyclovir to the newborn are not the primary preventive measures for neonatal herpes.

Type: Must know

Topic: Management of genital herpes in pregnancy

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) - Genital Herpes: Treatment and Management

questions.text: A 56 year old patient brought to emergency department seeking treatment for hyperkalemia. His ECG showed tall T waves with normal rhythm. Laboratory examination showed serum potassium levels to be 7.5 mEq/L. Which of the following therapies will lead to fastest reduction in the serum potassium levels?
questions.solution:
• Fastest acting drug in hyperkalemia is calcium gluconate but it does not reduce potassium level and only counteracts the ECG changes induced by K+.
  • For reducing the potassium level quickly, the drug is glucose insulin.

Drugs used for emergency treatment of hyperkalemia are:

  • Insulin (with glucose)
  • β-agonists
  • Sodium bicarbonate
  • Calcium gluconate

Drugs used as non-emergency measure in hyperkalemia are:

  • Loop diuretics
  • K+ exchange resins [Sodium polystyrene sulfate]

Indications of insulin therapy

  • All cases of IDDM
  • NIDDM patients Not controlled on OHA
    • In pregnancy
    • In complications like diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar coma (regular insulin i.v. is preferred).
    • To tide over stressful conditions like infections and surgery etc.
  • Acute hyperkalemia

Key takeaway

  • Fastest acting drug in hyperkalemia is calcium gluconate but it does not reduce potassium level and only counteracts the ECG changes induced by K+. For reducing the potassium level quickly, the drug is glucose insulin.

[Must Know]

[Insulin]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 291

choices.text: The cholera toxin is a protease that degrades mucosal proteins, leading to fluid loss.
The cholera toxin causes prolonged activation of adenylate cyclase, increasing intracellular cAMP levels and resulting in electrolyte and water secretion.
The cholera toxin inhibits the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, resulting in decreased absorption of fluids.
The cholera toxin disrupts the tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, leading to leakage of plasma into the intestinal lumen.

questions.text: In the context of cholera, which of the following statements accurately describes the role of the cholera toxin in the pathogenesis of the disease?
questions.solution:
The cholera toxin causes prolonged activation of adenylate cyclase, increasing intracellular cAMP levels and resulting in electrolyte and water secretion.

Mechanism of action of Cholera toxin -

  1. Binding: The B subunit of cholera toxin binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells.
  2. Entry: The toxin is internalized into the cell and transported to the endoplasmic reticulum.
  3. Activation: The A subunit is cleaved, and the A1 fragment enters the cytoplasm, acting as an enzyme.
  4. ADP-Ribosylation: A1 modifies the Gsα protein, leading to constant activation of adenylate cyclase.
  5. Increased cAMP: Adenylate cyclase converts ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP), increasing intracellular cAMP levels.
  6. Chloride Secretion: cAMP activates CFTR chloride channels, causing secretion of chloride ions into the intestinal lumen.
  7. Water Loss: Sodium and water follow chloride into the lumen, resulting in massive fluid loss and watery diarrhea.
  • A) The cholera toxin is a protease that degrades mucosal proteins, leading to fluid loss.
    • Incorrect. The cholera toxin is not a protease and does not directly degrade mucosal proteins. Its mechanism involves the activation of cellular signaling pathways.
  • B) The cholera toxin causes prolonged activation of adenylate cyclase, increasing intracellular cAMP levels and resulting in electrolyte and water secretion.
    • Correct. The cholera toxin binds to the Gs protein, leading to the persistent activation of adenylate cyclase. This results in elevated intracellular cAMP levels, which subsequently cause the intestinal epithelial cells to secrete excessive amounts of electrolytes and water into the lumen, leading to diarrhoea.
  • C) The cholera toxin inhibits the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, resulting in decreased absorption of fluids.
    • Incorrect.The cholera toxin does not inhibit the sodium-potassium ATPase pump. Instead, it affects fluid secretion by increasing cAMP levels.
  • D) The cholera toxin disrupts the tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, leading to leakage of plasma into the intestinal lumen.
    • Incorrect.The cholera toxin does not primarily affect tight junctions. It acts through the adenylate cyclase pathway to induce fluid secretion, rather than causing structural changes to tight junctions.

Key Takeaway:

The cholera toxin causes cholera by increasing intracellular cAMP levels through prolonged activation of adenylate cyclase, which leads to excessive secretion of electrolytes and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in severe diarrhoea.

TIPS AND TRICKS - Bacteria that act by Camp - CALP

C-Cholera toxin

A-Anthrax

L-heat Labile toxin of ETEC

P- Pertussis

Reference: World Health Organization (WHO) Guidelines on Cholera: WHO Cholera Guidelines

choices.text: It is the most common esophageal diverticulum found today.
It is specifically found herniating from Killian triangle, between the horizontal fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and the oblique fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle.
All of the above are false.

questions.text: All of the following statements are false about the condition seen in below image of Barium swallow except_______
questions.solution:
The barium swallow image is diagnostic of Zenker’s diverticulum and is the most common esophageal diverticulum.

Option A: Originally described by Zenker and von Ziemssen, the pharyngoesophageal diverticulum (Zenker diverticulum) is the most common esophageal diverticulum found today

Option B: It is usually manifested in older patients in the seventh decade of life and has been postulated to be a result of loss of tissue elasticity and muscle tone with age.

Option C: It is specifically found herniating from Killian triangle, between the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle. As the diverticulum enlarges, the mucosal and submucosal layers dissect down the left side of the esophagus into the superior mediastinum, posteriorly along the prevertebral space.

Reference: Sabiston textbook of surgery; 21st edition; chapter 42 ; page 1028.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has been trying to conceive for 2 years without success. Her hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is normal, but her laparoscopy reveals bilateral endometriomas. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Bilateral endometriomas are a common manifestation of endometriosis and can significantly impair fertility. In women with infertility and endometriomas, appropriate surgical management can improve ovarian function and enhance the chances of conception.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) In-vitro fertilization (IVF):

  • IVF is an option for women with severe endometriosis or persistent infertility after surgical management.
  • It is not the first-line treatment for this patient, as laparoscopic management of the endometriomas can restore fertility and should be attempted before IVF.

B) Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy (Correct):

  • Surgical removal of endometriomas improves ovarian anatomy, reduces inflammation, and enhances spontaneous pregnancy rates.
  • Laparoscopic cystectomy is especially indicated when endometriomas are bilateral, large (>4 cm), or symptomatic, as in this case.
  • It also facilitates histopathological confirmation, ruling out rare malignancy.

C) Hormonal therapy:

  • Hormonal treatments like GnRH agonists suppress ovulation and are not compatible with attempts to conceive.
  • Hormonal therapy is typically used for symptomatic relief, not for infertility management.

D) No treatment is required:

  • Endometriomas impact ovarian function and fertility. Observation without intervention is not appropriate in an infertile woman with documented endometriomas.

Type: Must know

Topic: Endometriosis and Infertility

Reference: Practice Committee of the American Society for Reproductive Medicine, Endometriosis and infertility guidelines.

questions.text: A 40 years old male presents with diplopia and easy fatiguability. The weakness is most severe in afternoon and evening particularly after repeated use of a muscle. on evaluation Hb-12.5 gm/dL, LFT and RFT are within normal limits. ANA is negative. There is no history of joint pain, skin rash, oral ulcer, dyspnoea on exertion or cough. Which of the following antibody is expected to be positive in this case?
questions.solution:
• Proximal muscle weakness with fatiguability on repeated activity and diurnal variation of weakness (with morning being time of least weakness and worsening of weakness on activity) strongly suggests the diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis.
  • The various antibodies that are positive in Myasthenia gravis include:
  • anti-AChR antibodies: seen in ~85% of all myasthenic patients but in only ~50% of patients with weakness confined to the ocular muscles. The presence of anti-AChR antibodies is virtually diagnostic of MG, but a negative test does not exclude the disease.
  • Antibodies to Musk are present in ~40% of AChR antibody-negative patients with generalized MG. Musk antibodies are rarely present in AChR antibody-positive patients or in patients with MG limited to ocular muscles.
  • antibodies to LRP4 and Agrin are found in rare patients with MG.
  • Anti-striated muscle antibodies directed against titin are other rare antibodies.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 3511

Option B): It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal stenosis or atresia and is therefore more prevalent in children with Down syndrome.

Option C): Duodenal obstruction typically causes vomiting in the neonate.The usual treatment is bypass (duodenoduodenostomy).

Option D): The diagnosis may be made in later life as a cause of pancreatitis, in which case resection of the head of the pancreas should be considered.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents at 16 weeks with a history of two previous second-trimester losses. On examination, her cervix is noted to be 2 cm dilated with no visible membranes. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of two previous second-trimester losses, which may indicate cervical insufficiency. Although she is already 2 cm dilated, the fact that there are no visible membranes suggests that cervical cerclage could still be performed. The goal is to prevent further pregnancy loss or preterm birth. Emergency cerclage is not indicated in the absence of bulging membranes, and progesterone therapy alone is not sufficient for this clinical scenario.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Cervical cerclage (Correct):

  • The patient’s history of recurrent second-trimester losses and current cervical dilation without visible membranes is indicative of cervical insufficiency, for which a cervical cerclage is recommended. It is the gold standard treatment in such cases and can reduce the risk of preterm birth.

B) No intervention:

  • In a patient with cervical insufficiency and dilated cervix at 16 weeks, no intervention would significantly increase the risk of pregnancy loss or preterm birth. Active management, such as cerclage, is required.

C) Emergency cervical cerclage:

  • While cerclage is indicated, this is not an emergency situation. Emergency cerclage is typically performed when there are visible membranes, which is not the case here. Routine cervical cerclage is appropriate.

D) Progesterone therapy only:

  • Progesterone therapy can reduce the risk of preterm birth but does not address the mechanical issue of cervical insufficiency, such as cervical dilation. Therefore, cerclage is the more appropriate choice in this case.

Type: Must know

Topic: Cervical Cerclage

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Chapter 11 First & Second Trimester Pregnancy Loss, Page no. 542-543

questions.text: A 16 year old female with severe persistent asthma is placed on multiple medications. She has been taking her medications as instructed, but one of the Medicine is causing her to have tachycardia, nausea, and jitteriness. She has been informed of the need to measure serum levels of this medication. Which medication is responsible for the above given undesirable side effects?
questions.solution:
• The methylxanthine agent is given in asthma because of its prominent bronchodilatory effect.
  • These agents have a low therapeutic index and often can cause adverse effects.
  • Narrow therapeutic index drug has low safety of margin. Hence, it requires monitoring of blood levels -Therapeutic drug monitoring.
  • Normal therapeutic range: 5-15 mg/dl
  • It is degraded by CYP1A2.
  • Side effects:
    • Mnemonic [DSP having Nausea]
      • Diuresis
      • S
      • Palpitation and arrhythmias
      • Nausea/vomiting/diarrhea
      • Pulsatile headache.

Option A: Ipratropium bromide is a short acting inhaled anticholinergic bronchodilator, Administered as aerosol, they produce minimal antimuscarinic side effects due to poor systemic absorption.

Option B: Montelukast and zafirlukast are very safe drugs; produce few side effects like abdominal pain, headache and rashes

Option C: Zileuton(Lipoxygenase inhibitor) inhibits synthesis of LTB4 (chemotactic) and LTC4 and LTD4 (bronchoconstrictor). Limiting features of this drug are short duration of action and hepatotoxicity.

Key Takeaway

  • Methylxanthines directly stimulate the heart and increase force of myocardial contractions. They tend to increase heart rate

[Must Know]

[Theophylline]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 246

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, lower abdominal pain, and mild vaginal spotting. Her β-hCG level is 2500 IU/L, and a transvaginal ultrasound shows no intrauterine pregnancy but a 2 cm adnexal mass without cardiac activity. She is hemodynamically stable. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Option wise analysis:

A. Laparoscopic salpingectomy

  • Used for surgical management of ectopic pregnancy in cases of hemodynamic instability, contraindications to methotrexate, or failed medical management.

B. Single-dose methotrexate therapy

  • The preferred treatment for hemodynamically stable patients with ectopic pregnancies, β-hCG levels <5000 IU/L, and an adnexal mass <3-4 cm without cardiac activity.

Methotrexate is the preferred treatment for hemodynamically stable patients with ectopic pregnancies who meet the following criteria:

  • β-hCG levels are <5000 IU/L.
  • Adnexal mass is <3-4 cm and shows no cardiac activity.
  • The patient has no contraindications to methotrexate (e.g., hepatic or renal dysfunction, blood dyscrasias).

C. Expectant management

  • Considered only if the patient is asymptomatic, with very low and declining β-hCG levels (<1000 IU/L), and no evidence of rupture or mass.

D. Laparotomy

  • Indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients or those with a ruptured ectopic pregnancy requiring immediate surgical intervention.

Type: Must know

Topic: Management of ectopic pregnancy

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Chapter 6, Early Pregnancy Complications, Page no. 110

questions.text: Which of the following is suggestive of new bone formation in human body?
questions.solution:
Markers of bone metabolism are used to evaluate the balance between bone formation and resorption. These markers are classified into markers of bone formation and markers of bone resorption.

Bone Formation Markers:

  1. Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP):
    • Specifically, bone-specific alkaline phosphatase (BAP) is a key enzyme produced by osteoblasts (bone-forming cells).
    • It is involved in the mineralization of the bone matrix and reflects osteoblast activity, making it a reliable marker of bone formation.
    • Increased levels of BAP indicate heightened bone formation activity, often seen in conditions like osteoporosis treatment, growth, or bone repair.
  2. Osteocalcin:
    • A protein secreted by osteoblasts that plays a role in bone mineralization and calcium ion homeostasis.
    • It is a direct product of osteoblast activity, making it another marker for bone formation.
  3. Procollagen Type 1 N-terminal Propeptide (P1NP):
    • Derived from the precursor of type 1 collagen, the most abundant protein in the bone matrix.
    • P1NP reflects collagen synthesis, directly linked to bone formation processes.

Bone Resorption Markers (for contrast):

  • Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP): Produced by osteoclasts and indicative of bone resorption.
  • C-terminal telopeptide (CTX): A breakdown product of type 1 collagen degradation during bone resorption.
  • Deoxypyridinoline: A cross-link of collagen that is released during bone breakdown.

General orthopaedics and basic sciences

Reference: Rockwood and Green's Fractures in Adult's 9th edition, page no. 148.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with involuntary leakage of urine when sneezing or coughing. She denies any urgency, nocturia, or dysuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
SUI is characterized by involuntary leakage of urine during physical activity, coughing, or sneezing, due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and a weak urethral sphincter.

Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) is caused by the failure of the urethral sphincter to prevent urine leakage when intra-abdominal pressure increases. This commonly occurs during activities like coughing, sneezing, laughing, or physical exertion. It is typically not associated with urgency, nocturia, or dysuria, distinguishing it from other types of incontinence.

Other Options Explained:

  • A) Urge incontinence: Characterized by a sudden, intense urge to urinate and inability to hold urine. Often associated with overactive bladder.
  • B) Overflow incontinence: Results from chronic urinary retention leading to continuous dribbling or incomplete voiding.
  • D) Mixed incontinence: A combination of symptoms of both stress and urge incontinence.

Type: Must know

Topic: Stress urinary incontinence

Reference: Shaw’s Gynaecology 17th edition, Chapter 31 Urinary Fistula and Stress Urinary Incontinence, Page no. 384

choices.text: To store repressed memories that cannot be accessed by conscious awareness.
To bring unconscious material into conscious awareness by linking it with words.
To allow wishes and desires to be fulfilled according to the pleasure principle.
To act as a barrier preventing instinctual drives from influencing the conscious mind.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary function of the preconscious system in Freud's topographical model?
questions.solution:
Option A: Incorrect. The preconscious does not store repressed memories; that function is attributed to the unconscious system. Repressed material remains outside of conscious awareness until it passes through the preconscious.

Option B: Correct. The preconscious system functions as a link between the unconscious and the conscious. It makes unconscious material accessible by associating it with words, making it possible for this content to reach conscious awareness.

Option C: Incorrect. The fulfilment of wishes and desires is characteristic of the unconscious system, particularly through primary process thinking. The preconscious system is involved in making unconscious content accessible, not fulfilling desires directly.

Option D: Incorrect. While the preconscious does play a role in accessing repressed material, it does not act as a barrier. The unconscious is more responsible for repressing instinctual drives and keeping them from entering conscious awareness.

FREUD'S TOPOGRAPHICAL MODEL OF THE MIND:

  • Freud’s Topographical Model: Divides the mind into three systems-conscious, preconscious, and unconscious.
  • Conscious System: Contains perceptions from the outside world and body, brought into awareness. It uses "attention cathexis" to focus psychic energy on specific ideas.
  • Preconscious System: Holds material that can be brought into conscious awareness by focusing attention. It interfaces with both the unconscious and conscious.
  • Unconscious System: Contains repressed material, primarily driven by instincts. It follows primary process thinking, disregards logic, and operates on the pleasure principle.
  • Repression: Keeps unconscious material out of consciousness. Unconscious content can enter consciousness through the preconscious if censorship is overcome.
  • Limitations: Freud later discarded the topographical model due to issues like defence mechanisms and unconscious needs for punishment, though some concepts remain useful (e.g., wish fulfilment, primary/secondary thought processes).

Tags:

Topic: Sigmund Freud, Topographical model

Difficulty Level: Must know

References: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 34, Pages 3323

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with severe abdominal pain. On doing blood investigations, serum amylase and lipase were elevated. On imaging, it was labelled as acute necrotizing pancreatitis. On doing a follow up CT scan after 5 weeks, a hypodense lesion was found in the region of pancreas. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Walled-Off Necrosis (WON)

  1. Development and Maturation:
    • Timeline: WON typically matures around 4 weeks after the onset of acute pancreatitis.
    • Formation: It forms when an area of pancreatic necrosis becomes encapsulated by a well-defined, thick wall of granulation tissue and fibrous tissue, separating the necrotic area from the surrounding healthy tissue.
  2. Composition and Structure:
    • Non-Liquefied Material: Unlike pseudocysts, which contain liquid, WON consists of necrotic tissue that has not undergone complete liquefaction. This material is often more solid or semi-solid.
    • Well-defined wall: The thick wall surrounding WON is typically well-defined and can be seen on imaging studies. This wall represents the encapsulation formed by the body's inflammatory response.
  3. Imaging Characteristics:
    • CT Scan: On a CT scan, WON appears as a hypodense (dark) area with a well-defined, thick wall. This appearance contrasts with the typically more fluid-filled pseudocyst, which is less defined and has a more uniform density.
  4. Potential Involvement:
    • Parenchyma and Peripancreatic Tissue: WON can involve both the pancreatic parenchyma (the functional tissue of the pancreas) and the surrounding peripancreatic fat.
    • Parenchyma Alone or Peripancreatic Fat Alone: It can be confined to the pancreatic tissue or to the peripancreatic fat alone, depending on the extent of the necrosis and the body’s response.

Clinical Implications:

  • Diagnosis: CT imaging is crucial for identifying WON, differentiating it from other pancreatic complications such as pseudocysts or abscesses.
  • Management: Treatment may involve supportive care, drainage if the WON causes symptoms or complications, and addressing the underlying cause of the acute pancreatitis.

Option A and C: Pseudocyst and acute peripancreatic fluid collection are seen in acute edematous pancreatitis

Option D: Acute necrotic collection is seen in acute necrotizing pancreatitis in less than 4 weeks duration.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Walled off necrosis is when an area of pancreatic necrosis becomes encapsulated by a well-defined, thick wall of granulation tissue and fibrous tissue, separating the necrotic area from the surrounding healthy tissue.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 688.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and hepatomegaly. Imaging studies reveal a large, heterogeneous liver mass. Biopsy confirms Hepatic Angiosarcoma. All of the following exposures are associated with this except?
questions.solution:
Hepatic angiosarcoma is a rare and aggressive primary malignant tumor of the liver that originates from endothelial cells lining blood vessels.

Several environmental and chemical exposures have been associated with an increased risk:

  1. Thorium dioxide (Thorotrast): Historically used as a contrast agent in radiology, it has been linked to a high incidence of hepatic angiosarcoma.
  2. Vinyl chloride: A chemical used in the production of plastics has been strongly associated with hepatic angiosarcoma.
  3. Arsenic: Chronic exposure to arsenic has been implicated in the development of hepatic angiosarcoma.
  4. Anabolic steroids: Long-term use of anabolic steroids may increase the risk.
  5. Hemochromatosis: Some reports suggest an association between hepatic angiosarcoma and hereditary hemochromatosis, a condition characterized by excess iron storage in the liver.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Hepatic Angiosarcoma is a rare, aggressive liver cancer often associated with variety of carcinogenic exposures including Arsenic(A), Thorotrast(B) and poly vinyl chloride(D).

Iron does not have any role in causing hepatic angiosarcoma.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran, 10th Edition, Page No.522.

choices.text: It increases blood calcium and phosphorus level
It increases blood calcium but decrease phosphorus level
It decreases blood calcium level but does not affect phosphorus level
It decreases blood calcium and phosphorus level

questions.text: Which of the following is true about parathyroid hormone?
questions.solution:
• Option b: PTH raises blood calcium by stimulating bone resorption (via osteoclast activity), increasing calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and promoting the activation of vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol), which enhances intestinal calcium absorption. PTH decreases blood phosphorus levels by increasing renal phosphorus excretion.
  • Option a: While PTH increases blood calcium levels, it decreases blood phosphorus levels, calcitriol increases the blood calcium and phosphorus level.
  • Option c: PTH does not decrease blood calcium levels. Its primary role is to maintain calcium homeostasis by increasing blood calcium levels. It also affects phosphorus levels by decreasing renal reabsorption. Calcitonin reduces the blood calcium level by increasing calcium deposition on bone.
  • Option d: PTH increases the blood calcium but decreases blood phosphorus level. This is not the correct option.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 874-875

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for FNAC?
questions.solution:
Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) is a diagnostic procedure used to extract cells from a mass for examination under a microscope. While it is generally considered safe, there are some contraindications to its use.

Absolute Contraindications:

  1. Uncorrected bleeding disorders: FNAC should be avoided in patients with significant coagulopathies or uncorrected bleeding disorders (e.g., hemophilia, thrombocytopenia) due to the risk of hemorrhage.
  2. Unstable vascular lesions: Vascular lesions like aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) should not be aspirated as puncturing them can result in catastrophic bleeding.
  3. Infection at the puncture site: If the skin or surrounding tissues at the aspiration site are infected (e.g., cellulitis, abscess), FNAC can worsen the infection or cause it to spread.

Relative Contraindications:

  1. Lack of a safe pathway: In cases where a clear, safe pathway to the mass is not available, such as with deep-seated lesions near major blood vessels or vital structures, FNAC should be done under imaging guidance or avoided.
  2. Suspected vascular tumors: Tumors with a highly vascular nature, like hemangiomas, should be approached with caution as they may bleed during or after the procedure.
  3. Patients on anticoagulant therapy: While anticoagulation therapy is not an absolute contraindication, special precautions should be taken. In some cases, stopping the anticoagulation or bridging with another therapy may be necessary.
  4. Very small or cystic lesions: In cases of small lesions or cystic structures, FNAC may not yield sufficient diagnostic material, which can limit the utility of the procedure.
  5. Poor patient cooperation: FNAC requires the patient to remain still during the procedure. Uncooperative patients, such as those with mental or neurological conditions, may pose a challenge, and sedation may be required.

Explanation:

B. Bleeding disorders, such as hemophilia or thrombocytopenia, increase the risk of excessive bleeding during FNAC.

A. Pregnancy is not a contraindication for FNAC, but caution should be taken.

C. Previous surgery at the site is not a contraindication, but may affect the accuracy of the results.

D. Age > 60 years is not a contraindication for FNAC.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The risks and benefits of performing FNAC should be carefully weighed, and alternative diagnostic methods may be considered if the risks are too high.

REFERENCE: ORELL & STREERTT'S FNAC, 5TH EDITION, PAGE NO.10.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their characteristic features.
questions.solution:
Impaired Oxidation of Fatty acids gives rise to diseases often associated with Hypoglycemia. Inherited defects in the enzymes of B oxidation and Ketogenesis also lead to nonketotic hypoglycemia, coma and fatty liver.

Defects in long and short chain 3-hydroxyacyl coA dehydrogenase - deficiency of the long chain enzyme may be cause of acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

Jamaican vomiting sickness is caused by eating the unripe fruit of the akee tree, which contains the toxin hypoglycin. This inactivates medium and short chain acyl coA dehydrogenase, inhibiting B oxidation and causing hypoglycemia.

Refsum disease is a rare neurologist disorder caused by a metabolic defect that results in the accumulation of phytanic acid.

Zellweger also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome occurs in individuals with a rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues. They accumulate C 26 - C 38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue with generalize loss of peroxisomal functions leading to severe neurological symptoms.

Reference: Harper' Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, chapter 22, page 225

questions.text: The diagram is showing the inferior view of the liver. The marked area is represented as which of the following Couinaud's hepatic segment?
questions.solution:
• Marked area is the quadrate lobe of the liver.
  • According to this nomenclature of Couinaud, segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe.

Couinaud's hepatic segments of the liver:

  • These are structural units of the liver.
  • There are eight hepatic segments.
  • The right physiological lobe is divided into anterior and posterior parts, and the left physiological lobe into medial and lateral parts.
  • Each of these parts is further divided into upper and lower parts and form eight surgically resectable hepatic segments.
  • The veins draining the hepatic segments are intersegmental, i.e., they drain more than one segment.
  • On the surface of the liver, there is no identifiable demarcation between anterior and posterior segments of the right lobe.
  • The fissures for ligamentum teres and ligamentum venosum mark the junction between the medial and lateral segments of the left lobe.
  • The caudate and quadrate lobes are incorporated into the upper and lower areas of the medial segment of left lobe.
  • According to nomenclature of Couinaud, the hepatic segments are numbered I to VIII
  • I to IV in the left hemiliver and V to VIII in the right hemiliver.
  • According to this nomenclature, the segment I corresponds to the caudate lobe and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe.
  • Segment I to IV of the left lobe are supplied by the left branch of hepatic artery, left branch of portal vein and drained by left hepatic duct.
  • The segments V to VIII of right lobe are supplied by right hepatic artery, right branch of portal vein and drained by right hepatic duct.

Reference: Textbook of anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume 2, 4th Edition, Page No 103, 104

questions.text: Name the marked muscle in the given diagram
questions.solution:
• Marked muscle is Ischiococcygeus.
  • It is part of the pelvic floor.

Pelvis muscles:

  • The muscles arising within the pelvis form two groups.
  • Piriformis and obturator internus form part of the walls of the pelvis and are considered primarily as muscles of the lower limb.
  • Levator ani and ischiococcygeus form the pelvic diaphragm and delineate the inferior limit of the lesser pelvis.
  • The fasciae investing the muscles are continuous with visceral pelvic fascia superiorly, perineal fascia inferiorly and obturator fascia laterally.

Coccygeus (ischiococcygeus):

  • The coccygeus is a small triangular muscle situated behind the levator ani muscle
  • Origin: It arises by its apex from the pelvic surface of ischial spine and sacrospinous ligament.
  • Insertion: From its base into the sides of upper two pieces of coccyx and the last piece of sacrum.
  • Nerve Supply: The ventral rami of 4th and 5th sacral nerves (S4, S5).
  • Actions
    • Assist the levator ani muscles to support the pelvic viscera.
    • Produce minor movements of the coccyx.

Reference: Textbook of anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume 2, 4th Edition, Page No 202, 203

questions.text: What is the primary mode of transmission of Cryptosporidium parvum?
questions.solution:
Contaminated water or food is the primary mode of transmission for Cryptosporidium parvum.

Treatment - Nitazoxanide

Cryptosporidium parvum: 4 sporozoites

Size-4-6µm

  • A) Airborne droplets
    Incorrect. Cryptosporidium parvum is not transmitted via airborne droplets; it is primarily spread through ingestion of contaminated substances.
  • B) Contact with infected animals
    Incorrect. While Cryptosporidium parvum can be found in animals, the primary transmission route is through contaminated water or food rather than direct animal contact.
  • C) Contaminated water or food
    Correct. Cryptosporidium parvum is primarily transmitted through ingestion of water or food contaminated with oocysts of the parasite. This is a common cause of outbreaks in areas with poor sanitation.
  • D) Direct skin contact
    Incorrect. Cryptosporidium parvum is not transmitted through direct skin contact. Transmission occurs through the ingestion of oocysts.

Key Takeaway: Cryptosporidium parvum is primarily transmitted via contaminated water or food, making good hygiene and safe water practices crucial in preventing infection.

Tag Line: Moderate

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Cryptosporidiosis

questions.text: siRNAs are most commonly associated with which biological phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The small ncRNAs termed miRNAs and siRNAs typically inhibit gene expression at the level of specific protein production by targeting mRNAs through one of several distinct mechanisms.

In the laboratory siRNAs are frequently used to decrease or "knockdown" specific protein levels (via siRNA homology-directed mRNA degradation), and thus serve as an extremely useful and powerful alternative to gene-knockout technology.

They guide the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC) to a specific target mRNA, where the siRNA's sequence is perfectly complementary to the target. This leads to the cleavage and degradation of the target mRNA, preventing its translation into protein.

Option A) Chromatin remodeling: While RNAi mechanisms can sometimes influence chromatin structure indirectly, this is not the primary function of siRNA.

Option C) Translation initiation: siRNAs act downstream of transcription and do not affect the initiation of translation.

Option D) DNA methylation: siRNAs do not directly cause DNA methylation, though certain RNAi pathways may influence epigenetic modifications.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter 34, Page 358-359

choices.text: Observe the patient with no further treatment
Repeat serum beta-hCG testing in another 48 hours

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy is given methotrexate. Her serum beta-hCG levels on day 4 show a 15% decrease from the initial value. What should be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
A 15% decrease in beta-hCG is a satisfactory response to methotrexate treatment. The next step is to continue monitoring the patient by repeating serum beta-hCG levels in 48 hours to ensure proper decline. If the levels continue to drop, expectant management can proceed.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Administer another dose of methotrexate:

Additional doses of methotrexate are only required if beta-hCG levels fail to decline by ≥15% between days 4 and 7.

B) Observe the patient with no further treatment:

While the initial response is favorable, continued monitoring is essential to confirm sustained decline and prevent complications.

C) Schedule the patient for surgery:

Surgery is reserved for cases of ruptured ectopic pregnancy, hemodynamic instability, or failure of medical management.

D) Repeat serum beta-hCG testing in another 48 hours (Correct):

This ensures that the patient is appropriately monitored to confirm resolution of the ectopic pregnancy.

Type: Must know

Topic: Management of ectopic pregnancy

Reference: Aria's practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery, 4th edition, Chapter 6, Early Pregnancy Complications, Page no. 110

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, G1P1, presents with complaints of fatigue, dry skin, and weight loss 4 months after an uncomplicated delivery. She also reports that she has not been able to breastfeed. Her labs show low prolactin, low cortisol, and low TSH levels. What is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of her condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient's presentation of fatigue, dry skin, weight loss, inability to breastfeed, and laboratory findings of low prolactin, low cortisol, and low TSH levels suggests a pituitary dysfunction, potentially Sheehan syndrome or another cause of hypopituitarism.
  • MRI of the pituitary gland (OPTION A) is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for pituitary damage, such as ischemia or necrosis, which may result in a diminished production of pituitary hormones (prolactin, cortisol, TSH, etc.).
  • Cortisol stimulation test (B) could be useful if adrenal insufficiency is suspected, but in this case, the pattern of low prolactin, cortisol, and TSH is more suggestive of a central (pituitary) issue. The cortisol stimulation test would likely follow if the MRI shows evidence of pituitary dysfunction.
  • Thyroid function tests (C) would measure the levels of thyroid hormones and TSH, but the patient's low TSH and low cortisol already suggest a pituitary problem. The issue is likely at the level of the pituitary, so MRI is the most direct and effective test.
  • Serum prolactin level (D) has already been measured and is low. In the context of this patient's clinical symptoms and lab findings, the next step is to evaluate the pituitary gland itself, which can be done with an MRI.

Type: Must know

Topic: Sheehan syndrome

Reference: Speroff's Gynaecology, 9th edition, Chapter 10, Amenorrhoea, Page no. 904

choices.text: Blood in IVC has more oxygen saturation
Pressure in left ventricle is more
Brain receives blood with low oxygen saturation
Heart receives blood with low oxygen saturation

questions.text: True about fetal circulation
questions.solution:
Fig. SpO2 levels in different portions of fetal circulation

  • Blood in IVC has more saturation than blood in SVC as IVC carries the oxygenated blood of umbilical vein.
  • The left ventricular blood has more oxygen saturation that right ventricular blood because it carries the blood of IVC, while blood in right ventricle is a mixture of blood from IVC and SVC.
  • So, the brain and coronary circulation receive blood with higher saturation (through ascending aorta) than the lower half of body.
  • The pressure in right and left ventricles are equal.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1855

choices.text: No comment as very high error

questions.text: In cancer treatment, survival rate of new modality of chemo therapy is compared with standard therapy, which shows better result with p value of 0.03. True statement is:
questions.solution:
The true statement is:

b. New drug more effective

  • A p-value of 0.03 indicates that there is a statistically significant difference between the new chemotherapy modality and the standard therapy. Specifically, it means that there is a 3% probability that the observed difference is due to chance.
  • Since the p-value is less than the commonly accepted significance level of 0.05, the results suggest that the new drug is likely to be more effective than the standard therapy.

Incorrect Options:

  • a. Standard therapy more effective: The data indicates the new drug is more effective, not the standard therapy.
  • c. Inadequate data: The p-value indicates sufficient statistical evidence to suggest a difference.
  • d. No comment as very high error: A p-value of 0.03 does not indicate a high error; it shows statistical significance.

Thus, the correct interpretation is that the new drug is more effective.

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-05, Page No 106-110

questions.text: Cardiomyopathy developing during last trimester and first 6 months after pregnancy is called as?
questions.solution:
• Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is defined as heart failure during the last trimester or within the first 6 months after pregnancy, while pregnancy associated cardiomyopathy is defined as new onset heart failure within first 6 months of pregnancy.
  • Risk factors for PPCM include are increased maternal age, increased parity, twin pregnancy, malnutrition, use of tocolytic therapy for premature labor, and preeclampsia or toxemia of pregnancy.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook, 21st Medicine, page no 1963

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding undergoes an endometrial biopsy. The histopathology report reveals simple endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is usually managed with progestin therapy to induce shedding of the endometrium and prevent progression to carcinoma. Hysterectomy is typically reserved for cases with atypia or persistent hyperplasia.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Progestin therapy (Correct):

  • Progestins are the first-line treatment for simple hyperplasia without atypia.
  • Mechanism: Progestins oppose estrogen's effects by converting the proliferative endometrium to a secretory phase and promoting stromal decidualization.
  • Common regimens:
    • Oral medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA) or norethisterone acetate.
    • Levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUD), which provides local progestin delivery.

B) Hysterectomy:

  • Reserved for patients with atypical hyperplasia or cases refractory to medical management.
  • Not appropriate as an initial step in simple hyperplasia without atypia.

C) Oral contraceptives:

  • While combined oral contraceptives (COCs) can manage heavy bleeding, they are not the primary treatment for endometrial hyperplasia.
  • Progestin-only therapy is more effective in reversing hyperplasia.

D) Endometrial ablation:

  • Not recommended for patients with endometrial hyperplasia.
  • It does not address the underlying pathology and may obscure future evaluation of the endometrium.

Type: Must know

Topic: Endometrial sampling

Reference: FOGSI GCPR on AUB

choices.text: Skin traction directly applies force to the bone, while skeletal traction applies force via the skin.

Skin traction is used for short-term treatment and involves applying force through adhesive strips or boots, while skeletal traction is for long-term treatment and uses pins or wires inserted into the bone.
Both skin and skeletal traction require surgical intervention for application.
Skeletal traction is less invasive than skin traction.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key difference between skin traction and skeletal traction?
questions.solution:
Skin Traction

  • Purpose: Used for short-term treatment, such as reducing muscle spasms or stabilizing minor fractures.
  • Application: Force is applied through adhesive strips, foam boots, or bandages attached to the skin.
  • Limitations: Can only exert limited force due to the risk of skin damage.
  • Common Uses: Pre-operative stabilization of hip fractures, minor soft tissue injuries.

Skeletal Traction

  • Purpose: Used for long-term treatment of more severe fractures requiring higher force.
  • Application: Force is applied via pins, wires, or screws surgically inserted into the bone.
  • Advantages: Provides greater stability and control over the alignment of the bone.
  • Common Uses: Femur fractures, tibia fractures, or cervical spine injuries.

General trauma

Reference: J. Maheshwari's, 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics, page no. 27.

choices.text: Spondylolisthesis; conservative management with physical therapy and pain management
Degenerative disc disease; spinal fusion surgery

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with chronic lower back pain and occasional pain radiating down her left leg. She reports that the pain worsens with prolonged standing and activities like lifting. Xray is as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis and the first-line treatment approach?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation (chronic lower back pain, radiating leg pain, positive spondylolisthesis test, and radiographic findings of forward vertebral displacement) is characteristic of spondylolisthesis, specifically spondylolytic or degenerative type.

Treatment of Spondylolisthesis

Principles of Treatment:

  • Mild, symptomless cases: No treatment is required.
  • Mild symptoms: Managed with conservative methods (brace, spinal exercises).
  • Moderate to severe symptoms: If these interfere with daily activities, surgical intervention may be necessary.

Methods of Treatment:

  1. Conservative Methods:
    • Rest and external support for the affected spinal segment.
    • Flexion exercises to strengthen and stabilize the spine.
    • Lifestyle modification: Patients may be advised to switch to less physically demanding jobs.
  2. Operative Methods:
    • Decompression surgery to relieve pressure on compressed nerves, if present.
    • Fusion surgery of the affected spinal segments, typically using intertransverse fusion (fusion between transverse processes of adjacent vertebrae).
    • Internal fixation with devices like pedicular screws and rods to provide stability and promote early mobilization of the patient.

Spinal pathologies and injuries

Reference: J. Maheshwari's, 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics, page no. 285.
