questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain. On examination, there was guarding present in the abdomen. An Xray was done which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pneumoperitoneum and Its Diagnostic Features

Causes of Pneumoperitoneum:

  • Perforation of a Viscus: For instance, a perforated peptic ulcer.
  • Obstruction: Bowel obstruction leading to ischemia and perforation.
  • Inflammatory Conditions: Conditions like diverticulitis.
  • Bowel Ischemia: Loss of blood supply leading to necrosis and perforation.
  • Trauma: Injury from procedures like colonoscopy or abdominal trauma.

Identification on Imaging:

  • Erect Chest X-Ray (CXR):
    • Right Hemidiaphragm: Small amounts of free gas can be seen outlining the smooth surface of the liver, creating a visible silhouette. This is because free air rises to the highest point when the patient is upright.
    • Left Hemidiaphragm: It is often more challenging to distinguish free gas from normal stomach and colonic gas. However, free air may be seen outlining the gastric bubble or causing the diaphragm to appear more radiolucent.
  • Supine Abdominal X-Ray:
    • Right Upper Quadrant: Free air often accumulates adjacent to the liver in the subhepatic space or Morrison's pouch (hepatorenal fossa). It may be seen as a crescent of air beneath the liver.
    • Rigler's Sign: The visualization of both sides of the bowel wall (outer and inner) due to the presence of free air outlining the bowel. This can be challenging to appreciate if bowel loops are closely packed together.
  • Abdominal X-Ray (AXR):
    • Falciform Ligament Sign: Free air may outline the falciform ligament, which appears as a vertical line of gas on either side of the ligament.
    • Ligamentum Teres: Air can be seen in the fissure for the ligamentum teres, highlighting the presence of pneumoperitoneum.
  • Other Signs:
    • Cupola Sign: Free gas may join across the midline beneath both hemidiaphragms, creating a continuous crescent of gas that can be seen as a high, curvilinear shadow on X-ray.

Key Imaging Considerations:

  • Diaphragm Visibility: On CXR, the diaphragm should appear as a relatively thin structure with free gas outlined below and lung above.
  • Location of Free Air: In the supine position, free air tends to accumulate in the subhepatic space and around the liver.

Option B is incorrect because consolidation is seen in lungs as opacity.

Option C and D are incorrect as in hepatosplenomegaly and splenomegaly, there is increase in size of the soft tissue shadow of the organs.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Air under the diaphragm is due to hollow viscera perforation known as Pneumoperitoneum.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page no 463.

questions.text: When one or two nucleotides are either deleted from or added to the coding region is called as
questions.solution:
If one or two nucleotide are either deleted from or added to the coding region of an mRNA, this is called Frame shift Mutation. Altering the reading Frame.

This can result in a product with a radically different amino acid sequence or a truncated product due to the eventual creation of a termination codon. E.g Cystic Fibrosis,

Option A) The codon containing the changed base due to mutation may code for the same amino acid this is called as silent mutation.

Option B) Mutation at splice sites can alter the way in which introns are removed from pre m RNA molecules producing aberrant proteins is called as Splice Site Mutation. E.g Myotonic Dystrophy

Option D) The codon containing changed base due to mutation may code for a different amino acid called as missense mutation.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Review SAE, Chapter 37, Page 634

questions.text: Vector for Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is:B. Tick

The vector for Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) is a tick, specifically from the Hyalomma genus. These ticks transmit the virus to humans and animals.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The vector for Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) is a tick, specifically from the Hyalomma genus. These ticks transmit the virus to humans and animals.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-15, Page no. 896-899.

questions.text: Parents with a family H/O diabetes decided to promote their children to stay away from mobile and computers and spend more time in outdoor activities. Level of prevention:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is a. Primordial.

  • Primordial prevention refers to actions taken to prevent the development of risk factors themselves before they emerge. In this case, encouraging children to engage in outdoor activities and avoid sedentary behaviors (such as excessive use of mobile phones and computers) aims to prevent the development of risk factors for diabetes (like obesity or physical inactivity).
  • Primary specific prevention involves preventing a specific disease or condition by controlling its risk factors, but this scenario is broader, focusing on lifestyle changes rather than a specific preventive measure like vaccination or medication.
  • Health promotion refers to broader actions that improve overall health and well-being, but the focus here is on preventing the development of risk factors for diabetes, fitting the definition of primordial prevention.
  • Secondary prevention refers to early detection and treatment of an existing condition, which is not applicable here as the goal is to avoid the development of risk factors in the first place.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Primordial prevention refers to the prevention of the development of risk factors themselves, aiming to prevent the emergence of environmental, social, or economic conditions that contribute to disease.

It focuses on modifying lifestyle and societal factors from an early stage, such as promoting healthy habits, reducing pollution, and creating supportive environments to avoid the onset of risk factors like hypertension, obesity, or unhealthy behaviors.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-02 ,Page no. 34-38.

questions.text: All are markers of Metabolic Syndrome except
questions.solution:
Abdominal Obesity is associated with cluster of Metabolic Abnormalities including Hyperglycemia, Dyslipidemia, High Triglyceride level, Low HDL level, Hypertension, Insulin Resistance - is referred to as the Metabolic Syndrome.

It is a risk factor for Cardiovascular disease and Type 2 Diabetes. The low grade systemic inflammation seen with obesity contributes to the pathogenesis of Insulin Resistance and T2DM plays a role in Metabolic Syndrome.

The following are considered markers of metabolic syndrome:

  1. Central obesity: Measured by waist circumference (specific cutoffs vary by population and gender), but not by the waist-to-hip ratio (WHR).
  2. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure, typically defined as ≥130/85 mmHg or use of antihypertensive medication.
  3. Low HDL cholesterol: For men, HDL < 40 mg/dL; for women, HDL < 50 mg/dL.
  4. Elevated fasting blood sugar: ≥100 mg/dL or use of antidiabetic medication.
  5. Elevated triglycerides: ≥150 mg/dL or use of medication for high triglycerides.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrated Biochemistry Review SAE, Chapter 30, Page 485-487

questions.text: WFNS (World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies) grading system is used for?

questions.text: A newborn child presented with mass over dorsum of nose . On examination Furstenberg test was found to be positive. This test is positive in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
The Furstenberg test is a clinical sign used to distinguish a mass in the head that communicates with the intracranial compartment from other masses:

The Furstenberg test involves compressing the internal jugular vein to see if the mass increases in size or pulsation.

The Furstenberg test can help distinguish between an encephalocele, which communicates with the intracranial compartment, and other masses like a nasal glioma or dermoid cyst, which do not.

When the internal jugular vein is compressed, an encephalocele will increase in size or pulsation because it communicates with the intracranial compartment. In contrast, compressing the internal jugular vein usually has no effect on nasal glial heterotopias or other masses that do not communicate with the intracranial compartment.

A mass that communicates with the intracranial compartment may also increase in size when the patient cries or performs a Valsalva manoeuvre.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg 166.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant has poor weight gain, a persistent cough, and a history of several bouts of pneumonitis. The mother describes the child as having very large, foul-smelling stools for months. Which of the following diagnostic maneuvers is likely to result in the correct diagnosis of this child?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis is cystic fibrosis (CF)
  • Cystic fibrosis (CF)is a multisystem disease caused by an abnormally functioning cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) protein.
  • Abnormal secretions are produced as a result of decreased permeability of ionized chloride in the secretory epithelium of a number of organs. Progressive lung failure is caused by accumulation of viscid secretions that obstruct the airway and lead to infection, bronchiectasis, and inflammatory changes.
  • CF has common presentations in form of frequent LRTI and symptoms of protein and fat malabsorption due to pancreatic insufficiency.
  • Sweat chloride test is a good screening test in suspected cases of CF.
  • CT chest is not done as a primary screening. (option a)
  • Serum immunoglobulin levels has no role. (option b)
  • Pulmonary TB can be one of the differentials, but foul smelling stools and younger age are points against it. Hence, tuberculin test is not done primarily. (option c)

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, pg. 2282

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant presents to your clinic because the mother is concerned that he is not eating well and he has been constipated. The mother tells you that her prenatal course and delivery were uneventful. On physical examination, the infant has a puffy face, large tongue, and persistent nasal drainage. Which of the following conditions is most likely to present with these findings?
questions.solution:
• Most infants with congenital hypothyroidism are asymptomatic at birth. Feeding difficulties, choking spells, and somnolence often present during the first month of life. Respiratory distress can also occur in part due to the large tongue and nasal obstruction.
  • On physical examination, you may find a large abdomen, umbilical hernias, subnormal temperature, cold skin, murmurs, or bradycardia.
  • Profound dietary deficiency of iodine will result in hypothyroidism and is the most common cause of goiter in the world.
  • Rickets results from a deficiency of vitamin D. This condition predominately affects the long bones and skull. (option b)
  • Pallor is the most important sign of iron-deficiency anemia. Children may also have the desire to ingest unusual substances such as ice or dirt. (option c)
  • Finally, hyponatremia and hypoglycemia are the prominent presenting signs of adrenal insufficiency in infants. (option d)

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2914

questions.text: Which of the following agent is used as contrast in CT scan?
questions.solution:
Iodinated contrast agents are commonly used in CT (Computed Tomography) scans to enhance the visibility of certain tissues and blood vessels. These contrast agents contain iodine, which is highly radiopaque, meaning it absorbs X-rays effectively. This makes structures with the contrast agent appear brighter on the CT images, improving differentiation between normal and abnormal tissues.

Types:

  • Non-ionic contrast (commonly used due to fewer side effects).
  • Ionic contrast (less commonly used, can have more side effects).

Option B,C and D are incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Iodinated contrast agents are commonly used in CT (Computed Tomography) scans to enhance the visibility of certain tissues and blood vessels.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of Diagnostic Radiology, fourth edition, page no 323

questions.text: A 65 years old male reports to medical emergency with chest pain. ECG is done which shows significant ST depression in V1-V4 leads. Troponin T is negative. He is admitted and repeat ECG after 6 hours shows ST depression in V1-V6 but troponin T is again negative. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The spectrum of ischemic heart disease: Important for therapeutic and prognostic decisions: 

  • Stable Angina pectoris is presence of chest pain or anginal equivalents after a fixed level of exertion. There is no history of any recent change in nature/severity/duration of pain or these symptoms.
  • Unstable Angina: Unstable angina is defined as 1) occurrence at rest (or with minimal exertion), lasting >10 min; (2) of relatively recent onset (i.e., within the prior 2 weeks); and/or (3) a crescendo pattern, i.e., distinctly more severe, prolonged, or frequent than previous episodes. However, there is no evidence of myocyte necrosis (elevated cardiac specific enzymes).
  • Non-ST segment elevation MI- symptoms of unstable Angina + evidence of cardiac myocyte injury (typically as elevated cardiac troponins which are specific for myocyte injury) and Non-ST elevation ECG changes.
  • ST elevation Myocardial infarction: symptoms of unstable Angina + evidence of cardiac myocyte injury (typically as elevated cardiac troponins which are specific for myocyte injury) and ST elevation ECG changes.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 1988

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of a uterine septum?
questions.solution:
Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing a uterine septum because it provides direct visualization of the uterine cavity, enabling the identification of structural abnormalities. It is often combined with laparoscopy to confirm the diagnosis and differentiate it from a bicornuate uterus, a condition with similar imaging findings.

Other Options:

  • HSG: Provides a general outline of the uterine cavity but lacks specificity to differentiate septate and bicornuate uteri.
  • Pelvic ultrasound: Particularly 3D ultrasound, is useful for initial screening but not as definitive as hysteroscopy.
  • MRI: Offers detailed imaging, especially for complex anomalies, but is not as practical for routine diagnosis.

Type: Must know

Topic: Congenital uterine anomalies

Reference: American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) Practice Committee Report, "Uterine septum: Diagnosis and Management"

Camel foot rete ridges- As a result, to accommodate the increasing population of basal cells, rete pegs take a plunge in the dermis in the form of regular elongation of rete ridges, giving the "camel foot" appearance to dermal rete ridges

Seen in Psoriasis vulgaris. (Option A)

choices.text: HPV diverts blood from better ventilated areas to poor ventilated areas in the lungs
HPV occurs in response to systemic hypoxia to increase blood oxygen levels
HPV results in systemic vasodilation to maintain blood pressure
HPV helps to maintain ventilation / perfusion ratio

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV) is correct?
questions.solution:
• Option d: HPV is a physiological mechanism that improves the match between ventilation (air reaching alveoli) and perfusion (blood flow in pulmonary capillaries).
  • By diverting blood away from hypoxic alveoli to better-ventilated areas, it ensures efficient gas exchange and prevents the mismatch that could lead to hypoxemia.
  • Option a: It diverts blood flow away from poorly ventilated (hypoxic) areas of the lungs toward better-ventilated regions to optimize gas exchange. Sending blood to poorly ventilated areas would worsen oxygenation.
  • Option b: HPV is a localized response to alveolar hypoxia in specific lung regions, not a systemic response.
  • Its primary role is to optimize the ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio by redirecting blood flow within the lungs, rather than addressing systemic oxygen levels directly.
  • Option c: HPV is a local vasoconstrictive mechanism specific to the pulmonary vasculature and does not involve systemic vasodilation. It is unrelated to systemic blood pressure regulation.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.1453

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a history of regular 28-day menstrual cycles. Her last menstrual period (LMP) started on January 10, 2024. Using Naegele's rule, what is her estimated date of delivery (EDD)?
questions.solution:
Naegele's Rule: Add 1 year, subtract 3 months, and add 7 days to the first day of the LMP.

  • LMP: January 10, 2024
  • Adding 1 year = January 10, 2025
  • Subtracting 3 months = October 10, 2024
  • Adding 7 days = October 17, 2024.

Type: Must know

Topic: Naegele's rule

Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition, Chapter 10, Antenatal Care, Preconceptional Counseling and Care Page no. 107

Initiated in a facility and continued at home

questions.text: Key features of kangaroo mother care are all the following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Kangaroo care is a technique practiced on newborn, usually preterm, infants wherein the infant is held, skin to-skin, with an adult.
  • The kangaroo position provides ready access to nourishment.
  • The parent's stable body temperature helps to regulate the neonate's temperature more smoothly than an incubator, and allows for readily accessible breastfeeding.
  • Babies who are eligible for kangaroo care include pre term infants, weighing less than 1,500 grams, and breathing independently.
  • Cardiopulmonary monitoring, oximetry, supplemental oxygen or nasal (continuous positive airway pressure) ventilation, intravenous infusion, and monitor leads do not prevent kangaroo care.
  • Babies who are in kangaroo care tend to be less prone to apnea and bradycardia and have stabilization of oxygen needs.
  • KMC provider can involve father or other relatives of baby other than mother.

Reference: AIIMS protocols in Neonatology, pg. 322

questions.text: Which is the ideal position for Ryle's tube insertion?
questions.solution:
• If the patient is conscious, the best position for inserting the Ryle's tube is sitting with the neck flexed.
  • The best position for comatose individuals is supine with the neck flexed.

The steps for inserting a Ryle's tube include:

  • Position: A conscious patient should be Sitting with neck flexed.
  • Check placement: Ask the patient to speak to assess the tube's position. You can also use pH paper to measure the aspirate pH.
  • Secure: Tape the tube to the patient's cheek to hold it in place.
  • Preparation: Put on gloves, gown, and face shield. Check the nostrils for obstructions and patency. Place a towel over the patient's chest.
  • Anesthesia: Spray a topical anesthetic in the nostril and pharynx at least five minutes before insertion.
  • Lubricate: Apply a water-soluble lubricant to the tip of the tube.
  • Insert: Gently insert the tube into the nose, aiming toward the earlobe.
  • Advance: Ask the patient to take sips of water through a straw while advancing the tube.

It's important to verify the tube's placement before each feeding to prevent complications like aspiration pneumonia.

Confirmation of correct position of Ryle's tube:

  1. Auscultation of epigastrium while injecting bolus of air through it
  2. Chest radiography
  3. pH measurement
  4. Ultrasound

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 336.

questions.text: Which of the following features on ultrasound help in identifying the gall bladder calculi?
questions.solution:
Posterior acoustic shadowing (or simply acoustic shadowing) is an ultrasound artifact that occurs when sound waves encounter a structure that strongly attenuates or blocks the transmission of sound. This typically happens with dense structures such as bone, calcifications, or stones (e.g., gallstones or kidney stones).

Because the sound waves are either absorbed or reflected by these structures, very little or no sound energy reaches deeper tissues, resulting in a dark or hypoechoic shadow on the ultrasound image behind (posterior to) the attenuating structure.

This shadowing effect is useful in diagnostic imaging, as it can help identify and characterize solid, dense objects, such as stones, calcifications, or foreign bodies.

Option A: Posterior acoustic enhancement (also known as through transmission) is an ultrasound phenomenon that occurs when sound waves pass through a structure with low attenuation, such as fluid-filled areas (e.g., cysts, the urinary bladder, or gallbladder). As the sound waves travel through these structures, they lose very little energy.

On the ultrasound image, this results in an area of increased brightness or echogenicity immediately posterior (deeper) to the low-attenuating structure. This phenomenon helps differentiate fluid-filled structures from solid masses, as solid masses tend to attenuate sound waves more and would not exhibit posterior enhancement.

Option B: Reverberation is an ultrasound artifact that occurs when sound waves bounce back and forth between two strong reflectors, producing multiple equally spaced echoes on the image. This creates the appearance of repeated structures that are not actually present, often seen in fluid-filled areas like the bladder or cysts.

Option D: Ring Down artifact in radiology, particularly in ultrasound imaging, refers to a type of reverberation artifact caused by trapped gas bubbles. It produces a continuous, solid streak or band of echoes extending down from the source of the bubbles.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Posterior acoustic shadowing (or simply acoustic shadowing) is an ultrasound artifact that occurs when sound waves encounter a structure that strongly attenuates or blocks the transmission of sound. This typically happens with dense structures such as bone, calcifications, or stones (e.g., gallstones or kidney stones).

Reference: Diagnostic Ultrasound, sixth edition, page no 27

questions.text: What anesthetic gas is in the blue conduit in OT?
questions.solution:
Blue pipeline in OT delivers Nitrous Oxide

choices.text: Baby fed with a bottle finding it difficult to suckle at breast
Baby on breastfeeding not able to suckle with bottle
Baby on spoon feeding not able to breastfed
Baby not accepting feed and needs feeding tube

questions.text: What is Nipple confusion?
questions.solution:
• A problem that may be seen in a bottle-fed baby in which it forgets how to nurse on mother's nipple
  • Breastfeeding requires far more vigorous mouth and tongue motions and greater muscle coordination than bottle-feeding.
  • On bottle nipples or even pacifiers, a newborn can forget how to nurse properly.
  • This confusion can lead to diminished or discontinued nursing. Nipple confusion is usually not a concern after the early weeks, once the baby is nursing well.

Reference: Care of newborn, Meharban Singh, 8th ed., pg. 233

choices.text: Slow-twitch (S) fibers have a high innervation ratio, providing sustained activity with large motor units
Fast-twitch fatigable (FF) fibers have a low innervation ratio, supporting brief, high-intensity contractions
Slow-twitch (S) fibers have a low innervation ratio, suitable for fine control and sustained activity
Fast-twitch fatigable (FF) fibers have a low innervation ratio and are primarily used during endurance activities

questions.text: A 32-year-old athlete presents to the clinic complaining of muscle fatigue and occasional difficulty in maintaining posture during prolonged physical activity. His muscle strength is normal but declines rapidly with sustained effort. Electromyography (EMG) reveals differences in motor unit recruitment and firing patterns. Which of the following best explains the innervation characteristics observed in this case?
questions.solution:
• On the basis of the type of muscle fiber they innervate, and thus on the basis of the duration of their twitch contraction, motor units are divided into S (slow), FR (fast, resistant to fatigue), and FF (fast, fatigable) units.
  • There is also a gradation of innervation of these fibers, with S fibers tending to have a low innervation ratio (ie, small units) and FF fibers tending to have a high innervation ratio (ie, large units).
  • A specific muscle action is developed first by the recruitment of S muscle units that contract relatively slowly to produce controlled contraction.
  • FF muscle units are recruited for the most demanding tasks. For example, in muscles of the leg, the small, slow units are first recruited for standing. As walking motion is initiated, their recruitment of FR units increases. As this motion turns to running or jumping, the FF units are recruited.
  • From the above explanation option c is true.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no.274

choices.text: Increase in conductance of K+ in the nodal tissue
Slows down the depolarizing effect of h current

questions.text: A physiologist was teaching the student effect of Valsalva manoeuvre on cardiac potential. Valsalva manoeuvre does not cause which of the following changes in the nodal tissue?
questions.solution:
• Valsalva maneuvers occur regularly during coughing, defecation, and heavy lifting. Increase in intrathoracic pressure against closed glottis increase in intrathoracic pressure and causes strong vagal stimulation.
  • Vagal stimulation leads to decrease the slope of the prepotentials rather than increase in slope (Option d)
  • When the cholinergic vagal fibers to nodal tissue are stimulated, the membrane becomes hyperpolarized (option a).
  • Acetylcholine released at the nerve endings increases the K+ conductance of nodal tissue (option b). This action is mediated by M2 muscarinic receptors, which, via the βγ subunit of a G protein, open a special set of K+ channels.
  • The resulting K+ currents (IK Ach) through these G protein-gated K+ channels slow the depolarizing effect of h current. (Option c)
  • There is decrease in firing rate in the nodal tissue reduces the heart rate.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 1184

choices.text: Scratching inhibits histamine release from mast cells
Scratching activates large fast conducting fibers that inhibit itch signals
Scratching blocks the release of prostaglandins in the skin
Scratching decreases the production of substance P

questions.text: Why does simple scratching relieve the sensation of itching?
questions.solution:
• Option b: Scratching activates A-beta fibers, which are large, fast-conducting mechanoreceptive fibers. These fibers stimulate inhibitory interneurons in the spinal cord, which suppress itch signals transmitted by slower-conducting C-fibers carrying itch sensation.

This interaction, known as the "gate control theory of itch," explains why scratching temporarily relieves the sensation of itching.

  • Option a: Histamine release from mast cells is a primary trigger for itch, particularly in allergic reactions. However, scratching does not directly inhibit mast cell degranulation or histamine release.
  • Option c: Prostaglandins are inflammatory mediators that sensitize neurons to itch and pain. However, scratching does not directly affect their release.
  • Option d: Substance P is a neuropeptide involved in pain and itch signaling, particularly in chronic conditions. While scratching might modulate the sensation of itch, it does not reduce substance P production.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 386

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms inhibit HCl secretion from the stomach?
questions.solution:
• Option c: Somatostatin, released by D cells in the stomach, inhibits gastric acid secretion by:
    • Directly acting on parietal cells to decrease HCl secretion.
    • Inhibiting the release of gastrin from G cells.
    • Reducing histamine release from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells.
  • Option a: Gastrin, secreted by G cells, stimulates HCl secretion by binding to CCK-B receptors on parietal cells and ECL cells.
    • Effect: It enhances histamine release from ECL cells, which in turn further stimulates HCl secretion.
  • Option b: Acetylcholine, released from vagus nerve endings, binds to M3 receptors on parietal cells, directly stimulating HCl secretion.
    • Effect: It also stimulates gastrin release from G cells and histamine release from ECL cells, increasing HCl secretion.
  • Option d: Histamine is released by ECL cells and binds to H2 receptors on parietal cells, stimulating HCl secretion.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page no. 1053, 1076

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetic medications should not be used in chronic renal failure?
questions.solution:
• Pethidine (also known as meperidine) is an opioid analgesic commonly used for pain management.
  • In patients with chronic renal failure, pethidine should be avoided due to its active metabolite, normeperidine, which can accumulate and cause neurotoxicity.
  • Normeperidine can lead to central nervous system excitation, seizures, and other adverse effects, particularly in patients with impaired renal function.
  • Alternative opioids with shorter or no active metabolites, such as fentanyl or sufentanil, are preferred in patients with chronic renal failure.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no. 727

questions.text: A 20 year old patient complained of swelling over the knee joint. There was no history of trauma or pain. On examination it was non tender. An x-ray was advised which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteochondroma is typically identified on imaging studies, especially X-rays, and has characteristic features that help in diagnosis.

Radiological Features:

X-ray:

  • Appearance: Appears as a well-defined, cortically based bony outgrowth (exostosis) that protrudes from the bone surface.
  • Stalk: Often has a "stalk' or pedunculated appearance, connecting to the underlying bone.
  • Cartilage Cap: A thin layer of cartilage may be visible over the bony protuberance, though this is not always discernible on X-rays.

CT Scan:

  • Provides a more detailed view of the bony structure and can better demonstrate the cartilage cap.
  • Useful for evaluating the extent of the lesion and any involvement with surrounding structures.

MRI:

  • Offers detailed visualization of the cartilage cap and surrounding soft tissues.
  • Helpful in assessing any potential complications, such as soft tissue masses or changes suggestive of malignant transformation.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that consists of bone and cartilage.

It is one of the most common benign bone growths and typically arises near the growth plates of long bones, such as the femur, tibia, or humerus. The tumor forms as an outgrowth of the bone surface, covered by a cartilage cap, and can occur as a solitary lesion or as part of a condition called multiple hereditary exostoses (MHE).

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 1014

questions.text: What is the root value of the nerve injured in the fracture shown in the given diagram?
questions.solution:
• Diagram is showing the fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus.
  • In case of the fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus, there is a chance of the injury to the ulnar nerve.

Ulnar nerve:

  • It is branch of medial cord of brachial plexus.
  • Root valve: C7, C8, T1
    • C7 fibres from communicating branch of the lateral root of median nerve.
  • Also known as musician nerve.
  • Branches in arm: No branches given
  • Branches in forearm:
    • Muscular branches:
      • Flexor carpi ulnaris
      • Medial half of flexor digitorum profundus
    • Cutaneous branches:
      • Dorsal cutaneous branch for medial one-third of dorsum of hand.
      • Palmar cutaneous branch for medial one-third of palm.
  • Branches in Hand:
    • Muscular branches:
      • Palmaris brevis muscle
      • Flexor digiti minimi
      • Opponens digiti minimi
      • Abductor digiti minimi
      • 3rd and 4th lumbricals
      • Dorsal and palmar interossei
      • Deep head of flexor pollicis brevis
      • Adductor pollicis
    • Cutaneous branches:
      • Digital branches to medial 1½ fingers, nail beds and dorsal aspects of distal phalanges

Nerve related to the humerus:

  • Three nerves are directly related to the humerus and are, therefore, liable to injury.
  • The axillary nerve at the surgical neck
  • The radial nerve at the radial groove at middle of shaft
  • The ulnar nerve behind the medial epicondyle

Reference: Textbook of anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume - 1, 4th Edition, Page No - 178 to 181
